On November 23, 2021 at 9:48 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmetha White made an unannounced inspection visit to Owens Small Family Home for the purpose of conducting an Annual Random Inspection. LPA met with the Licensee, who granted access to the home and together a tour of the entire home was conducted. The facility is licensed to provide care and supervision services for four (4) female developmentally disabled and/or medically fragile children, ages 3-17 years old, ambulatory only. The census today is zero (0) and living in the home currently are the Licensee and the Licensee’s Mother. The program accepts Regional Center Placement Children. The facility is set up as follows: This is a two--story 6 bedrooms 2 ½ bathroom, home located in a residential area. The home has a living room, dining room, kitchen, a pantry area, a laundry area, and a backyard. Living Room: is equipped with a two sofas, a screened fireplace, a small glass table, and a cabinet. Dining Room: is equipped with a wooden table and six (6) chairs. Kitchen: is equipped with a four (4) burner stove, a wall oven, a refrigerator/freezer, a microwave, and a dishwasher. There is also a sliding glass patio door which opens to the backyard. Sharp knives are kept in a locked kitchen drawer and made inaccessible to children in care. The food service is adequate with perishable and nonperishable food supplies. Pantry area: is located between the dining room and kitchen and contains additional food supplies. Laundry area: is located off the kitchen and it is equipped with a washer and dryer. Backyard: is free from obstructions and contains a small shed which LPA observed is used for storage. Bedroom #1: Is located downstairs and is vacant. The room is equipped two twin size beds. The room has a closet and drawer space, working lights, and windows. Bedroom #2: Is located downstairs and is occupied by Licensee. The room is equipped two twin size beds. The room has closet and drawer space, working lights, and a window. Bedroom #3: Is located downstairs and is used as an office space with a desk, chair, and a filing cabinet. Bedroom #4: Is located upstairs and is vacant. The room is equipped a queen size bed. There are adequate drawers, closet space, working lights, and a window. Report continued on LIC 809-C

Bedroom #5: Is located upstairs and is vacant. The room is used for storage. Bedroom #6: Is located upstairs and is occupied by Licensee’s Mother. The room is equipped a queen size bed. There are adequate drawers, closet space, a working light, and windows. LPA observed the home to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. The home has a working telephone readily accessible to children in care. There are no security bars on the windows of the home. Disinfectants and Cleaning solutions are made inaccessible to the children. Caregiver maintains a safe and comfortable temperature in the home. Hot water is kept at a safe temperature. LPA observed the home to have ( ) fully charged fire extinguisher. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. The First Aid Kit was checked and found to be complete. LPA observed passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps and open porches were unobstructed. The front and backyard were clean and free of debris. There are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the home. There was no swimming pool, hot tub, spas, nor similar bodies of water located at the facility. Adequate supervision will be provided for children when in care. Caregiver will provide and ensure three nutritious meals, snacks and special diets. LPA reminded Licensee to ensure the following when children are in placement: Children are accorded personal rights and the corresponding form is in their file. Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Licensee acknowledges abuse reporting requirements. Licensee’s First aid/ CPR training is valid until 01/27/2023. Emergency telephone numbers are posted in a prominent location. Caregiver has not conducted any training hours. Licensee and adults residing in the home have DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances as well as Child Abuse Index Checks. During the visit, LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. All posting requirements for Small Family Home Licensure and Emergency Plan were met. The home currently has no staff or clients placed in the home. Licensee was issued an advisory note regarding ongoing training hours. PER California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTER 4 no deficiencies were cited during this visit.

On Thursday 7/29/21 at 1:05PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility for a required annual inspection. LPA met with Licensee Naneth Pama Caderao and informed of the purpose of the visit. Safety precautions were taken, including a pre-visit screening call, at-visit temperature screening, hand hygiene, and mask-wearing. The facility has three staff and three children in care. LPA conducted confidential interviews with staff and residents. Interviews did not indicate any violations. LPA utilized the Inspection Tool to conduct the inspection. LPA observed the facility files to meet the requirements with the following exceptions: There is no LIC 9020 Register of Clients or equivalent. LPA advises, per Title 22, Section 80071, that Licensee acquire the form, fill out, and keep it in a central location in the home. LPA provided a copy of the form to Licensee. Residents R1 and R2 (See LIC 811 Confidential Names) did not have medical assessments in their files. Per Licensee, the doctor for one youth and the mother for the other youth need to send them over to Licensee. LPA advises, per Title 22, Section 80070, that Licensee ensure that the medical and capabilities assessment is obtained within 30 days of placement. The psychotropic medications were not logged on separate logs. The medication administration records were otherwise very well organized with no inconsistencies. LPA advises, per Title 22, Section 83070, that Licensee begin using the "PMAR," which LPA provided to Licensee, for all psychotropic medications. All three staff have a health screening form signed by the staff member but not filled out or signed by a physician. LPA advises, per Titel 22, Section 80066, that Licensee ensure all staff have a health screening, clearance for work, and a negative TB test result on file.

LPA inspected the facility site and observed the facility to be clean, sanitary, and in good condition. The grounds were free of obstruction and mess. There were no hazards or bodies of water. Per Licensee, there are no firearms or ammunition on the premises. Room and hot water temperatures measured within permitted ranges. A can of disinfectant spray was observed on a high shelf in an unlocked closet from when. Licensee used it earlier today, but Licensee immediately moved it to the locked chemicals storage. There are no citations. Four advisories were provided at today's visit. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Licensee Naneth Pama Caderao, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On Monday 7/11/22 at 10:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lisette Valenzuela made an unannounced visit to the above facility for a required annual inspection. LPA Valenzuela inspected the facility site and observed the facility to be clean, sanitary, and in good condition. The grounds were free of obstruction and mess. Per Licensee, there are no firearms or ammunition on the premises. The kitchen was stocked the adequate essentials to meet the client needs. Sharps and knives were stored in a locked drawer in the staff room, and chemicals were stored in locked cabinets in the locked laundry room. Food storage was sanitary and organized, and the pantry was stocked with food to meet the 7-day nonperishable, 2-day perishable mandate. Medications were locked away and separated by resident. Bedrooms were clean,linens were clean, and each resident has their own bed and closet/drawer space. The facility has four staff members and two clients currently in care. LPA Valenzuela conducted a confidential interview with the Licensee Naneth Caderao. The interview conducted did not indicate any violations. During visit, LPA Valenzuela observed that staff interact with the residents and maintain appropriate staff-client ratios. LPA Valenzuela reviewed 2 client files and 4 staff files. All files were complete and contained all the correct documentation for both client and staff files. At this time, per Title 22 Regulations, no deficiencies were cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to Licensee Naneth Pama Caderao, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

LPA observed the facility to be clean and organized and maintained in safe condition. No hazards were observed. Medications and chemicals are locked away and stored separately and safely. The ktichen is fully stocked with quality food. One assistant caregiver (S1 - See LIC 811 Confidential Names) did not have a current and valid association to the facility. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80019 Criminal Record Clearance. See LIC 809-D attached. Additionally, pursuant to Section 80019, LPA is assessing a civil penalty for the criminal record clearance violation, totaling $500. See LIC 421BG. No other deficiencies were observed. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Licensee Naneth Pama, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

investigation_findings: 13On 2/12/25 at 10:15 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted a complaint inspection at PAMA Small Family Home and spoke with Naneth Caderao, Licensee. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. Based on LPA’s interviews with staff and a review of records, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. The licensee’s admission has been documented. Therefore, the allegation— Licensee did not notify required party of licensee's absence from the facility—is SUBSTANTIATED. Facility is being cited for violation of California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 4, Sections 83061(b)(1)(A) Reporting Requirements. Please refer to the attached 9909D. At this time, one deficiency was given. An exit interview was conducted, during which appeal rights were reviewed and provided. A copy of this report was given to Naneth Caderao.

deficiencies.description:
83061(b)(1)(A) Reporting Requirements
(b)The licensee shall notify... 48 hours or longer. (1)Notification...shall include (A)Dates of intended absence. 
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interview and record review the Licensee did not comply with the section above by not notifying the licensing agency of intended absence, which poses a potential risk to health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee will review regulation and inform staff members who may serve as designated facility representatives in the event of their absence. An email confirming the date of the training, along with a list of potential designees, will be sent to the LPA by the close of business on 03/12/25.

narrative:
On 07/30/2025 at 10:30 a.m., Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Omar Sawyer and LPA Jonathan Medina conducted an unannounced Annual Inspection and met with Licensee, Naneth Caderao. LPA Sawyer disclosed the purpose of the inspection and was granted entry into the facility. At the time of the visit there are 2 Staff working and 3 Clients at the facility. The CARE Inspection Tool was used during the visit. During the inspection, LPAs obtained an updated LIC 500 (Personnel Report) to ensure the facility’s records are current. A review of the Guardian background check system on July 30, 2025, confirmed that all staff associated with the program had cleared Department of Justice (DOJ), Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), and Child Abuse Central Index (CACI) background checks. One staff member is currently listed as “in process.” Upon interview with the Licensee LPA’s were informed that potential Staff has not worked at the facility and will not be hired. The facility currently has a census of three (3) minor clients, with no more than two clients sharing a bedroom. At 10:45 a.m., LPAs reviewed four (4) staff files and three (3) client files. Client files were complete and contained admission agreements, consent forms, emergency contact information, personal property/valuables lists, and signed personal rights acknowledgments. Staff files contained required documentation, including current First Aid/CPR certifications, fingerprint clearances, educational verification, TB test results, criminal record statements, health screenings, personnel records, and employee rights forms. Staff training records and certificates were reviewed and found to be current. Continues on LIC809-C

At 12:30 p.m., during the physical plant inspection, no deficiencies were observed. The facility and grounds were found to be clean, orderly, and free of obstructions or hazards. According to the Administrator, there are no firearms on the premises. Bedrooms are double-occupancy, and each bed is equipped with clean linens and mattress pads. Adequate storage is available for resident’s personal belongings. Food was observed to be of good quality, within expiration dates, and properly stored. The water temperature measured 109°F, and the thermostat reading was 72°F, both within regulatory limits. Clients' medications were stored appropriately, Medication Administration Records (MAR) and Psychotropic Medication Administration Records (PMAR) accurately reflected administration. Staff had up-to-date First Aid and crisis intervention training. At 1:15 LPAs reviewed the operations section of the CARE tool. No deficiencies were observed in this section. Home is currently operated as stated on license and plan of operation. LPAs conducted one confidential staff interview and one confidential client interview. The required annual inspection is complete. No deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was conducted at 2:45 p.m., and a copy of this report was given to Administrator Naneth Caderao, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On March 1, 2024 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes met with Applicant Steven Johnson via Microsoft Teams to complete a component II interview. A signed copy of this report will be placed in facility file.

On April 10, 2024 at 1:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes completed a pre-licensing inspection of Peace & Love Small Family Home. LPA met with Applicant Steven Johnson who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. Currently there are no clients in placement at this time. The home is a two story building with four bedrooms and three and one half bathrooms which are set up as follows: · Bedroom #1 (Applicants) has one bed will sleep the applicant. · Bedroom #2 (Client’s) has two bed’s, it will sleep two client’s. · Bedroom #3 (Client’s) has two bed’s, it will sleep two client’s. · Bedroom #4 (Client’s) has two bed’s, it will sleep two client’s. · A great room/living room, kitchen, dining area, two bathrooms, laundry room, a two car garage, a loft, an office and the backyard. The Client’s bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two client’s will be in a room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate closet space for the client’s belongings. There was a smoke detector / carbon monoxide detector in every bedroom. The eight smoke detectors / carbon monoxide were checked, and they were working properly. The house is equipped with a fire sprinkler system. The home’s central air conditioning module was located on the side of the house. The home’s tank less hot water heater was located the garage. The appliances were in working order. The client’s files will be locked inside a file cabinet in the master bedroom. There was adequate food storage space and a supply of two days of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable foods. A trash can for storage of solid waste had a tight-fitting lid and was present.

The sharp knives will be in a locked cabinet above the stove. The medications will be located in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. The hot water in the master bath measured to be 107.8 degrees Fahrenheit, the hot water in bathroom two measured to be 110.4 degrees Fahrenheit, in bathroom three 114.8 degrees Fahrenheit and in bathroom four 117.1 degrees Fahrenheit. The home’s First Aid kit was accessible and is located in the kitchen. The first aid kit is missing a thermometer, scissors, and first aid manual. There are three fire extinguisher’s present in the home one is located in the kitchen by the kitchen cabinets, one is in the upstairs laundry rooms, and one in the upstairs loft area. They were observed to be properly charged and inspected by the fire department. Licensee stated there were no weapons/firearms in the home. There is no pool or other body of water at the home. The backyard where clients will have access to play is fenced. There is no land line phone in the home. The following corrections need to be made · Complaint hotline number needs to be posted · The following supplies are needed for the first aid kit o Thermometer o Scissors o First aid manual · Home phone line A Component III was completed. An exit interview was conducted. Application will be forwarded to the Licensing Program Manager for Licensing.

narrative: On November 15, 2024, at 9:30AM, a Component II Office Visit was held to discuss the application received for Pean Small Family Home located at 26808 Sassafras Court, Canyon Country, CA 91387. On December 20, 2024, at 9:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA), Kim Dear and Licensing Program Manager, (LPM), Enrique Hernandez, arrived at Pean Small Family Home for the purpose of conducting a Pre-Licensing Inspection. LPA and LPM met with Anne Thiongo and Peter Kihumbu, Licensees who granted access to the home and provided a tour of the home. A health and Safety inspection was conducted upon entrance onto the property. The home will provide care and supervision to four (4) developmentally disabled children, male and female, ages 3-17 years, ambulatory only. Currently the census is zero (0). The home has no bodies of water on the premises. LPA observed the following during the inspection: : This home is a two story home five (5) bedrooms, four (4) bathrooms, living room, dining room, family room, kitchen, laundry room, a detached three (3) car garage, and a backyard. There are eleven (11) total dual carbon monoxide and smoke detector units and three (03) fire extinguishers are located throughout the home: (1) Kitchen, (1) Laundry room and (1) in the garage. The first floor : Kitchen: Equipped with a five (5) eye burner gas stove, tested for operation, adequate eating utensils , microwave, refrigerator/freezer, and a dish washer. There is a mid sized table with seating for six. There is wooden wall cabinet that is locked and can be opened with a key and/ or magnet for the medication. Cabinet area stores knives and are locked. In lower drawer, kitchen and the cleaning supplies are stored in a locked cabinet under the sink. See 809C

Dining Room: Seating for 8-10 people around a large wooden table and (2) two end tables. Family Room: Consists of (3) large sectional sofas, a large TV, a non- operational electric fireplace with locked glass. All furniture is in good repair. Guest Bedroom : Has queen sized bed, toilet, shower, double sink, adequate lighting, and (2) night stands. 1st. Bathroom: Bathroom has double sink, a shower, and flushing toilet. Locked cabinet has four (4) drawers for extra linens, towels, and extra personal hygiene products for clients. Hallway: There is a second closet and cabinet for licensee personal clothing items. Personal Rights, the Grievance process, Disaster Plan, Discipline Policies and Procedures were displayed in hallway. Currently, all adults in the home have a Criminal Clearance on file with Community Care Licensing Division. Seating Area: (2) Large sofas , seating areas small round table and a large ottoman and a china cabinet. Second Floor/ Interior: Play Room: Equipped with two (2) large sofas, a mid- sized sofa, piano, television, easel/ dry- erase board, desk with chair. Balcony with locked door, accessible by door with screen. Master Bedroom: Occupied by Licensee. Equipped with a king-sized bed, sink, shower, jacuzzi, dresser drawer, adequate lighting, and a window. 2nd. Bathroom: Bathroom has a shower and tub feature, window, trash can with lid, and flushing toilet. Bedroom # B: to be occupied by Client. Equipped with a (2) twin sized beds, dresser drawer, lighting, and a window. Bedroom # C: to be occupied by Client. Equipped with a (2) twin- sized bed, dresser drawer, adequate lighting, and a large window. 3rd.. Bathroom: Bathroom has a shower and tub feature, window, trash can with lid, and flushing toilet. See 809C

Laundry Room: Equipped with an operable washing machine and dryer, fire extinguisher. Cabinets store laundry supplies and some cleaning agents. Door entrance has lock operated by fingerprint / or code on door knob. Office Area: Equipped with a desk, computer station, locked cabinet for staff/client files. Playroom: is equipped with large television, sofas, adequate lighting and age-appropriate toys and games. There is also access to balcony. Door remains locked. All furniture is in good repair. Garage/ Exterior:: Is detached from home. Garage area remains locked and is only accessible to the Licensees and is inaccessible to residents. A toolbox, refrigerator and storage shelves are also present. tools are also located in this area. (2) Bar- B- Que grills, (1( Propane and the other charcoal burning. Water hose is stored in a closed container. Licensee registered (2) two vehicles for transportation. A 2016 Honda van, and a 2017 Acura. The water temperature was recorded at 70 degrees. (Water heater currently being replaced at the time of the inspection. Back& Front Yard/ Exterior: Yard is free of debris and hazards. The water shut off valve is located at the front of the home. The home has no bodies of water on the premises. Transportation Vehicles: 2016 Honda Odyssey and 2017 Acura Both vehicles are registered and are insured. Registration for both vehicles are verified current. The insurance coverage with Geico expiring May 21, 2025. Vehicles were inspected for working seat belts, front and back brake lights, blinkers, horn, to be in working order. auto Insurance policies, first-aid kit and a charged fire extinguisher, (optional). LPA observed the facility to be clean, safe and sanitary. Pathways , stairwells inclines, ramps, and open porches, are unobstructed. LPA shared reporting instructions for incident reporting,Law Enforcement contacts, a direct reporting link, about reporting all changes to within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. as well as the time frame for reporting. LPA informed the licensing that a Component III Tele- orientation will be scheduled per Community Care Licensing procedures An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On June 19, 2025, at 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Aimee Moratalla and Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Enrique Hernandez arrived at Pean Small Family Home for the purpose of conducting a Post Licensing Inspection. LPA and LPM met with Licensees, Anne Thiongo and Peter Kihumbu who granted access to the home and together a tour of the interior and exterior of the home was conducted. The census today is zero (0) and living in the home currently are the Licensees, two biological children, and Adult 1. The home has no bodies of water on the premises. A health and Safety inspection was conducted upon entrance onto the property. The facility is set up as follows: This is a two-story 5-bedroom, 3-bathroom, home located in a residential area. The home consists of a living room, receiving room, dining room, kitchen, office area, laundry area, play room, a backyard, and garage. Family room: is equipped with a sectional sofa, a mounted flat screen television, and an electric fireplace that is locked. Living room: is equipped with two couches and a coffee table. Dining room: is equipped with a table that seats eight. Kitchen: is equipped with a refrigerator/freezer, a five (5) burner gas stove/oven (all burners were operational at the time of this inspection), dish washer, and a microwave. Sharp knives are kept locked in a kitchen drawer next to the stove. Cleaning supplies are kept in the laundry area equipped with a fingerprint lock. Report continued on LIC 809C.

The kitchen also has an exit door that leads to the backyard. From the backyard there are two gated pathways that lead to the street. Office area located on the second floor: is equipped with table, chair, two monitors, and computer. Laundry area: is located on the second floor next to the office area and is equipped with a washer and a dryer. A fire extinguisher, and cleaning tools are stored in this area. Backyard: contains two barbeque grills, portable plastic table, and a water hose in a storage container. Garage: LPA observed the garage is used for storage, with TV, couch, a fridge that contain alcohol – secured with a lock; the door from the house always remains locked and is made inaccessible to children in care. Bedroom #1: is located on the first floor – for guests. The room is equipped with queen-sized bed, closet, dresser, and television, a working light, and two windows. This room was vacant at the time of the inspection. Bedroom #2: is located on the second, it’s the master’s bedroom (A). This room is equipped with king-sized bed, at the foot of the bed are toddler beds, a dresser, bathroom, two walk-in closets. The room contains a working light, windows. Bedroom #3: is located on the second floor (B). The bedroom is occupied by Child#1. The room is equipped with a bunk bed and the bottom part is detached and next to it is another twin bed, dresser, closet, a working light, and windows. Bedroom #4: is located on the second floor (C). The bedroom is occupied by Child#2. The room is equipped with bunk bed, closet, dresser, a working light, and windows. Bedroom #5: is located on the second floor (D). The bedroom is occupied by adult#1. The room is equipped with a bunk bed, closet, two dressers, a working light, and windows. (3) Bathrooms: one bathroom is located along the hallway on the first floor, second and third bathrooms are located on the second floor. The bathrooms contain a toilet, sink/s, and a combined shower/tub. The hot water was tested and found to be with 105-120 (F) Report continued on LIC 809C

LPA observed one (2) fully charged fire extinguisher. The hallway on the second floor has cabinets which store extra linens. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. Medications are stored in a locked cabinet above the kitchen counter. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept locked inside the laundry room. The home has a working telephone readily accessible to children in care. The First Aid Kit was checked and found to be complete. LPA observed the home to be clean, safe, and sanitary. Passageways, stairways, and hallways are unobstructed. The front and backyard were clean and free of debris. There are no bodies of water located on the premises. The water shut off valve is in the front of the home and the shut off valve for the gas and electricity are on the side of the home. LPA reminded Licensees to ensure to send a copy of the program statement, of the new car registration, and fire extinguisher maintenance tag, and the emergency disaster plan. To install lock on the door that leads to the garage, and to secure the television in the room. During the visit, LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. All posting requirements for Small Family Home Licensure and Emergency Plan were met. The home currently has no staff or clients placed in the home. An exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with the Licensee, Peter Kihumbu

On November 14, at 1:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Cheraki Davis began a pre-licensing inspection for Phrasiah Small Family Home license. The home is a one story building with four bedrooms and two bathrooms which are set up as follows: · Bedroom #1 (Master) has one bed, will sleep the licensee, and has a master bathroom. · Bedroom #2 (Guest) had one queen bed; was vacant and will not be used for clients. · Bedroom #3 (Client’s) was vacant, had two twin-sized beds. It will sleep two clients. · Bedroom #4 (Guest) had one queen size bed, was vacant and will not be used for clients. · A great room/living room, kitchen, dining area, two bathrooms, an attached two car garage, a laundry room, storage closet, and the backyard. The Client’s bedroom was arranged so that no more than two clients will share the room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate closet space for the client’s belongings. There was a smoke detector in every bedroom and a carbon monoxide / smoke detector located in the hallway. The four smoke detectors and the carbon monoxide / smoke detector were checked, and they were working properly. The home’s central air conditioning module was in the side yard. The client’s files will be locked inside a locked cabinet. There was adequate food storage space and a supply of two days of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable foods. A proper storage of all food was discussed. A trash can for storage of solid waste did not have a tight-fitting lid and was located in a kitchen cabinet. The hot water in the Master Bathroom measured to be 105 degrees Fahrenheit. The client bathroom also had a trash can with a working lid. The water temperature of the client bathroom was observed to be 106.3 degrees Fahrenheit. The home’s First Aid kit was accessible the first aid kit was missing the first aid manual and thermometer and located in the pantry. The following deficiencies were observed: The client’s beds need a fitted and plat sheet placed on them. The medication and vitamins were not stored in a locked cabinet. The required forms needed prior to operation, were not posted at the time of this inspection. The lock on the side gate needs to be change so that it can be used as a fire exit. The request for a license will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval once the Plan of Corrections are cleared. An exit interview was conducted. On 11/20/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit to deliver notice of deficiencies found during an investigation and inspection of the facility. LPA met with Licensee Robin Ann Prior and informed of the purpose of the visit. On 11/20/23, Licensee did not have an available phone and the doorbell does not ring, contributing to an approximately 1 hour long delay in granting LPA entry to the facility. Licensee's house phone is no longer in operation, and Licensee stated she depends on the cell phone, which was not operational due to the battery being low or dead. LPA issued an advisory. See LIC 9102. The resident in care has a gastrostomy tube, but no individualized health care plan could be located in the facility files, and Licensee was unable to supply one. LPA issued a citation of 83069.1(a). LPA informed Licensee that the needs and services plan may be combined with the individualized health care plan. However, no needs and services plan could be located either. LPA issued a citation of 83068.2(a). Licensee was also unable to supply a first aid/CPR certificate and evidence of training by a health care professional to provide specialized health care to the resident in care. Licensee stated they completed the first aid training in 2022, but no certificate could be supplied during inspection. LPA issued citations of 83075(f)(2) and 83065.1(a)(1). An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Licensee Robin Ann Prior, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

deficiencies.description:
83069.1 Individualized Health Care Plans...
(a) The licensee shall not accept a child with special health care needs unless the licensee has obtained an individualized health care plan for the child.  The plan shall include the following information:...
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review, observation, and interview, licensee did not ensure maintenance of individualized health care plan due to resident with gastrostomy tube having no plan in the facility records, which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees to submit by the due date of 12/20/23: resident R1's (see LIC 811) specialized health care plan.

deficiencies.description:
83065.1 Additional Personnel Requirements...
(a)(1) Prior to caring for a child with special health care needs..., the in-home health care provider shall complete training in specialized in-home health care provided by a health care professional...
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review, observation, and interview, licensee did not ensure maintenance of documentation of training due to no documentation in facility records of licensee's gastrostomy tube training, which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees to submit by the due date of 12/20/23: documentation of licensee's gastrostomy tube training by a health care professional.

deficiencies.description:
83068.2 Needs and Services Plan
(a) At the time of placement, the licensee or a designated person shall request for each child, a needs and services plan which describes the child's service needs.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review, observation, and interview, licensee did not ensure maintenance of a needs and services, updated at least annually, due to no plan being located in facility records, which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees to submit by due date of 12/20/23: resident R1's (see LIC 811) needs and services plan and/or individualized health care plan, so long as that plan includes all information required in Section 83068.2.

deficiencies.description:
83075 Health Related Services
(f)(2) The licensee shall maintain copies of current  First Aid and  CPR certificates.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review, observation, and interview, licensee did not ensure maintenance of first aid/CPR certification due to no certification being located in facility records, which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees to submit by due date of 12/20/23: Licensee's valid and current first aid/CPR certification.

investigation_findings: 13On 11/20/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a visit to the home regarding the above allegations. LPA met with Licensee Robin Ann Prior and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential interviews, observations, and record review, it was found that there were reports of bruising and poor diapering and hygiene care provided to the resident in care. However, there were also reports, including from the assigned social worker and the investigating CPS worker, that there had been no observations nor concerns of abuse or neglect in the home. LPA's observations included that the licensee had a large supply of diapers, and the resident in care did not have a strong odor or noticeabe signs of poor hygiene. Lastly, multiple reports observed bruising to be likely from leg supports rather than abuse. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, based on LPA’s observations and interviews, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Licensee Robin Ann Prior, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

13On 2/9/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a follow-up complaint investigation visit in order to deliver investigation findings. investigation_findings: 13On 12/12/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a complaint investigation visit. LPA met with Licensee Robin Prior and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential observations, interviews, and record review, it could not be confirmed that the licensee's conduct presents a risk to the client in care. Interviews with multiple parties who oversee the care of the client in care reflect that there have been no reports or observations of suspected abuse of the client. Multiple interviews reflect observations of the licensee providing good care to the client. During LPA's observation of the client, LPA did not observe marks, injuries, or other indicators of abuse. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, based on LPA’s observations and interviews, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and the licensee's appeal rights were provided to Licensee Robin Prior, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

The above ground pool was observed with a locked fence surrounding it and keeping it inaccessible to clients. Staff and client files are kept secure in the office. AD informed LPA that if a placement was accepted, they would be placed in the single occupied rooms The master bedroom is occupied by the Administrators. Continued on 809-C

LIC 500 was observed current and has no changes since last inspection. LIC 610 is current and posted. On March 24, 2025, at 10:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Erika Butler, arrived at Power and Change Small Family Home for the purpose of conducting a Pre-Licensing Inspection. LPA met with Applicant Casper Andrews who granted access to the home and together a tour of the interior and exterior home was conducted. Home is apart of a commercial multi-use property. LPA entered the home through the commercial property, through the laundry room to gain entrance to the residential property. There are two other units on the grounds of this property. One unit is vacant, and the other unit will be vacant on the April 26, 2025. The Applicant states once tenant leaves, the units will remain vacant while licensed. The home is set up as follows: This is a three bedroom, two bathroom home located in a commercial area. The home consists of a living room, kitchen, laundry space, and backyard area, Living room: is equipped with mounted TV, sectional couch, 2 ottomans, fireplace that is not covered. Dining room: is equipped with a table with four chairs. Kitchen: is equipped with a refrigerator/freezer, a four burner gas stove (two burners were operational at the time of the inspection), and microwave. Sharp knives will be kept inaccessible in applicants locked bedroom. LPA observed a covered trash can. LPA observed ample and non-perishable food items. The Applicant will ensure that three nutritious meals and snacks will be provided to the clients. Exit signs are located at the front door and bedroom #2 door. 809 continued on page 1 of 3

Bedroom #1: Applicants bedroom is equipped with full size bed with drawers dresser, adequate closet space, television, adequate lighting, and window. Window has bars and no bar release. Bedroom #2: Client's bedroom is equipped with full bed, dresser, adequate closet space, adequate lighting, window with bars and no bar release, and exit door that leads outside will remain locked. Bedroom #3: Client's bedroom is equipped with full bed, drawers, adequate closet space, lighting, and windows. Sliding door that leads outside is currently blocked by a piece of wood. Bathroom: Bathroom #1 is located in Applicant's bedroom, and bathroom #2 is located in the hallway. Bathtub was observed to be rusted and not clean. Vehicle: The Applicant will use a 2017 GMC Sierra will be used to transport clients. Insurance is valid from February 10, 2025 - August 10, 2025. The vehicle was observed to be in good condition. The home’s temperature is maintained by central air/heating. LPA observed one fully charged fire extinguisher which is located in the kitchen. Extra linens will be stored in the cabinet in the hall. The smoke alarm and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. First Aid kit was missing thermometer. The Applicant will purchase a lock box for refrigerated medication. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept in Applicant's bedroom that will remain locked and inaccessible to children in care. LPA advised Applicant to ensure the following when children are in placement: Children are accorded personal rights and the corresponding form is in their file. Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Applicant acknowledges abuse reporting requirements. Applicant will ensure grievance process, Disaster Plan, discipline policies and procedures will be posted in dining room area. Report continued on LIC 809C. (Page 2 of 3)

LPA observed cameras in the living room, kitchen, side of the home, the alley which leads to the backyard entrance of the home, and a camera in the front of the home. During the inspection, LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. Applicant informed that the following corrections will need to be made. Lighter needs to be removed from kitchen drawer. Bathtub needs to be cleaned in bathroom #2. Applicant will purchase extra cutlery for the home. Applicant will fix the handle for the shower in bathroom #2. Applicant will place a covering over the fireplace in the living room. Applicant will purchase a lock box for refrigerated medication. Applicant will purchase a thermometer for the First Aid Kit. Applicant will fix the 2 burners on the stove Applicant will purchase a foot operator release for window guard. The Fire Department will come out to complete the inspection of the home. Applicant will have the cell phone fixed for children in care use. Applicant will purchase an alarm, and lock for the sliding door in bedroom #2. Applicant will clean the kitchen stove. Applicant's fingerprints are pending. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of report will be emailed to Applicant Casper Andrews.

On July 03, 2024, at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rafael Enriquez began a pre-licensing inspection and component III for Praise Home and Care Small Family Home for an initial license. LPA met with applicant Nelson Chiedu who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. Currently there are no children placed in the home. The applicant was approved to serve three ambulatory children ages 0 to 17. The home is a two-story building with four bedrooms and three bathrooms which is set up as follows: Downstairs: There was a formal living room, dining room, living room, kitchen, a storage room, a bathroom, three car garage, backyard, and a laundry room. Upstairs: Bedroom #1 sleeps one child, has a bunk bed with two full sized beds. It sleeps the applicant’s daughter. Bedroom #2 will sleep two foster children, has two twin sized beds. It was vacant. Bedroom #3 will sleep one foster child, has one twin sized bed. It was vacant. Bedroom #4 sleeps the applicant and his spouse, has a California King bed, has a bathroom and a walk-in closet. There was a bathroom, and hallway cabinets. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings.

The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. Telephone service and appliances were in working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients/children will have access. Sharp knives and sharp objects were locked in a cabinet in the kitchen. Cleansers/chemicals were inaccessible and stored in laundry room in a locked cabinet. There was adequate food storage space and a supply of three days of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable food. A proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. The water temperature was observed to be at 117.5 degrees. First Aid kit was accessible with all required items, and it was in the upstairs hallway cabinet. A Fire extinguisher was observed and properly charged. The fireplace was in the living room area, and it was properly screened. All the appropriate forms were posted in view of facility clients. As stated by applicant, there were no weapons/firearms and there were no pools or other bodies of water. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. The request for licensure will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to applicant Nelson Chiedu.

On September 06, 2024, at 12:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rafael Enriquez began a post-licensing inspection for Praise Home and Care Small Family Home. LPA met with licensee Nelson Chiedu who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the licensee. Currently there is one child placed in the home. The licensee was approved to serve three ambulatory children ages 0 to 17. The home is a two-story building with four bedrooms and three bathrooms which is set up as follows: Downstairs: There was a formal living room, dining room, living room, kitchen, a storage room, a bathroom, three car garage, backyard, and a laundry room. Upstairs: Bedroom #1 sleeps one child, has a bunk bed with two full sized beds. It sleeps the applicant’s daughter. Bedroom #2 will sleep two foster children, has two twin sized beds. It sleep one foster child. Bedroom #3 will sleep one foster child, has one twin sized bed. It was vacant. Bedroom #4 sleeps the licensee and his spouse, has a California King bed, has a bathroom and a walk-in closet. There was a bathroom, and hallway cabinets.

The small family home is operating within capacity/limitation, is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair, the outdoor area is free of safety hazards, no pool, or other bodies of water on premise. The SFH has adequate supply of perishable and nonperishable foods, chemicals are locked in the laundry room, knives are locked in a kitchen cabinet. The water temperature was measures at 117.5 degrees. Medications are stored in a locked kitchen cabinet, the disaster plan, personal rights, and other documentation are properly posted, smoke detectors are operable/tested. There are no firearms or dangerous weapons per licensee. First aid kit is maintained, and complete First Aid certifications are current and in expire 2/2026. All adults subject to background checks are cleared. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to licensee Nelson Chiedu.

****Continued from LIC 9099**** A confidential interview stated that a report was filed with the County about the bruises that were on FC1’s body and a report was filed with CCL a short time later. Another confidential interview stated the level of care was being met. Based on confidential interviews the allegations LIC did not report FC1’s injury to the county as necessary and FC1 sustained bruises while at the trampoline park or residential park are unsubstantiated. The allegations may have happened or be valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were explained and given to Nelson Chiedu.
investigation_findings: On January 10, 2025, at 1:13 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karen Beal met with Licensee Nelson Chiedu to deliver the investigative findings for the above-stated allegations. On November 1, 2024, at 10:36 AM, LPA initiated the investigation at Praise Home and Care Small Family Home (SFH) and obtained pertinent documents from the facility files. LPA interviewed the licensee (LIC), Foster Child 1 (FC1), County Social Worker (CSW), and Out of Home Investigator (OHI). On October 24, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint that foster parent did not report an incident involving minor in care as necessary and Minor sustained an unexplained injury while in care. Specifically, it was alleged the LIC did not report the injury immediately to the County Social Worker (CSW) and the Foster Child 1 (FC1) received bruises while at the trampoline park and a residential park. ****Continued to LIC 9099-C****

narrative:
On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Abdoulaye Traore conducted a pre-arranged pre-licensing tele-inspection as a result of COVID 19 related restrictions. This tele-inspection was conducted via facetime with applicant Evelyn Preston. The Facility was toured both inside and out the applicant. The home is a two-story home and consists of: Downstairs: a dining room with a large table, a furnished living room, a kitchen, a gaming room for Applicant’s son, a bathroom, office and the garage. Upstairs: Bedroom #1 it was furnished with a bunk bed. It sleeps the applicant’s 9-year-old daughter and 8-year-old son. Bedroom #2, the room was furnished with a full size bed, It will sleep one foster child- vacant. Bedroom #3 the room was furnished with a crib and it sleeps applicant two year old daughter. Bedroom #4, The room was furnished with a king size bed- master bedroom and it sleeps applicant and spouse. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room was commonly used for other purposes used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors were checked and were working properly. The laundry room was located upstairs with a locked door. Outside the bedrooms, there was a loft designated as a play area which contained a lot of toys appropriate for the child to be placed. The fireplace was located in the living room area and it was properly screened. Telephone service and appliances were in a working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the box located in the garage. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in a locked box in the kitchen area. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be within the range.

Proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. First Aid kit was accessible and contained all required items. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, visitation policy and Personal Rights were posted. As stated by applicant, there were no weapons/firearms and there were no pool or other body of water. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. Component III orientation was provided to the applicants/license which include incident reporting procedures, clients and staff records requirements, and client personal rights. Facility will accept only one ambulatory developmentally disabled child and licensed for a capacity of one foster child age 0-17. Based on this inspection, the home is appropriate for a capacity of one ambulatory client, all requirements are met at this time. On this date, Facility is recommended for licensure. The request of License will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report to be emailed to the applicant this date.

Bedroom #1 furnished with a bunk bed. It sleeps the licensee's 10-year-old daughter and 9-year-old son. Bedroom #2, the room is furnished with a twin size bed, a closet and plenty of storage space. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room was commonly used for other purposes other than a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and were working properly. The laundry room was located upstairs with a locked door.

The fireplace was located in the living room area and it was properly screened. Telephone service and appliances were in working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the box located in the garage. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in a locked box in the kitchen area. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be within the range. Proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. First Aid kit was accessible and contained all required items. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, visitation policy and Personal Rights were posted. As stated by Licensee, there were no weapons/firearms. There were no pool or other bodies of water. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. Facility will accept only one ambulatory developmentally disabled child and licensed for a capacity of one foster child age 0-17. Based on today's inspection and observations, there are no deficiencies being cited at this time in accordance with Title 22, Division 6, Chapters 1 & 4. Exit interview conducted and copies of this report are given.

The Facility was toured both inside and out with the Licensee. The home is a two story home and consists of: Upstairs: There was loft play area with toys and games, an office and Laundry room and: Bedroom #1 furnished with full bed size, a closet and plenty of storage space It sleeps a 16- year old client Bedroom #2, furnished with a twin size bed, a closet and plenty of storage space. It sleeps a 9-year-old male client Bedroom #3 furnished with full size bed,a closet and plenty of storage space. it sleeps a 16 year old female client Bedroom #4 Master bedroom furnished with a king size bed. It sleeps licensees Downstairs: Bedroom #5, furnished with a queen bed. a closet and plenty of storage space. It sleeps a 15 year-old-female client, a dining room with a large table, a furnished living room with a fireplace, a kitchen, a pantry, a gaming room play area, a bathroom, shoe/storage under the stairs, and the garage. All bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room was commonly used for other purposes other than a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and were working properly. The laundry room was located upstairs with a locked door.

There was 7 days of non-perishables and 3 days of fresh perishable foods observed in the pantry, refrigerator and freezer. The fireplace was located in the living room area and it was properly screened. Telephone service and appliances were in working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the locked in the laundry room. Sharp knives and objects were inaccessible and stored in a locked box in the pantry. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be at 110 degrees. Proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. First Aid kit was accessible and contained all required items. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, visitation policy and Personal Rights were posted. As stated by Licensee, there were no weapons/firearms. There were no pool or other bodies of water. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. During record reviews, LPA and LPM observed that the licensees did not maintain a separate log for each psychotropic medication prescribed to the clients. Facility was given a technical violation (83070(b)(12)). Based on today's inspection and observations, there are no deficiencies being cited at this time in accordance with Title 22, Division 6, Chapters 1 & 4. Exit interview conducted and copies of this report are given.

C1 which caused a bruise to C1’s arm. Confidential interviews and record review provided conflicting information regarding the four allegations. narrative: During investigation, confidential interviews stated that FC1 would pee on people such as FC1’s therapist. investigation_findings: 13On 07/19/2024, at 1:50 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Abdoulaye Traore conducted an unannounced visit to Preston Small Family Home (SFH) and met with Licensee (LS) Zenobia Groves to deliver the investigative finding for the allegation listed above. In addition, LPA B. Aborchie interviewed facility Staff 1, 2, & 3 (S1, S2, S3). LPA B. Aborchie also obtained documents pertinent to the investigation. Furthermore, LPA M. Perez and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Abdoulaye Traore interviewed current HM, S1, & S2 to obtain more information. On 10/04/2023, Community Care Licensing received an allegation that facility staff inappropriately handled foster child while in care. It was reported that when foster child 1 (FC1) urinated on the grounds of the home, “they” (foster mother and other adults in the home) would press FC1’s face into the urine-soaked carpet.

narrative:
Regarding the allegation that facility operated out of ratio, it was specifically alleged that several times there was only one staff working. During investigation, confidential interviews stated that each client has at minimum 1 on 1 coverage but most of the time, the facility provides additional staffing. The confidential interview added that coverage depends on the approved client’s ratios. LPA reviewed facility personnel report to ensure, the facility was following the ratio requirement according to the placement agreement. LPA was unable to gather additional information at this time. In regard to the allegation that facility staff handled youth in a rough manner, it was specifically alleged that staff grab C1 to stop C1 from hitting staff. Confidential interviews stated that staff do not grab clients. The confidential interviews continued stating that staff will try and de-escalate the behavior or redirect them. LPA was unable to gather additional information due clients refusing to be interviewed. Concerning the allegation that facility staff threw objects at youth, it was specified alleged that a human sized bear and ice was thrown at C1. Confidential interviews denied that any staff had thrown ice or a human sized bear at C1. Additionally, the confidential interviews disclosed that C1 did have a human sized bear in C1’s room but C1 never pays attention to it. LPA was unable to gather additional information. LPA was unable to interview C1 due to being non-verbal. Regarding the allegation that facility staff squirted youth with water, it was specifically alleged that staff squirted water at C1 with a water gun. During investigation, confidential interviews denied that staff has squirted C1 with a water gun. Additional confidential witnesses stated such scenario was not observed at the facility. LPA was unable to gather additional information. In regard to the allegation that youth sustained unexplained bruising in care, it was specifically alleged that bruises were observed on C1 that might have caused by staff. Confidential interviews stated that no bruises were observed on C1 recently. It was added that C1 tends to self-harm, and C1 sometimes wears a helmet and arm covers to avoid C1 from biting themselves. LPA was unable to gather additional information.

Concerning the allegation that facility staff did not intervene when youth hit another youth, it was specified alleged that C1 was observed beating C2. Confidential interviews denied that C1 beat C2. It was added that staff will keep them away from each other do to they can be unpredictable. Additionally confidential interviews stated that staff will redirect clients from each other so that they don’t hurt each other. LPA was unable to gather additional information. Finally, it was reported that facility staff smoked inside the facility in the presence of youth. It was specified that staff was smoking inside the house near the youths. Confidential Interviews denied that staff smoke in the house or around the house. It was added that the staff that smoke walk down thew street on their breaks to smoke. LPA was unable to gather additional information. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that that facility operated out of ratio, facility staff handled C1 in a rough manner, facility staff threw objects at C1, facility staff squirted C1 with water, C1 sustained unexplained bruising in care, facility staff did not intervene when youth hit another youth and facility staff smoked inside the facility in the presence of youth may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the allegations. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report along with the appeal right were reviewed and provided to facility representative.

narrative: Regarding the allegation that licensee is not meeting minors needs, it was specifically alleged that facility was not able to handle C3’s issues. During investigation, confidential interviews stated that when C3 starts having behavioral issues they follow the facility procedures. The facility will try first will attempt to de-escalate the situation, then try to re-direct, if it continues staff will call the licensee to ask if restraint or calling the police is needed. Staff will follow the instructions they are given. LPA was unable to gather additional information. In regard to the allegation that license is not providing a safe environment for minors, it was specifically alleged that C3 stated C3 did not want to be in the home. Confidential interviews stated that they try and provide an environment where all the clients can enjoy. It was added that C3 was brought in a person to teach C3 how to do nails since C3 enjoys nails. LPA was unable to gather additional information. Concerning the allegation that licensee used force to restrain minor, it was specified alleged that there were two incidents where force had to be used to hold C3. Confidential interviews stated that they practice CPI and SPA Hold as their restraint protocols which are more of self-defense. An additional confident interview stated that the police had come to the facility and had to use force to restrain C3 and eventually took C3 on a 5150 hold. LPA was unable to gather additional information. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that licensee is not meeting C3’s needs, licensee is not providing a safe environment for C1, C2, C3 and C4 and licensee used force to restrain C3 may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the allegations. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report along with the appeal right were reviewed and provided to facility representative.
