narrative:
On September 26, 2024, at 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Maryjane Perez and Joon Choi arrived at Preston Small Family Home (SFH) to conduct annual required inspection. LPAs met with House Manager (HM) Joshua Chocobar who granted us access into the home. Currently, there were 4 ambulatory clients in the home and licensed for a capacity of 6. The Facility was toured both inside and out with the House Manager. The home is a two story home and consists of: Downstairs: Bedroom #1: Furnished with a queen bed with fitted sheets and blankets and a clothes rack with plenty of storage space. Dining Room: A large table with an Arts and Crafts storage closet Living Room: Furnished living room with a fireplace, couch and TV Kitchen: A stocked pantry, locked Sharps, and fire extinguisher #1 inspected May 2024 Living Room #2: play area Bathroom #1: Running water with temperature of 119 degrees Closet #1 : Shoe/storage under the stairs Garage: office space, medications, cleaning supplies, allowance logs, first aid kit, emergency supplies and fire extinguisher #2 Upstairs: Loft: loft play area with couch and TV Laundry room: locked laundry room with detergents and clients hygiene boxes Bedroom #2: furnished with full bed size, a closet and plenty of storage space. It sleeps one client Bedroom #3: furnished with a full-size bed, a closet and plenty of storage space. It sleeps one client Bedroom #4: furnished with full size bed and a twin size bed a closet and plenty of storage space. It sleeps one client

Bedroom #5: Master bedroom furnished with a king size bed and storage space. It sleeps Administrator Bathroom #2: running water with temperature reaching 103 degrees Backyard: enclosed with fence and had side gate along with storage sheds. All bedrooms were arranged for one child per bed. There were adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and were working properly. The facility car had proof of insurance and registration all up to date, there was a fire extinguisher #3 that was up to date, first aid kit with all supplies intact. LPAs interviewed 2 staff and 1 client. LPAs reviewed 5 staff files and 4 client files. No deficiencies were cited during this visit, an exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report along with a technical assistance was reviewed and provided to house manager Joshua Chocobar.

Another confidential interview stated that when there are staff call outs, there is always someone to cover the shift, someone is always available. However, another confidential interview stated that there are issues about being short on staffing at times. Regarding the complaint that staff are using inappropriate restraints, confidential interviews stated that all the staff in the home are crisis prevention intervention (CPI) certified and follow proper protocol. Other confidential interviews stated that CPI hurts and last a long time. However, another confidential interview stated that a restraint lasts between 5- 10 minutes but no longer than that. Another confidential interview stated that a lot of clients get restrained except for the clients with autism. Also, confidential interview stated that CPI is the last resort and is rarely used. LPA received conflicting information. Based on confidential interviews and a review of pertinent documents, the allegations that the facility is operating out of ratios and staff are using inappropriate restraint may have happened or are valid but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to house manager Linda Thomas.
investigation_findings: 13On April 28, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez made an unannounced visit to Preston Small Family Home (SFH)and met with house manager Linda Thomas to deliver the findings for the above stated allegations. On November 13th, 2024, Community Care Licensing received complaint allegations that the facility is operating out of ratios and staff are using inappropriate restraint. On November 21st, 2024, LPA M. Perez conducted a health and safety inspection, and no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. LPA interviewed staff 1 (S1), staff 2 (S2), staff 3 (S3), staff 4 (S4), staff 5 (S5), client 1 (C1), client 2 (C2), client 3 (C3) and client 4 (C4). In regard to the allegation that facility is operating out of ratios, it was specifically reported that the facility is not operating according to their billing agreement ratio. During investigation, confidential interviews stated that there is not a required ratio to provide, however, the ratios used are for support and safety reasons. Other confidential interviews stated that sometimes staff complain about not having enough help.

narrative: Furthermore, other confidential interviews consistently denied the allegations and indicated that they had not witnessed any inappropriate interactions between staff and clients. It was reported that clients are always supervised with at least two to three staff members assigned to a client. Staff assignments are rotated to prevent the same staff from being assigned to the same clients. In addition to the staff rotations, confidential interviews reported that male staff members are paired with female staff members during shifts to ensure professional conduct and accountability. Male staff are also not allowed to enter the clients' bedrooms or go to the second floor without a female staff member present. Overall, confidential interviews reported that clients felt safe in the facility and comfortable around the staff. Based on confidential interviews the allegation that staff engage in inappropriate sexual interactions with the minors (C3 and C4) while in care may have happened or be valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, along with the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated January 24, 2025, and appeal rights, was explained and provided to House Manager Joshua Chocobar.
investigation_findings: 13On May 8, 2025, at 10:35 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Peete made an unannounced visit to Preston Small Family Home (SFH) and met with House Manager Joshua Chocobar, to deliver the investigative finding for the allegation mentioned above. The investigation was conducted by Special Investigator (Inv) Jesus Gonzalez of the Community Care Licensing (CCL) Investigations Bureau. The investigation included interviews the facility staff (S1-S4), clients in care (C2-C4) and law enforcement (LE). Inv Gonzalez could not interview C1 due to C1’s inability to communicate verbally. On January 17, 2025, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that staff engage in inappropriate sexual interactions with the minors (C3 and C4). However, the Inv Gonzalez did not find any corroborating statements or sufficient evidence to support the allegation. While one confidential interview expressed suspicion regarding inappropriate behaviors between the staff and clients, no additional information or evidence was provided to support the allegation. (Continued on LIC 9099C)

narrative: On June 19, 2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez arrived unannounced at Preston Small Family Home (SFH) and met with house manager Joshua Chocobar. The purpose of this visit was to address information that the department has received regarding C1's health and safety concerns. During the inspection LPA obtained pertinent documents, conducted interviews with five staff members (S1, S2, S3, S4, and S5) and conducted a health and safety inspection of the home where no hazards were observed. Due to the need to gather additional information, this case management is being extended. A copy of this report was provided to House Manager Joshua Chocobar .

On May 16th,2025, at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ashley Ruacho and Olena Maico conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection at the above address. LPAs met with Kingsford Kyei, applicant. A physical plant inspection was conducted. The following were observed at the time of inspection: This facility is a two- story home located in a residential neighborhood. This facility consists of five (5) bedrooms, three (3) full bathrooms upstairs and a half bath downstairs. On the first floor there is a living upon the entry of the home with a dining area, family room, office room, kitchen, pantry, laundry room, two car garage, front yard, and backyard space. The backyard has a locked shed for storage with its own AC unit. There are two (2) security cameras located in the front, one on top of the front door, one facing the front door from the roof along with a ring doorbell camera. There are three additional cameras in the backyard, one on each side of the home and one overlooking the backyard. There is one camera located in the garage. There are no cameras inside the home. Overall, the facility is clean, sanitary and in good condition. The facility has no bodies of water. The facility has a centralized heat and air-conditioning unit. Temperatures in all rooms are maintained at 74 degrees (F). The hot water temperature was measured at 123 degrees (F). LPAs instructed Licensee to lower the hot water temperature and ensure it does not exceed 120 degrees (F). LPAs also informed Licensee that should the temperature go above 125 degrees (F) a sign must be posted regarding temperature warning. Carbon monoxide and smoke alarms were tested and observed to be operational. There are two (2) fire extinguishers in kitchen and one in the garage. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions, will be kept and locked in the laundry room.

Knives and sharps will be locked in a kitchen cabinet. The facility has a working telephone. The applicant reports no firearms on the premises. The grounds are free from obstructions and hazards. Facility will be utilizing one bedroom for clients. During inspection, LPAs observed that the bedroom which will be used for clients has a bunk bed, closet, and desk space. A crib will be purchased if needed upon placement and set up in the mater bedroom. LPAs also observed extra linens stored in the hallway closet on the second floor. Client records and staff records will be stored and locked in downstairs office. Medications will be centrally stored in the office and a small/mini fridge will be placed in office for medications that need to be refrigerated. A complete first aid kit is readily available in a central location in the facility. Pending Items -Background Clearance are still pending, Licensee was instructed to contact Guardian as it has been pending since 10/17/24. -Applicant reports that Emergency Plan (LIC 601), facility sketch, and personal rights will be posted at the facility. -Posting of menu and activities will be posted in the kitchen. An exit interview was conducted a signed copy of this report was provided to the applicant.

met_with: Priscilla Kyei and Kingsford Kyei- Licensees
narrative:
On June 27, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Demetris Teal and conducted a Component II- in person meeting at the Monterey Park Regional Office. The following were present; Priscilla Kyei and Kingsford Kyei- Applicants of Priscilla Kyei Small Family Home. Purpose of the meeting was to review and discuss the program statement and application. LPA asked Applicants for their picture I.D;'s LPA called the meeting to order and introduced himself. LPA asked Applicants for their orientation documents to sign the Component II and Component III. Copies signed and given to applicant and placed in application file. LPA had previously asked for a copy of the Program Statement to be brought to the meeting. LPA asked Applicants to bring two copies: one to keep for the application folder and another for the Applicants to follow along with. Applicants did bring the folders but during the in-person meeting, it was decided that the Applicants would make corrections to the Program Statement again. LPA will await the updates. LPA asked Applicants if their clearances were completed on Guardian. Applicants were not sure, and a careful check of Guardian showed their status as "pending". Applicants said they were unaware how to contact Guardian. LPA sent information via email and instructed Applicants to please contact Guardian. Continued on page 2

page 2 LPA addressed questions about the qualifications of each applicant in the care of clients they will accept whom have specific medical disabilities. Applicant Priscilla Kyei is a nurse but stated she does not have training with peritoneal dialysis. Applicant Kingsford Kyei stated he does not have formal training for the disabilities listed in the program statement. LPA advised Applicants that they and any staff hired would need to be trained and have proof of training, upon demand, to give the care necessary to any client. LPA advised Applicants to please be familiar with the Small Family Home Regulations. LPA gave Applicants a printout of forms to be aware of from the CDSS public website: LIC 311E, LIC 9122A, LIC 9240 and LPA discussed LIC 624 forms. LPA gave Applicants information regarding the SIR reporting process including the email address and information to send any incident reports. LPA will email the links to the Applicants as well. LPA asked Applicants if there were any placed children in the home. Applicants said no. LPA was advised that the Applicants have three (3) biological children in the home. Applicants said that one of the children is over eighteen (18). LPA asked if the eighteen (18) year old has Guardian clearance. Applicants said no, but he is fingerprinted. LPA asked about the document in the application for health screening and the LIC 503 for Kevin Kyei. Applicants said he is their eighteen (18) year old son, but he will not be working at the home. LPA advised Applicants about their son and what he is not allowed to do with the children that are placed in the home, if he is not an approved babysitter, employee/staff, etc. Applicants asked about family members that are allowed around the placed children. LPA advised that any adult that has a criminal background, or is not approved by the State, should not be around or left alone with the placed children. Any person 18 or over living in the home should be fingerprinted. LPA asked Applicants where they would receive placements from. Applicants said the County and possibly the Regional Center. Continued on page 3

page 3 Applicants asked about visitation of placed children's relatives or biological parents in their home. LPA advised to make sure the program statement addresses it and to review the SFH regulations. LPA discussed the facility sketch and advised to ensure all rooms discussed have dimensions, per the form and clearly show clients rooms, Applicants and biological children's rooms. Component III information discussed. Component III handouts emailed and given to Applicants. LPA requested all updates to the program statement be sent to him by July 13, 2025.

The purpose of this Component II meeting was to review and discuss the incomplete application and Program Statement and to resolve any outstanding concerns that may have existed. On April 23, 2025, at 2:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Erika Butler conducted a Small Family Home (SFH) Component III office meeting with Applicant, Rene Abarca. LPA Butler met with Applicant to discuss forms required to be maintained, available, and posted at the facility for inspections. We discussed child and personnel records that are required to be documented, retained and available for inspection. We also discussed specific requirements, concerns and issues operating a SFH, such as, reporting requirements, personnel requirements, supervision, intake issues, compatibility, removal/discharge policies, complaint procedures, transportation, health services, food, hygiene, visitation, personal property, searches, and community sensitivity. Licensing of facility will be May 1, 2025. A copy of this report was provided to the Applicant, Rene Abarca.

On March 27, 2025, at 10 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cheri Wilkerson, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) JoAunne’ Griffin arrived at Prosperity Haven for the purpose of conducting a Pre-Licensing Inspection. LPA and LPM met with Dimitri Turner, Assistant Caregiver who granted access to the home and together a tour of the interior and exterior home was conducted. Currently living in the home is the Applicant and Assistant Caregiver. The health and safety assessment was conducted. The home is set up as follows: This is a two-story four-bedroom, three-bathroom home located in a residential area. The home consists of an open concept living room, dining area, kitchen, loft, laundry space, backyard area, and attached garage. Livingroom: is equipped with mounted TV, one chair, couch, and faux fireplace. Dining area: is equipped with a granite island and three chairs. Loft: is equipped with a mounted TV, chair, desk, folding table, and two chairs. Kitchen: is equipped with a refrigerator/freezer, a four-burner gas stove (all burners were operational at the time of the inspection), microwave, and dishwasher. Sharp knives are kept inaccessible in a locked Continued on LIC 809-C

cabinet in kitchen. LPA observed a covered trash can, dishes, and eating utensils. LPA observed ample and non-perishable food items. The Applicant will ensure that three nutritious meals and snacks will be provided to the clients. Bedroom #1: is located downstairs. Bedroom is equipped with a full-size bed, adequate closet space, television, adequate lighting, and windows. Bedroom has been designated as a guest bedroom. Bedroom #2: is located upstairs and will be occupied by Applicant and Assistant Caregiver. Bedroom is equipped with two full-size beds, adequate closet and dresser space, adequate lighting, and windows. Bathroom #2 is in bedroom #2 and was observed to be clean and in good repair. Bedroom #3: is located upstairs and will be occupied by child in care. Bedroom is equipped with a full-size bed, adequate closet and dresser space, adequate lighting, and windows. Bedroom #4: is located upstairs and will be occupied by child in care. Bedroom is equipped with a full-size bed, adequate closet and dresser space, adequate lighting, and windows. Bathrooms: Bathroom #1 is located downstairs in hallway near entrance and bathroom #3 is located upstairs in hallway next to laundry space. Bathrooms were observed to be clean and in working condition. Laundry Space: is located upstairs and consist of washer and dryer and cleaning supplies. Laundry space will remain locked and inaccessible to children in care. Vehicle: The Applicant will use a 2022 Dodge Charger and a 2014 Toyota Camry LE to transport children in care. Insurance is valid from January 30, 2025 -July 30, 2025 for the Camry LE. The home’s temperature is maintained by central air/heating. LPA observed one fully charged fire extinguisher which is located in the entrance to the garage. Extra linens are stored in the linen closet located upstairs in the hallway. The dual smoke/carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be Continued on LIC 809-C

in working order. First Aid kit was found to be complete with required items. Home is equipped with sprinkler system. Home was observed to have cameras in the Livingroom, downstairs hallway and upstairs hallway. Garage was observed to be used as storage space. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept under kitchen sink and is locked and inaccessible to children in care. LPA reminded Applicant to ensure the following when children are in placement: Children are accorded personal rights, and the corresponding form is in their file. Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Applicant acknowledges abuse reporting requirements. Applicant will ensure grievance process, Disaster Plan, discipline policies and procedures will be posted in common area of home. Applicant was advised that the following need to be completed prior to licensing. · Purchase a mobile phone for children in care use. · Post required postings in common area of home. · Component III will be scheduled. · Applicant will submit LIC 200 to reduce capacity to two. An exit interview was conducted with Dimitri Turner. A copy of this report will be emailed to prosperityhaven24@gmail.com.

On 7/8/2025, at 9:18 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nestor Gomez arrived at Prosperity Haven Inc. (Small Family Home), for the purpose of conducting a required Post-Licensing Inspection. LPA contacted Facility Administrator (FA), Dimitri Turner, and FA stated he was currently at work, and he could come to the facility. At 10:55 am, LPA Gomez met with Facility Administrator (FA), Dimitri Turner, who granted access to the facility and provided a tour of the facility. This small family home is a two-story four-bedroom, three-bathroom home located in a residential area. The home consists of an open concept living room, dining area, kitchen, loft, laundry space, backyard, and attached garage. There are no clients at the time of the inspection. During the time of inspection, LPA Nestor conducted an inspection of the following areas: Livingroom: equipped with a mounted tv, one lounge chair, couch, and a faux fireplace. Dining area: equipped with granite island and three chairs. Kitchen: equipped with a refrigerator/freezer, a four-burner gas stove (all burners were operational at the time of the inspection), microwave, and dishwasher. Sharp knives are kept inaccessible in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. Continue on 809-C (Page 1)

LPA observed a covered trash can, dishes, and eating utensils. LPA observed ample and non-perishable food items. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept under the kitchen sink in a locked cabinet. Loft: equipped with a mounted tv, three chairs, desk, and a folding table. Laundry space: located upstairs. Equipped with a washer and dryer. Laundry space will remain locked and inaccessible to children in care. Backyard: equipped with a grill. The backyard area is mostly empty space. Garage: Used for storage and contains a tankless water heater. The applicant stated that he plans on installing a second fridge in the garage. Licensee is storing a 2004 Ford Ranger (purple) for a relative in the garage that will not be used to transport clients. Bedroom #4: located downstairs. Currently vacant. The bedroom is equipped with a full-size bed, adequate closet space, television, adequate lighting, and windows. The bedroom has been designated as a guest bedroom, but the applicant stated that they can use the bedroom for clients if necessary. Bedroom #3: located upstairs. Currently occupied by the applicant and assistant caregiver. The bedroom is equipped with two full-size beds, adequate closet and dresser space, adequate lighting, and windows. This bedroom is equipped with bathroom #2 that was observed to be clean and in good repair. Bedroom #2: located upstairs. Currently vacant. The bedroom is equipped with a full-size bed, adequate closet and dresser space, adequate lighting, and windows. Continue on 809-C (Page 2)

Bedroom #1: located upstairs. Currently vacant. The bedroom is equipped with a full-size bed, adequate closet and dresser space, adequate lighting, and windows. Bathrooms: Bathroom #1 is located downstairs in the hallway near the entrance. Bathroom #3 is located upstairs in the hallway next to the laundry space. Bathrooms were observed to be clean and in working conditions. Additional Notes: LPA tested the water temperature in the kitchen. The water temperature results were 103 degrees Fahrenheit which does not fall within regulation. The applicant stated they will adjust the water heater temperature. The home temperature is maintained by central air/heating. The facility is equipped with two (2) fire extinguishers which are located by the backdoor exit and upstairs in the loft. LPA observed extra linens that are stored in the linen closet in the upstairs hallway. The dual smoke/carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. LPA observed the first aid kit located in a locked cabinet in the kitchen completed with the required items. The home is equipped with a sprinkler system. The Home was observed to have three (3) cameras located in the living room, downstairs hallway, and upstairs hallway. There is also a ring camera and a doorbell camera. The applicant stated that the doorbell camera does not work. Vehicles: LPA Nestor inspected two (2) facility vehicles in total. 2022 Dodge Charger (White) with current registration as stated by the FA. Insured by Direct Auto that expires on 12/11/2025. The vehicle was not at the facility during the time of the inspection. 2014 Toyota Camry LE (brownish gold) with current registration as stated by FA. Insured by Infinity Insurance company that expires on 1/30/26. The vehicle was not at the facility during the time of the inspection. Continue on 809-C (Page 3)

Staff Interview: LPA Nestor conducted one (1) staff interview with FA. Client Interview: LPA Nestor conducted zero (0) client interviews. The facility did not have any clients at the time of the inspection. There were four (4) deficiencies observed at the time of the inspection. See 809-D. A copy of this report was reviewed and provided to the FA. End of Inspection (Page 4)

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie made an announced pre-licensing inspection on 05/19/2025 at 01:00 PM and met with Purity Gachunga, Licensee. LPA Goldie toured the facility inside and out and observed the following: A dual occupancy bedroom with appropriate bedding, supplies and storage. Two restrooms are available to youth, LPA Goldie observed that the water temperature in the restrooms measured 110 degrees Fahrenheit. The kitchen is fully stocked with supplies for youth in care. LPA Goldie observed the oven, stove top, fridge and freezer were working during the inspection. There are some nonperishable foods available during inspection but no perishable supplies were present or necessary. LPA Goldie observed that the smoke detectors were all functioning and there is a carbon monoxide detector that is functioning in the hallway. LPA observed two fire extinguishers are also present. LPA Goldie observed that the yard of the facility is accessible for youth in care. LPA Goldie observed that there are fruit bearing trees in the front yard. Loose bricks were accessible and will be removed from the backyard. Outdoor activities are available. LPA Goldie observed that the locked cabinet for cleaning supplies is in the laundry area and that there is adequate storage for washing supplies. LPA Goldie observed the common area of the living room has appropriate seating for clients, family members and guests and, includes a television and books.. LPA Goldie advised licensee the program statement is still under review. Until the Program Statement is complete and approved , background clearances have been received and yard debris is removed the facility cannot be issued a license. Exit interview was conducted and document was provided.

On July 9, 2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez arrived at Purity Small Family Home (SFH) for a change of location pre-licensing inspection. LPA met with licensee Purity Ateku who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out. The licensee is applying to serve 4 clients ages 3 to 17 years old at the new location. The home is a two story building with five bedrooms and three bathrooms. The downstairs consisted of an office area where clients files/ personnel records were stored in a locked cabinet. There was a dining room area with adequate seating. Bathroom #1 was fully functioning and had water temperature measuring 110.4 degrees Fahrenheit. There was a hallway with fire extinguisher #1 and a storage closet storing extra house hold items. Bedroom #1 had two twin size beds, with all required bedding, closet/dresser space and will be utilized for two clients- currently vacant. The laundry room was accessible to clients but had a locked cabinet storing laundry detergent's. There was a living room area with a screened fire place and adequate seating. The kitchen had all required postings such as personal rights, visitation policy, emergency plan, facility sketch and house rules. There were a locked cabinets for storing medications, first aid kit. and sharp objects. The upstairs consisted of a hallway with fire extinguisher #2 that was operable, bedroom #2 that had a queen size bed, fully furnished and will be utilized for guest. Bathroom #2 was fully functioning with dual sinks and a shower. Bedroom #3 was a guest bedroom and had a queen size bed with a desk and computer. Bedroom #4 had two twin size beds, all required bedding, dresser/closet space and will be utilized for two clients- currently vacant. Bedroom #5 was the master bedroom for licensee that will be locked at all times and had bathroom #3, closet space, and a balcony that will be off limits without adult supervision.

The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced, free of hazards, had two side gates with latches for emergency use and there was no pools or other bodies of water. The garage was a two car garage and was free of hazards. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawers and closets for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients/children will have access. There was a stationed land line service and trash cans had tight fitting lids. As stated by licensee, there were no weapons/firearms There are no deficiencies observed at this time. Based on this inspection, the home is appropriate for a capacity of 4 ambulatory clients. The request for licensure will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final review and approval. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to licensee Purity Ateku

On August 16, 2023 at 2:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes began a pre-licensing inspection for Purity Small Family Home license. LPA met with applicant Purity Ateku who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. Currently there is no client in the home. The applicant is applying to serve 4 client ages 3 to 17. The home is a two story building with four bedrooms and three bathrooms which are set up as follows: · Bedroom #1 (master) has one bed sleeps the applicant and spouse and has a master bathroom · Bedroom #2 (Client’s) was vacant has two twin beds, it will sleep two clients. · Bedroom #3 (Client’s) was vacant has one twin bed and one full bed, it will sleep two client’s. · Bedroom # 4 (Guest) has one queen bed and will serve as a guest bedroom · A great room/living room, kitchen, dining area, three bathrooms, a loft, an attached two car garage, and the backyard. The Client’s bedroom was arranged so that no more than two clients will be in the room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate closet space for the client’s belongings. There was a smoke detector in every bedroom. The four smoke detectors were checked, and they were working properly. There are two Carbon Monoxide detectors one located in the dining area and one is located in the loft and were working properly. There is no dedicated phone line. The home’s central air conditioning module was located on the back porch. The home’s hot water heater was located inside the garage. The appliances were in working order. Continued on next page

The client’s files will be locked in a cabinet in the office. There was adequate food storage space. There was a two day supply of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable foods. A proper storage of all food was discussed. A trash can for storage of solid waste had a tight fitting lid. The sharp knives are in a locked kitchen cabinet. The medications are located in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. The hot water in bathroom one (master) measured to be 112.7 degrees Fahrenheit, in bathroom two 113 degrees Fahrenheit, and in bathroom three 112.8 degrees Fahrenheit. The home’s First Aid kit was accessible and is located in the pantry. Two fire extinguishers were present in the home one is located in the pantry and one is located upstairs. They were observed to be properly charged and inspected by the fire department. There is no firearm in the home as stated by the applicant. There is no pool or other body of water. The backyard where clients will have access to play was fenced. The following items need to be corrected · Dedicated telephone line · Lock up cleaning supplies · Fix hole on first landing going up the stairs. · Build dresser for girls room · Put sheets on beds The request for a license will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. On February 12, at 11:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem began a pre-licensing inspection for Radiant Roots Small Family Home license. LPA met with applicant Kierstin Dowden who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. Currently there are no clients placed in the home. The applicant is applying to serve one to two clients age 3-17 years old. The home is a one story building with four bedrooms and two bathrooms which are set up as follows: · Bedroom #1 (Master) has one bed will sleep the licensee, with attached master bathroom. · Bedroom #2 (Biological son) will not be used for clients. · Bedroom #3 (Clients) was vacant, had two twin sized beds. It will sleep two clients. · Bedroom #4 (Guest) is currently being used by the Licensee's sister. · A large family room and kitchen area, dining room, one additional bathroom, an attached garage, a laundry room, storage closet, and backyard. The Clients' bedroom was arranged so that no more than two clients will share the room, and no room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom. There was adequate closet space for the client’s belongings, as well as comfortable lighting. The clients' mattresses were in good repair and the beds' sheets were observed to be clean. There were functioning smoke detectors in the home, including the clients' bedroom, as well as a carbon monoxide detector located in the hallway. The clients will use the bathroom across the hall form their designated bedroom. The client bathroom was clean and contained a working shower, sink, and toilet. The bathroom also contains a non-slip rug. The water in the bathroom was measured to be above 120 degrees Fahrenheit, but upon adjustment of the garage water heater the bathroom sink was measured to be 117.0 degrees Fahrenheit. CONTINUED...

...CONTINUED The kitchen area was clean and contained several utensils and dishware for client use. Additionally, the fridge and pantry had adequate food and the licensee provided to LPA a thorough plan for client meals. The home's fire extinguisher is also located in the kitchen. A trash can for storage of solid waste did have a tight-fitting lid and was located in a kitchen. The water temperature in the kitchen was measured at 107.4 degrees Fahrenheit. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions, and medications are all kept locked in the hallway closet. The hallway closet also contains a complete first-aid kit and manual. The client files will be locked inside the kitchen cupboard. The living room area contains a large couch and child play area. Their are age-appropriate activities for clients to use, including toys, video games, books, and a television. The room is clean and free from obstructions, and the fireplace in the living room area is being held closed with twine. Applicant stated there were no weapons or firearms in the home. LPA observed there was no swimming pool or bodies of water on the premises. The licensee's sister has been denied fingerprint clearance and is currently living in the home. Licensee states the uncleared adult is planning on moving out in the next two weeks. The following deficiencies were observed: 1. The fireplace located in the living room needs to be securely fastened and inaccessible to clients. 2. Licensee must obtain telephone service in home. 3. The uncleared adult must move out of the home. The request for a license will be forwarded to the Licensing Program Manager for final approval once the deficiencies are cleared. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Kierstin Dowden.

narrative:
On 11/19/2021 at 11:30AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olivia made an unannounced to Raza Small Family for the purpose to conduct the Annual/Required licensing Inspection. LPA Rosas met with Adult#1(A1) who granted access to the home and an inspection of the facility was conducted together. Individuals mention in this report are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 11/19/21. The facility is a two-story family home in a gated residential neighborhood and it has six (6) bedrooms, five (5) bathrooms, living room, kitchen, dining area, backyard, fireplace with a secured screen on attached two car garage and one (1) attached garaged. There are two cats in the home. The home is licensed to serve four (4) developmentally disabled children, ages 2-17 years, ambulatory only. The annual fee is current. Currently in placement are two (2) Children. Adult#1 confirmed that there are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the facility. LPA Rosas inspected the following: Outdoor Area: There was no swimming pool or bodies of water on the premises. The activity space is free of hazard materials and debris. LPA observed a staff displayed the utility shut-off valves. The facility is surrounded by wooden fence and is observed to be good condition. The water pond is cover with rocks and no water. They have BBQ grill, and outdoor furniture. Garage: The attached two car garage is used as storage and is kept locked. Additional one car garage in front of the front door that is used as storage. Disinfectants and chemicals are locked in cabinets made inaccessible. Extra refrigerator is kept inside the garage withe extra food and snacks. Living Room: There is adequate furniture which appears to be in good condition. There is a television and fireplace that is non-operable. Report continues on LIC 809-C Page 1 of 3

Laundry Room (Upstairs) : The laundry room is located upstairs floor. The laundry is equipped with a washer and dryer unit that was observed to be in good condition. The laundry detergent is made inaccessible to the children and is disputed according the load of the laundry. Disinfectants and chemicals are locked in cabinets made inaccessible. Dining Area: One table with six chairs is next to the Kitchen: There is a gas stove/oven with four (4) burners, all operating. There is a microwave, refrigerator/freezer and a toaster oven. LPA’s observed adequate perishable/nonperishable food supplies. Sharp knives, disinfectants/cleaning solutions made inaccessible to the children locked in cabinets. investigation_findings: 13On July 7, 2022, at 9:30am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olivia Rosas made an announced inspection to Raza Small Family Home the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegations and to deliver the findings. LPA Rosas met with Adult#1 (A1) and together discussed the investigation details. Individuals mention in this complaint are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated July 7, 2022. During interviews A1 denied the allegations of having lack of supervision and allowing Child#1 (C1) to run away from the home and smoking marijuana. Further, pertinent parties denied having concerns or suspicions of abuse or neglect from A1. Based on the confidential interviews conducted during the investigation process, record review, statements obtained, the allegations cannot be substantiated. Information reviewed produced a lack of evidence to support reported allegations mention above. Report continues on LIC9099C

13On 07/14/2022 at 8:30 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Bernice Karnsrithong arrived at Raza Small Family Home for the purpose of conducting a complaint investigation. Health and safety risk assessment was conducted upon arriving at the facility. LPA met with Leila Raza, Administrator who granted access and tour of the facility. During the investigation of the allegation, Licensee did not provide child transportation to job and family visit; LPA conducted confidential interview and reviewed documentary evidences. There was no corroborating evidence that suggest that licensee did not provide child transportation to job and family visit. During the visit, LPA Karnsrithong has observed two (2) vehicles parked in a two-car garage that the licensee used to transport clients to family visit, school, doctor, and job appointments. Due to lack of evidence obtained during the investigation, LPA determines that the allegation are unsubstantiated at this time meaning, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that a violation occurred. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview conducted with Leila Raza, Administrator. A copy of this report will be provided to the facility.

On July 13, 2023 at 9:37am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made an unannounced inspection at the above listed facility and met with the Administrator (FA). The purpose of the visit is to conduct a case management deficiency inspection. This is a two story 6 bedroom, 4.5 bathroom small family home licensed for (4) children, ages 2-17 years, ambulatory only. License is posted and Foster youth Bill of rights Handbook is available for children’s reading. Upstairs Bedroom One: (1) Autistic Male Child Sheets, desk, closet and drawers for child’s personal use available. Windows have screens and are in good condition. Bedroom has an on-suite bathroom in good condition. Upstairs Bedroom Two: (1) Female Child Sheets, desk, closet and drawers for child’s personal use available. Windows have screens and are in good condition. Bedroom has an on-suite bathroom in good condition. Downstairs Bedroom Three: (1) Trans-male child Sheets, desk, closet and drawers for child’s personal use available. Windows have screens and are in good condition. Bedroom has a hallway bathroom in good condition. Bed has no bedframe “We have the frame in the garage but she wants it that way and she wants to sleep in that closet space in the dark.” Downstairs Bedroom Four: (1) Female Child Sheets, desk, closet and drawers for child’s personal use available. Windows have screens and are in good condition. Bedroom shares a hallway bathroom with bedroom 3, and is in good condition. LPA Wilson and the licensee discussed the following: The rules and regulations for incident report writing to emphasize that Each incident has to be written on a separate incident report, and that a separate incident reports needs to be written for each client (that are not involved in the same incident). LPA Wilson provided a copy of the form (LIC624-LE) for incidents when contacting law enforcement. A Type B violation was issued this day. 80061 Reporting Requirements A copy of the appeal rights was left at the facility

deficiencies.description:
80061	Reporting Requirements
(a) Each licensee or applicant shall furnish to the licensing agency reports as required... within the agency's next working day... In addition, a written report containing the information specified in (2) below... within seven days...
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on LPA observations and interviews conducted the licensee did not ensure the facility prepares LIC624 seperately for each client and use a LIC624-LE form when law enforcement is called, which poses an immediate danger to the health safety and personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
Licensee will provide a plan to LPA by the due date to ensure reporting requirements are followed.
Licensee will ensure adults in the home are familiar with the regulation.

On October 20, 2021 at 2:02 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes began an inspection for a Small Family Home license. LPA met with applicant Tiffany Sarpy who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured inside and out with the applicant. Applicant is applying for a capacity of 2 ambulatory clients. Applicant prefers age 2-8 clients. The Small Family Home is a five bedroom and a three bathroom home. The home is set up as follows: Bedroom # 1 The room was furnished with two beds- It will sleep two kids. Bedroom #2 The room consist of a queen bed- Guest room- Vacant Bedroom #3 The room consist of al king bed and it sleeps Licensee and Spouse Bedroom #4 The room is turned into an office Bedroom #5 Is empty Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes was used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. There were plenty of toys for the children. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and are working properly. Telephone service and appliances were in working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medication will be locked in a cabinet by the office. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in a cabinet in the garage. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in the cabinet in the garage as well. First Aid kit was accessible and had all required items. There were no guns or weapons as stated by Mrs. Sarpy at this time. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be at 113 degrees. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. Continued on next page

Personal Rights, The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan and visitation policy were posted. The backyard was observed to be clean and free of hazards. There is no pool or other body of water. There was no deficiency observed during today’s visit. The home was in compliance with Title 22 Regulation. The applicant will be scheduled for a Component III prior to licensure. The request of License will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was discussed and provided to applicant this date

The hot water temperature in bathroom 1 was 116 degrees Fahrenheit, bathroom number 2 was 105.2 degrees Fahrenheit, and the master bathroom was 114.6 degrees Fahrenheit. On November 15, 2023 at 01:55 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes began day one of the annual inspection for Remarkable Care Small Family Home license. LPA met with Licensee Tiffany Sarpy who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the Licensee. There were two clients present at the time of inspection. The home is a one story building with four bedrooms and 3 bathrooms which are set up as follows: · Bedroom #1 (Master) has one bed sleeps the Licensee. · Bedroom #2 (Client’s) was vacant has two twin beds; it will sleep two client’s. · Bedroom #3 (Client’s) has two twin bed’s and sleeps two client’s. · Bedroom #4 (spare) was vacant has one queen bed; it is used as a guest room. · A great room/living room, kitchen, dining area, 3 bathrooms, laundry room, a two car garage, office, and the backyard. The Client’s bedroom was arranged so that no more than two clients will be in the room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate closet space for the client’s belongings. There was a smoke detector / Carbon Monoxide Detector in every bedroom. The smoke detectors / Carbon Monoxide Detectors were checked, and they were working properly. The home’s central air conditioning module was located in backyard. The home’s hot water heater is located in the garage. The appliances were in working order. The client’s files are locked in a cabinet by the office. There was adequate food storage space. There was a two day supply of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable foods. A trash can for storage of solid waste had a tight-fitting lid. The sharp knives are locked in the garage. The medications are located in a locked cabinet by the office.

The hot water in bathroom one (Master) measured to be 106.4 degrees Fahrenheit, in bathroom two 105.6 degrees Fahrenheit, and in bathroom three 106.7 degrees Fahrenheit. The First Aid kit was available and had all required supplies. There was one fire extinguisher present in the home it is located by the office. It was observed to be properly charged and inspected by the fire department. There is no firearm in the home as stated by the Licensee. There is no pool or other body of water present. The backyard where clients have access to play was fenced. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights was provided to Tiffany Sarpy.

On May 14th, 2025, at 10:15 AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Claudia Aguilera and MaryJane Perez arrived at Remarkable Care Small Family Home (SFH) to conduct and unannounced random annual inspection. The home is a single-story building with five bedrooms and three bathrooms. Currently, two ambulatory clients reside in the home. The home is licensed for a capacity of four ambulatory clients. LPAs toured the inside and outside of the home with licensee Tiffany Sarpy. Upon entry, LPAs observed a hallway that led to the kitchen, dining room, living room, laundry room, five bedrooms, three bathrooms, and two car garage. The kitchen was observed to be clean and organized. LPAs observed a minimum of seven-day non-perishable and a three-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. The living room was furnished with a large sectional couch, the dining room consisted of a large table with four chairs, a bench and three stools located in the bar area. The laundry room was inspected, and no chemicals were found. Bedroom #1 is a playroom that contained toys, small couch, play kitchenette, and a toy chest. Bedroom #2 consisted of two twin beds, dresser, and closet the room is currently vacant. Bedroom #3 was utilized for 16-year-old step-daughter the room consisted of a queen size bed, a closet, and dresser. Bedroom #4 consisted of a Cal King size bed and sleeps Licensee and Spouse. Bedroom #5 consisted of two twin beds and sleeps 5-year old and 6-year old male clients. All bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two clients share a room and one child per bed. No room was commonly used for other purposes other than a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawer and closet space for each child’s belongings. The three bathrooms were inspected and were fully functioning.

The medications were stored and locked in a container located in the hallway. The First Aid Kit was located in the laundry room accessible to clients and contained all required items. The garage was inspected and used for two cars, storage, locked sharps and chemicals, as well as an additional refrigerator was also maintained in the garage. The water temperature was tested and measured at 117.9 degrees F. All trash cans were observed to have tight fitting covers. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: visitation policy, emergency disaster plan, and current menu. The clients’ medication log records were kept updated with no discrepancy. The fire extinguisher was observed and operable. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and working properly. All hazardous items were made inaccessible to areas where clients have access. All windows and screens were in good repair. There were no guns or weapons in the home as stated by Licensee. A landline was accessible to clients for calls. There was a total of six cameras, two cameras were located in the common areas, one in the master bedroom, and three outdoor and met the Title 22 camera policy. Two clients were interviewed, however due to limited verbal skills they were unable to answer LPAs questions. Additionally, Licensee and spouse were interviewed, and no issues were found. The facility outside grounds were also inspected and observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. Clients’ files and staff files were reviewed. Based on today's inspection and observations, there are no deficiencies being cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report was provided to Licensee.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Galindo conducted a complaint inspection at Robert Morris Small Family Home and met with Chance Land. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation(s). During the investigation, LPA interviewed staff and reviewed records which revealed that staff is not trained to do restraints and facility reported the incident late. Confidential interviews confirm that staff restrained youth. After reviewing the staff’s file, LPA observed there is no training on file for restraints. As far as the incident itself is concerned, facility staff reported the incident to the Department on September 18, 2023 when the incident occurred on August 29, 2023. Based on the information obtained, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

deficiencies.description:
Personnel Requirements 80065(f). All personnel shall be given on-the-job training…, as appropriate to the job assigned and as evidenced by safe and effective job performance.

This requirement is not met as evidence by: Based on record review and interviews, licensee did not ensure staff are properly trained to handle situations where youth are physically distressed which poses an immediate health, safety or personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee stated a plan will be submitted by 12/19/2023.

deficiencies.description:
Reporting Requirements 80061(b) Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours.  In addition, a written report containing the information specified in (2) below shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event.
This requirement is not met as evidence by: Based on record review, licensee did not notify the Department of the incident within the next day that it occurred and did not submit a written report within 7 days as required which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee stated they will submit incident reports timely and will train staff on reporting requirements. Licensee stated training plan will be provided by 12/19/2023.

narrative: On March 25, 2024, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Briana Placencia and Miriam Flores conducted a Case Management inspection at Robert Morris Small Family Home and met with Chance Land. LPAs conducted a Case Management inspection due to the Department receiving a late Incident report, the Incident report was received on March 11, 2024, but the incident in question happened in January 2024. The Department determined this to be a risk to the health and safety of the children in care at this time, therefore the facility is being cited on the attached LIC809D. A copy of this report and Appeal Rights was provided to the facility.

deficiencies.description:
80061  Reporting Requirements 
(b)	Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours.  In addition, a written report containing the information specified in (2) below shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event.
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record reviews, the licensee failed to report and incident that occurred within the allotted time frames, which poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee states there will be a meeting with the management team to ensure that reporting deadlines are met. Licensee states they with submit the plan of correction to LPA Placencia by 3/26/2024. The meeting with be completed on or before April 8, 2024.

investigation_findings: 13On March 25, 2024, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Briana Placencia and Mariam Flores conducted a complaint inspection at Robert Morris Small Family Home and met with Chance Land. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During the investigation, LPA conducted interviews, a records review and reviewed supporting documents provided by the facility. Based on confidential interviews and other information obtained, the department has made the following determination. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to provide the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

deficiencies.description:
80072  Personal Rights 
(a)	Except for children’s residential facilities, each client shall have personal rights which include, but are not limited to, the following:
(3)	To be free from corporal or unusual punishment, infliction of pain, humiliation....

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews, the licensee yelled at minor in care, which poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care,
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee stated they will retrain the staff on personal rights, Licensee will submit the plan to LPA Placencia via email by 3/26/2024. Licensee will email LPA the completed training on or before April 8, 2024.
