narrative: On May 6, 2024 Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Briana Placencia and Angelica Borja conducted a facility visit at Robert Morris Small Family Home and met with Chance Land. LPAs conducted the visit due to an incident that occurred in the facility on 5/1/2024, involving S1 and C1 (see 811 for confidential names). A walk through of the facility was conducted and there was no noted deficiencies at this time.

On May 15, 2024 Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Reyna Martinez and Angelica Borja conducted a facility visit at Robert Morris Small Family Home and met with Sherrill Morris. The purpose of the meeting was to discuss an incident that occurred at the Small Family Home (SFH) that involved an arrest involving S1. Based on the information obtained involving an incident that occurred with S1 and C1, SFH is being issued a citation for California Code of Regulations 83072(d)(7) Personal Rights on the attached LIC809D page. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

deficiencies.description:
83072 Personal Rights (d)	The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights...(7) To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and corporal punishment. 

This requirement is not met as evidence by: Based on record review, S1 who is the Licensee conducted unreasonable physical constraint and left bruising on minor, C1, which poses an immediate health, safety or personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee has chosen to close the Small Family Home and surrender the license for the home. Licensee provided the license with Licensee's signatures on the back and provided to LPA.

narrative:
On July 28, 2021 at 10:42 AM Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Abdoulaye Traore and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shanae Pharaoh, arrived at the Small Family Home and met with licensee, Ms. Rochelle Sherman. The purpose of the visit was to conduct an annual required inspection of the Rochelle Sherman Small Family Home. The Licensee led a tour of the home.. The facility was toured inside and out. Currently there were no (0) foster children in placement. The licensee has four (04) adopted children (two of which are 18 or older). The home is set up as follows: · First floor: · Bedroom #1: Has two standard hospital beds w/rails - Has one direct exit (Sleeps AC1 and AC2) · Bedroom #2: Has two standard hospital beds/ w/rails - Has one direct exit w/ full bath attached. (Sleeps AC3 and AC4 · Bedroom #3: Has one standard hospital beds w/rails - Has one direct exit (Vacant) · · Second floor: · Bedroom #4: Master suite w/ full bath attached. (Sleeps Licensee/spouse) · Bedroom #5: Has Toddler bed & one queen bed (Vacant) · Bedroom #6: Has one full bed. Has one direct exit (Vacant) · Oxygen equipment is in use on the premises. No Smoking - Oxygen in Use" signs are posted in appropriate areas

Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The fireplace was properly screened. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medications were locked and stored in a supply closet. Cleansers/chemicals and were stored in a locked garage area. The first aid kit is located in the supply closet with medications on the first floor. There were no guns or weapons as stated by the licensee at this time. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be within regulatory requirements. Proper storage of all food was noted. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. The Emergency Disaster Plan with exit map, Title 22 Personal Rights, and visitation policies are posted at this time. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. A tour of the backyard was done and the licensee had a pool that was made inaccessible by a five foot mesh fence that had a self-latching gate that swings outward as required. There was also a jungle gym on the property for the children. The Licensee's CPR card /First Aid card expires 08/2021. The licensee currently retains no staff and no clients. There were no children or staff records to review. The following information was discussed with the licensee: - LIC 610 (Emergency Disaster Plan for Children’s Residential). The forms can be located online at. http://www.cdss.ca.gov/inforesources/Community-Care-Licensing: Forms Based on today's inspection, there are no deficiencies being cited at this time. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was given to Licensee. .

***Amended from 04/17/2023 to continue to the second page*** CPR card expires 05/026, and the First Aid card expires 05/2026. Administrative records Children and staff records are organized. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. A tour of the backyard was done, and the licensee has a pool that was made inaccessible by a five-foot mesh fence that had a self-latching gate that swings outward as required. There is a house under construction that will house the Licensee’s parents upon completion. Based on today's inspection, there are no deficiencies being cited at this time. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was given to Licensee.

On 6/6/2025, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Claudia Aguilera and Cynthia Ramos conducted a 2 year required inspection at Rochelle Sherman Small Family Home (SFH). The home is licensed to serve non- ambulatory clients, however currently no clients are placed in the home. The home was toured inside and out with Licensee, Rochelle Sherman. The home is two story residence with six bedrooms and five bathrooms and a media room. Upon entering LPAs observed a formal receiving area that included a small bar. Through the hallway, the kitchen was observed to be organized and clean, no sharp/knives were accessible to clients. A family room was observed with a couch, tv and decorative fireplace. The formal dining room was also observed to have a large dining room table that included six seating chairs. The laundry room was also observed and inspected, two fire extinguishers were located and operable. There are three bedrooms on the first level of the home and three bedrooms on the second level of the home. Currently, bedrooms on the first level (Bedroom #1, #2 and #3) are occupied by Licensee's adoptive children who ages 17, 24, 33. Bedrooms are arranged so no more than two clients share a room and no bedroom is used as a passageway. Currently, the home has two vacant spaces for two future clients. In addition, a locked room was observed and inspected which stores all medication for adoptive children living in the home. LPAs also inspected two first aid kits which contained all required supplies. Two full bathrooms were located in the first floor and one-half bathroom was located in the hallway of the first floor. On the second level of the home, the master suite (Bedroom #4) is occupied by the licensee and spouse, master suite also has a bathroom (Bathroom #4). On the other side of the second level, there is a small living room and an additional laundry room. LPAs observed 2 additional guest bedrooms (bedroom #5 and #6) and a media room. The upper level of the home is inaccessible to clients due to non-ambulatory status. The water temperature was tested and measured at 107.4 degrees F. LPAs observed a minimum of seven-day non-perishable and a three-day perishable supply of food.

All windows and screens were in good repair. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and operable. LPAs observed a firearm with trigger lock,in addition the firearm is kept in a firearm case, and the case is kept in Licensee's safe box located in master bedroom closet. Per, Licensee there is no ammunition in the home, The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: personal rights and visitation policy. The backyard was also inspected, and included a play set with swings and slides, there were no hazards or obstructions observed. The pool was observed and inspected to be inaccessible by a five foot mesh fence that had a self-latching gate that swings outward as required. In addition, a small home was located in the far left of the property that houses licensee’s father, mother and aunt. Per licensee, the property has it's own address. There are six outdoor cameras which meet the title 22 camera policy. Based on today's inspection and observations, there are no deficiencies being cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report was provided to Licensee.

On April 5, 2022, at 10:57AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Yuvi Diaz conducted an unannounced inspection to the above facility. LPA met with Myrna Carillo, Administrator who assisted with this inspection. LPA Diaz observed the facility to be clean, safe,sanitary, and in good repair both inside and outside. The facility is a single story home. The facility consisted of five bedrooms, two bathrooms, two living rooms, kitchen, dining room, laundry room, and garage. Three of the bedrooms had two twin beds, dresser, and closet. Fourth bedroom is used for facility staff to take breaks in and has a bed. Fifth bedroom is a master bedroom and office for administrator's use. All common areas where furnished and the furniture was in good repair. Upon arrival to the facility LPA noted that staff was preparing food for lunch. Lunch was spaghetti, with salad and turkey meat.Refrigerator and dry food storage was stocked. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children have access. The medications were locked and stored in a kitchen cabinet. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in laundry room. Sharp knives were made inaccessible and locked in a kitchen drawer. The smoke detectors located in the hallway and all the bedrooms and were in good working order. The carbon monoxide detector was located in the hallway near the bedrooms. LPA observed client files and staff files to be in a secure area and locked. First aid was located in the kitchen with all the required items. Fire extinguisher was serviced. LPA observed the facility license, emergency disaster plan, floor/exit plan, foster youth rights, developmental disabilities rights are posted. Lastly, LPA toured the backyard and noted no trip hazards. LPA reviewed five client files. Client files contained copies of personal rights, representative signatures, copies of IPP, IEP, medical history, and immunization forms. LPA reviewed three staff files, one administrator file, and one licensee file. All files contained updated CPR/First Aid, caregiver criminal clearance, health screening/tb form, and training's. Report continues on LIC 809-C

A review of Licensing Information System on April 4, 2022 indicates that all facility staff is associated to the facility and had DOJ, FBI, and child abuse index check clearances. LPA completed the following domains on the care tool: physical plant, operations, staffing records, and SHCN. LPA will need to compete the client file recods at a different time. There where no deficiencies noted at today's inspection. Exit interview was conducted with Mryna Carillo, Administrator and a copy of this report will be e-mailed to the Administrator.

On March 27, 2023, at 8:54AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shalisa Stiger and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez, conducted an unannounced inspection to the above facility. The Administrator was not available at this time, LPA Stiger called the Administrator and was informed they were at a doctor's appointment and will return around 11:00AM. LPA Stiger and LPM Rodriguez drove to a nearby Starbucks to wait for the Administrator's call. Administrator called LPA Stiger at 9:37AM to advise they were headed back to the home. LPA Stiger advised they will be back at the home at approximately 10:00AM. At 10:05AM, LPA Stiger met Administrator who assisted with this inspection. LPA Stiger observed the facility to be clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair both inside and outside. The facility is a single story home with solar panels. LPA Stiger observed a two (2) trash cans with lids on side of home and one (1) vehicle parked out front. The facility consisted of five bedrooms, two bathrooms, two living rooms, kitchen, dining room, laundry room, and garage. Bedroom 1- Master Bedroom consisted of queen bed, walk in bathroom with two sinks and shower. This bedroom is also used as an office for Administrators and files are located here. Lighting was in working order. Smoking detector in room, tested and in working condition. Thermostat set at 69 degrees. Bedroom 2-consists of two (2) clients: C1 and C2. There are two (2) twin beds, two (2) dressers and one (1) closet with clothes and blankets for extra bedding. Lighting was in good repair. Smoke detector in room, tested and in working condition. Bedroom was observed to be clean and in good repair. Bedroom 3- Consists of one (1) client C3 and (1) vacanct bed. There are two (2) twin beds, one (1) closet with clothes and blankets for bedding. Lighting was in good repair. Bedroom was observed to be clean and in good repair. Report continued on LIC809-C.

Bedroom 4- Consists of two (2) clients C4 and C5. Two (2) twin beds, two (2) dressers, one (1) closet with clothes, diapers and extra linen. Lighting was in good repair. Bedroom was observed to be clean and in good repair. Bedroom 5- Staff room consists of one (1) twin size bunk bed used for late shift staff and to take breaks. Room is inaccessible to clients. Lighting was in good repair. All common areas were furnished and the furniture was in good repair. The hallway bathroom for clients has a walk in shower, double sink, water temperature was at 110.6 F. Refrigerator and dry food storage was stocked for perishable for three (3) days and non-perishable food for seven (7) days. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children have access. The medications were locked and stored in a kitchen cabinet. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in laundry room. Sharp knives were made inaccessible and locked in a kitchen drawer. The smoke detectors located in the hallways and all the bedrooms were in good working order. The carbon monoxide detector was located in the hallway near the bedrooms were tested and in working order . The living room consisted of a sofa and two (2) chairs with a piano. The dining room consists of a table with five (5) chairs and tableware for clients. Non-perishable and staff foods are stored in the cabinets of the dining room. Family room consisted of one sofa and table with four (4) chairs. A fireplace sealed with a glass door and controls were locked. Lighting was in good repair. LPA observed client files and staff files to be in a secure area and locked. First aid was complete with all the required items and located in the kitchen area. Fire extinguisher was serviced. LPA Stiger observed the facility license, emergency disaster plan, floor/exit plan, foster youth rights, developmental disabilities rights are posted. Lastly, LPA toured the backyard and noted no trip hazards. LPA Stiger identified and completed all the domains of the CARE Tool during today's inspection. One citation was issued on the LIC809-D page. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was issued.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Misty Valencia arrived unannounced at the facility on this date and met with Myrna Carrillo, Administrator. The purpose of the visit was to complete an Annual Inspection using the CARE tool. The facility is licensed to care for five ambulatory for children ages 0-20 years old, but has an age exception. The facility has five staff. Staff and other adults residing/working in the home have complete Criminal Record Clearances on file. The facility has five of clients in placement, who are Alta Regional Center clients. LPA completed a Health and Safety Inspection of the facility. The facility is a home-like setting, with three client bedrooms, one staff bedroom and a Master bedroom for the administrators. There are one bathroom for clients, and one for staff. All toilets, showers, and sinks were functioning properly. The living area is spacious with a couch. The home was clean and organized. The room temperature was comfortable and no odor was detected. Smoke alarms were in working order, fire extinguishers were current, and a first aid kit was fully stocked. Disinfectants, knifes and medications are locked in a cabinet. LPA observed the kitchen to have at least 2 days of perishable food and 7 days of non-perishable food on hand, with additional food stored in the cabinet . Client’s bedrooms had clean bedding, along with a dresser and closet which provided ample storage space for personal belongings. There is no swimming pool or other body of water on the premises. There are no firearms or other weapons in the facility. continued on 809-C

LPA reviewed five client files. All clients had a current Individual Program Plan (IPP) on file created by the Regional Center. Clients were current on CHDP medical exams and dental exams. LPA reviewed five staff files. Staff files contained sufficient training hours and CPR and First Aid was current. LPA interviewed no clients due to them all being non-verbal. LPA interviewed two staff. Facility is issued a citation per Child's Records 83070(b)(11) (b) For each child in the home, the licensee shall maintain a separate, complete, and most up to date record or file that includes the following: (11) A copy of the current court order, or written authorization of the child's parent or guardian, for each psychotropic medication, as defined in Section 83001(p)(2) A signed copy of this LIC-809 (and LIC-809C, and LIC 809D, if applicable) report was provided to Myrna Carrillo, Administrator. . An exit interview was conducted. Appeal rights were provided (if applicable)

On October 10, 2024 at 2:09pm Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Tatyana Shulz and Orlando Areizaga made an unannounced visit to conduct a case management regarding the facilities Plan of Operation not being in compliance as previously approved. LPA met with Administrator, Myrna Carillo who assisted with the inspection. Based on interviews conducted with the licensee and observations of the Plan of Operation, it was confirmed that the facility was not operating in accordance with the Plan of Operation that the Department has approved. The Plan of Operation stated that the age range of clients accepted into the facility are 6-16 years of age. There are currently 4 clients in placement whose ages exceed the approved age range with no age exception requests for either client. The facility has since updated their license to reflect the new age range accepted, 6-17 years old and non-minor dependents. Also, the facility is currently in the process of transitioning into an Adult and Senior program. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator, Myrna Carillo and a copy of this report and the Appeal Rights were discussed and provided to the Administrator. This case management investigation is closed, and the facility has been cited for Plan of Operation 80022 (k) (See LIC 809D).

deficiencies.description:
80022 (k) Plan of Operation 
The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: There are currently 4 clients in placement whose ages exceed the approved age range with no age exception requests for either client, which poses a potential Health and Safety risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility has requested to change the age range of their license to reflect the age of clients currently residing at the facility. The facility is currently in the process of transitioning into an Adult and Senior program.

narrative: On October 10, 2024 at approximately 2:09pm Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Tatyana Shulz and Orlando Areizaga made an unannounced inspection to conduct a case management at the Small Family Home. LPAs were greeted by Myrna Carillo, Administrator who granted LPAs access. LPAs conducted a tour of the inside and outside of the facility where LPAs observed the following deficiency. · Cleaning products being left under the clients bathroom sink. LPA Shulz witnessed staff place the cleaning products in the locked laundry room cabinet. The facility has been cited under the California Code of Regulation on the LIC809-D page. Refer to 809-D for plan of corrections. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to Administrator, Myrna Carillo.

deficiencies.description:
80087(g) Building and Grounds
Disinfectants, cleaning solutions, poisons, firearms and other items that could pose a danger if readily available to clients shall be stored where inaccessible to clients.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observations conducted, the licensee did not ensure the safety of clients by allowing cleaning solutions to be in the clients bathroom which poses an immediate Health and Safety risk to participants.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator will remove the cleaning solutions from the clients bathroom and lock it in an inaccessible area.

narrative:
On March 11, 2021 at 10:05 AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA’s) Abdoulaye Traore and Kourtney Williams began a pre-licensing inspection for a Small Family Home license. LPAs met with applicant Ana Gallegos who led a tour of the home. The home was toured both inside and out with the applicant. The applicant is applying for a capacity of four ambulatory children. The home consists of: Downstairs: Bedroom #1, It was furnished with a full-size bed. It sleeps applicant’s 15-year-old son. There were also a family room, dining area, a common bathroom with a shower, a storage area and a kitchen Upstairs: Bedroom #2- Master bedroom. The room consists of a queen bed. It sleeps applicant/licensee and spouse. Bedroom #3- The room was furnished with one full bed size and twin-size bed- vacant. It will sleep two children. Bedroom #4- The room was furnished with one full bed size and twin-size bed- vacant. It will sleep two children. Bedroom#5- The room was furnished with one full bed size with a sliding twin-size bed. It sleeps applicant’s 9-year-old daughter and a 17-year-old daughter. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors were checked and were working properly. There were toys, books, puzzles, children’s table and chairs that were observed to be safe, clean, and age appropriate for the age group of children to be cared for.

Inside the facility the fireplace was properly screened. The home currently does not have a house telephone service, however, licensee stated that she utilizes a cell phone. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medications were locked in a top cabinet in the kitchen including one first aid kit. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored under the kitchen sink. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in the medication cabinet. There were no guns or weapons as stated by Applicant at this time. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 106 degrees. Proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. There was an additional First Aid kit located upstairs in a closet. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, visitation policy and Personal Rights were posted. The backyard was observed to be clean and free of hazards. There was no pool or other body of water. Based on this inspection, the home is appropriate for a capacity of 4 ambulatory clients, however, the applicant will be installing a telephone line and be available at all times. After the correction is completed, the applicant will notify LPA Traore. The applicant has been scheduled for a Component III on Monday March 15, 2021. The request of License will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval once the component orientation is completed and the correction has been made. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was discussed and provided to applicant this date

On September 14, 2023 at 02:18 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes began an annual inspection of Rose’s Small Family Home. LPA met with Licensee Ana Gallegos who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the Licensee. Currently there are two clients in the home. The home is a two story building with five bedrooms and three bathrooms which are set up as follows: · Bedroom # 1 is the Master sleeps the Licensee and has a master bathroom. · Bedroom # 2 (Clients) has one full bed and sleeps one client. · Bedroom # 3 (Clients) has one full bed and sleeps one client. · Bedroom # 4 (Clients) has a full bed and will sleep one client. · Bedroom # 5 (Clients) has one full bed and will sleep one client. · A great room/living room, sitting room, kitchen, dining area, three bathrooms, an attached one car garage, and the backyard. The Client’s bedrooms were arranged so that no more than one client will be in the room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate closet space for the client’s belongings. There was a smoke detector in every bedroom. The five smoke detectors were checked, and they were working properly. The Carbon Monoxide detector is located in the kitchen and was working properly. There is a dedicated phone line. The home’s central air conditioning module is located on the patio. The home’s hot water heater was located in the garage. The appliances were in working order.

There was adequate food storage space. There was a two day supply of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable foods. A trash can for storage of solid waste had a tight-fitting lid. The sharp knives are in a locked kitchen cabinet. The medications are located in a locked kitchen cabinet. The hot water in bathroom one (master) measured to be 126.9 degrees Fahrenheit, bathroom two 124.8 degrees Fahrenheit, and in bathroom 3 124.1 degrees Fahrenheit. The home’s First Aid kit was accessible and is located in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. Two fire extinguishers are present in the home one is located on the wall by the sliding glass door and the second is located on the wall upstairs by master bedroom. They were observed to be properly charged and inspected by the fire department. There is no firearm in the home as stated by the Licensee. There is no pool or other body of water. The backyard where clients will have access to play was fenced. There is one deficiency at this time The hot water I the home measured more than 120.0 degrees in every bathroom. The home will be cited for Health and Safety Code section 80088(e)(1) (1) Hot water temperature controls shall be maintained to automatically regulate temperature of hot water delivered to plumbing fixtures used by clients to attain a hot water temperature of not less than 105 degrees F (40.5 degrees C) and not more than 120 degrees F (48.8 degrees C). An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, LIC 809D and appeal rights was provided to Licensee Ana Gallegos.

On April 09, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rafael Enriquez met with applicant Rose Muiruri for a Component II. LPA went over revisions needed for the application prior to licensure. LPA gave a copy of the notification of incomplete application (LIC 184), Letter of Application Revisions, and additional correspondence to assist with the revisions needed to the application. Copy of this report was emailed to applicant and a signed copy will be placed in the facility file.

On June 19, 2024, at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rafael Enriquez began a pre-licensing inspection and component III for Rose Small Family Home for an initial license. LPA met with applicant Rose Muiruri who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. Currently there are no children placed in the home. The applicant was approved to serve two children ages 0 to 17. The home is a single-story building with four bedrooms and three bathrooms which is set up as follows: · Bedroom #1, it was furnished with a queen-sized bed. It sleeps the applicant. · Bedroom #2, it was furnished with two twin sized beds. It will sleep two foster children. It was vacant. · Bedroom #3, it was furnished with a queen-sized bed. It is a guest room. It was vacant. · Bedroom #4, the master bedroom is furnished with a king-sized bed, had a bathroom and two closets. It sleeps Applicant’s mother. · There was also a living room, kitchen with dining area, a storage room, two bathrooms, three car garage, backyard, and a laundry room. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings.

The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. Telephone service and appliances were in working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients/children will have access. Sharp knives and sharp objects were locked in a drawer in the kitchen. Cleansers/chemicals were inaccessible and stored in a locked box in the garage. There was adequate food storage space and a supply of three days of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable food. A proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. The water temperature was observed to be at 120.0 degrees. First Aid kit was accessible with all required items, and it was in the hallway cabinet counter. A Fire extinguisher was observed and properly charged. The fireplace was in the living room area, and it was properly screened. All the appropriate forms were posted in view of facility clients. As stated by applicant, there were no weapons/firearms and there were no pools or other bodies of water. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. The request for licensure will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to applicant Rose Muiruri.

LPA met with applicant Rose Muiruri who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the licensee. Currently there are no children placed in the home they had been recently removed from the home. The applicant was approved to serve two children ages 0 to 17. The home is a single-story building with four bedrooms and three bathrooms which is set up as follows: · Bedroom #1, it was furnished with a queen-sized bed. It sleeps the licensee. · Bedroom #2, it was furnished with two twin sized beds. It will sleep two foster children. It was vacant. · Bedroom #3, it was furnished with a queen-sized bed. It is a guest room. It was vacant. · Bedroom #4, the master bedroom is furnished with a king-sized bed, had a bathroom and two closets. It sleeps licensee’s mother. · There was also a living room, kitchen with dining area, a storage room, two bathrooms, three car garage, backyard, and a laundry room.

SFH is operating within capacity/limitation, it is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair, the outdoor area is free of safety hazards, no pool, or other bodies of water on premise. The SFH has adequate supply of perishable and nonperishable foods, chemicals are locked in the laundry room and garage, knives are locked in a kitchen cabinet. The water temperature was measures at 120.1 degrees. Medications are stored in a locked box in a kitchen cabinet, the disaster plan, personal rights, and other documentation are properly posted, smoke detectors are operable/tested. There are no firearms or dangerous weapons per licensee. First aid kit is maintained, and complete First Aid certifications are current. All adults subject to background checks are cleared. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to Licensee Rose Muiruri.

Another confidential interview stated that none of the staff have told C1 to hurt themselves but C1 has suicidal ideations and tries to hurt themselves and when that happens staff will call law enforcement. Another confidential interview stated staff was nice but maintain that staff would pull C1 by the legs and restrain C1 resulting in C1 being scared to return to the facility. narrative:
On the above date Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera met with licensee Mrs. Isigi, who granted access to the home. The purpose of this visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the small family home. The home was toured both inside and out with Mrs. Isigi. Presently there are three foster children in placement and all three were present during time of inspection (See LIC 811). The home is a two story with five bedrooms and three bathrooms. The home is set up as follows: Bedroom #1- downstairs- Master bedroom was furnished with two twin beds, one crib and a bathroom- Sleeps licensee and infant (C1). Bedroom #2- downstairs- The room consists of two separate twin beds- Sleeps one child (C2) Bedroom #3- downstairs- The room was furnished with two twin separate beds- Sleeps only bedridden child (C3) Bedroom #4- upstairs- The room consist of one queen bed- vacant Bedroom #5- upstairs –extra bedroom- no bed or furniture- vacant Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. Inside the facility there is an operable smoke detector located downstairs. There is also an operable carbon monoxide detected located downstairs and upstairs in the hallways and all five bedrooms. The fireplace is properly screened. The medications are locked and stored in a locked box inside a locked medicine cabinet.

Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in a locked cabinet inside the garage. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. The First Aid Kit is located in the kitchen and contains all required items. There are no guns or weapons as stated by Mrs. Isigi at this time. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 119. Proper storage of all food was noted. The Emergency Disaster Plan posted at this time. A copy of the license was readily available to LPA during time of inspection. The backyard where children will have access to play is completely fenced and free of hazards. The home has a pool that is appropriately fenced. The fence is a 5-foot tall wrought iron fence that completely surrounds the pool. The gate is self-latching and open outward with the latch located at least 54 inches from the ground. There are no windows that access the pool. Toys are safe, clean and age appropriate for the age group of children to be cared for both inside and outside the facility. The Licensee(s) meet the requirements for the 8 hours of annual foster care training. Licensee’s First Aid and CPR cards expire on July 03, 2022. A review of staff records on this date indicates that all adults residing in the home or providing care and supervision to children have received fingerprint and child abuse index check clearances. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was reviewed and given to Mrs. Isigi along with the LIC 811.

Based on confidential interviews, the Department determined there was not sufficient information to determine that FM’s behavior poses a risk to FC1 in care. Although the allegation may have happened or may be valid, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the allegation. The Department’s finding was that this allegation is unsubstantiated. A copy of this report and confidential name list LIC 811 was given to licensee

On December 21, 2023, at 10:15 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie began a facility inspection for a Small Family Home capacity increase. LPA met with applicant Roselyn Isigi who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. The applicant was applying for a capacity increase of 6 non-ambulatory developmentally disabled clients. The home was a two story home and was set up as follow: Downstairs: Bedroom #1- Master bedroom was furnished with two twin beds. The bedroom was vacant. Bedroom #2 - The room consisted of two twin hospital beds. It sleeps one client. Bedroom #3 - The room was furnished with two twin hospital beds - Sleeps one client. There were also an office, a visitor lounge, a family room, a living room, two dining areas, a pantry, a kitchen and two bathrooms. Upstairs: Bedroom #4 - The room consist of one queen bed- Sleeps the licensee. Bedroom #5 - The room was furnished with no bed or furniture - vacant.

Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes was used as a bedroom, and no bedroom served as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and were working properly. There was one family room, a playing/therapy area and one living room next to the front entrance which was also designated to visitation. There was an approved fire door installed between the living area and the clients’ rooms. There was also another approved fire door at the master bedroom. Fire extinguisher was located by the living room. Inside the facility the fireplace was properly screened. Telephone service and appliances were in a working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medication will be locked in the kitchen cabinet. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the garage by the laundry area. The master bedroom door will always be locked when there were children present. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in a locked kitchen cabinet. There were no guns or weapons as stated by licensee at this time. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 112 degrees. Proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. The backyard was observed to be clean and free of hazards. Toys and sports equipment were observed at this time for the age group of children to be cared for. Emergency Disaster Plan with exit map, visitation plan and Facility Sketch and Personal Rights were posted. The backyard was fenced with a wrought iron self-closing fence surrounding the pool. The access gate swings away from the body of water. The height of the wrought iron fence is 60", spacing horizontal bars is 5.8" apart, and it was 2" from the ground on hard surface. Based on this inspection, the home is appropriate for a capacity increase of six non-ambulatory clients. The home was following tittle 22 Regulations. The request for capacity increase to six non-ambulatory clients will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was discussed and provided this date to Roselyn Isigi.

Regarding the allegation that licensee did not pick up sick foster child from school in a timely manner, it was specifically alleged that licensee did not pick up FC1 from school when FC1 was sick. During investigation, confidential interview stated that L1 attempted to get to school to pick up FC1 but had taken L1’s van to the shop because it needed vehicle repairs. It was added that L1 attempted to rent a vehicle that would accommodate FC1’s wheelchair. Additional confidential interviews corroborated that L1 was trying to pick up FC1 from school, but the van was in the shop causing an unintentional delay in getting FC1 home from school. The school was able to work with L1 by providing school bus transportation. In regard to the allegation that licensee did not seek medical attention for foster child in a timely manner. It was specifically alleged that L1 did not take FC1 to doctor in a timely manner. Confidential interview stated that after L1 received their car back from the vehicle repair shop, FC1 was taken to urgent care the same day. Additional confidential interviews corroborated that L1 took FC1 to the emergency room on the same day. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that licensee did not pick up sick FC1 from school in a timely manner and licensee did not seek medical attention for FC1 in a timely manner may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violations. Therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report along with the appeal right were reviewed and provided to facility representative.

Regarding the allegation that licensee does not meet a minor's dietary needs, it was specifically alleged that licensee does not provide appropriate snacks for FC1. During investigation, confidential interview stated that L1 checked with a website for appropriate foods for FC1’s dietary needs. Additional confidential interviews stated that FC1 was given different foods that FC2 and FC3 due to their dietary needs. LPA was not able to interview FC1 because FC1 refused to be interviewed. LPA was unable to gather additional information. In regard to the allegation that licensee mishandles a minor's medications, it was specifically alleged that FC1 stated they ran out of medicine at home and the licensee had not refilled FC1’s prescription. Confidential interviews stated that FC1 had arrived at the home with enough medicine for a while but would use it more often because FC1 would have unhealthy foods at school that would affect FC1. It was added that licensee worked with FC1’s doctor to get more medicine. Additional confidential interviews stated that they didn’t know if FC1 ran out of medicine. LPA was not able to interview FC1 because FC1 refused to be interviewed. LPA was unable to gather additional information. Furthermore, the allegation that licensee does not communicate effectively, it was specified alleged that the licensee does not respond to the phone calls from the school. Confidential interviews stated that L1 tries having good communication with the school but that some of the staff give L1 a hard time. It was added that L1 does call the school back when she misses a call. An additional confidential interview corroborated that some of the school staff give L1 a hard time. LPA was not able to interview FC1 because FC1 refused to be interviewed. LPA was unable to gather additional information. Finally, the allegation that licensee has not completed required documents for a minor, it was specifically alleged that licensee has not signed important paperwork regarding a safety plan for FC1. Confidential interviews stated that L1 had filled out all paperwork at the parent center in Corona. Other information obtained stated that the allegation is true. LPA received inconsistent information regarding the allegation.

Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that licensee does not meet FC1’s dietary needs, licensee mishandles FC1’s medications, licensee does not communicate effectively, and licensee has not completed required documents for FC1 may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violations. Therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report along with the appeal right were reviewed and provided to facility representative.

narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Juliet Robles conducted a virtual Component II session with Roselyn Small Family Home on January 23, 2025 at 3:00 PM via Microsoft Teams. LPA met with the applicant, Roselyn Isigi. The purpose of the meeting was to review and discuss the program statement and application. LPA introduced herself and started the meeting with asking licensee what is her reason for relocating. On January 28, 2025 at approximately 1:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Juliet Robles conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection at the above address. The licensee is relocating her Small Family Home Program from Norco to Bakersfield. Upon arrival, LPA met with Roselyn Isigi, the owner/administrator. Together they toured the external and internal areas of the home. The following was observed at the time of inspection: Physical Plant This facility is a one-story house located in a quiet residential community. The facility consists of five (5) bedrooms, three (3) bathrooms, kitchen, dining area, living room, family room, laundry room and backyard with a pool and basketball hoop. Overall, the facility is clean, sanitary and in excellent condition. Passageways are free from obstruction. Knives and sharps, disinfectants and cleaning solutions will be kept locked and secured in the kitchen. Per administrator there are no firearms on the premises. The facility has a centralized heat and air-conditioning unit. Temperatures throughout the home during the inspection were comfortable. Carbon monoxide and smoke alarms were tested and observed to be operational. The home has one fire extinguisher. The pool has a fence that is at least 5 feet high and has a self-latching device. A fire inspection was conducted by the Kern County Fire Department on 01/23/25 and a fire clearance was granted for three ambulatory clients, 2 non-ambulatory and 1 bedridden client. Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment, and Supplies Bedroom #1 a client with a wheelchair will have one twin bed and a dresser that will be used, Bedroom #2, will have 2 twin beds and 2 dressers, Bedroom #4 will have 1 or 2 twin beds and dresser, & Bedroom#5 will have 1 or 2 twin bed/s with dresser. There are two bathrooms that can be utilized by the clients. The owner/administrator will occupy bedroom # 3 and has its own bathroom.

Heath Related Services and Record Keeping Medications, the first aid kit will be centrally stored and locked in a cabinet by the kitchen. The kit contains all required supplies. The client and staff files will be stored in a locked file cabinet in the administrators’ bedroom. LPA also conducted Component III - Category Specific Orientation with the applicant. The following items were discussed and provided to the applicant: -Title 22 regulations on Small Family Homes - Continuing Requirements (General Licensing Requirements) - Buildings and Grounds requirements - Personnel Records (forms) - Client Records (forms) -Reporting Requirements - Other administrative forms LPA guided applicant to go to this website for additional information regarding the inspection and its CARE Tools and methods, please visit the CARE Tools web page or the Inspection Process Project web page.(www.cdss.ca.gov) On today’s visit, the administrator submitted the following: LIC 200, 308, 402, 215, 420, 500 and a copy of her driver’s license. The revisions for the Program Statement were explained to administrator/owner and will be submitted on/or before February 07, 2025. LPA advised licensee that all documents submitted, and revisions of PS will also be reviewed by LPM Yeung. No deficiencies were observed on this date. An exit interview was conducted a signed copy of this report was provided to the applicant.

On April 11, 2025 at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Juliet Robles conducted an unannounced inspection at the Small Family Home facility and met with the licensee, Roselyn Isigi. The purpose of the inspection was about post licensing. Currently the facility has two (2) children in care. At 9:05 AM, LPA and licensee toured the internal and external areas of the home. The following was observed at the time of inspection: This facility is a one-story house located in a quiet residential community. The facility consists of five (5) bedrooms, three (3) bathrooms, kitchen, family room, dining area, laundry room and backyard with pool and basketball hoop. Overall, the facility is clean, sanitary and in excellent condition. Passageways are free from obstruction. Knives and sharps, disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept locked and secured in the kitchen. Per licensee, there are no firearms/ammunition on the premises. The facility has a centralized heat and air-conditioning unit. Temperatures throughout the home during the inspection were comfortable. Carbon monoxide and smoke alarms were tested and observed to be operational. The home has one fire extinguisher. The pool has a fence that is at least 5 feet high and has a self-latching device. Medications, the first aid kit is centrally stored in a cabinet by the hallway. The first aid kit contains all required supplies. The home has toilets, wash basins, and one shower/bath for clients' use. The water temperature was tested at 105 degrees which is within regulatory guidelines. Licensee got a phone call emergency from the school to pick up one client not feeling well. This inspection will be continued on another day to complete. On today’s visit LPA reminded licensee about the current LIC 503, and TB testing and any new hires will go through fingerprints and documents. LPA provided licensee PIN 24-09-CRP for the Video Cameras in Children’s Residential Congregate Care Facilities. LPA reminded the licensee to submit the PS addendum by May 13, 2025. There are no deficiencies found at this time. An exit interview was conducted and LPA provided a copy of the following reports: LIC 809, LIC 811 to Ms. Roselyn Isigi, Administrator/Licensee.

On August 19, 2025, at 9:50 AM, an unannounced Case Management inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Juliet Robles to discuss timely submission of incident reports to the Department. LPA Robles met with the Licensee, Roselyn Isigi. On July 07, 2025, LPA Robles received an email report from the Small Family Home (SFH) Administrator about an incident with regards to client’s runaway that resulted in an accident (See Reference LIC 811, Confidential Name List dated 08/19/25). The date of the incident was July 4, 2025, the Department was notified late of the incident. On July 17, 2025, LPA Robles contacted SFH Administrator to discuss completing a process on Guardian and the program statement addendum for video camera usage. LPA Robles emailed and left voice mail messages to the administrator but no response. Per administrator, she is out of the country at that moment and will be back at the end of July. LPA had asked the administrator if she had submitted an incident report about her being away from the SFH facility. Per administrator, she stated she did but did not forward any email to LPA. Based on the above information, a technical advisory (TA) was issued to the SFH facility. Exit Interview was conducted and the following reports: LIC 809, LIC 9102, LIC 811 were provided and discussed with the administrator, Roselyn Isigi.

On June 11, 2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez arrived at Rosemary Cole Small Family Home for a pre-licensing inspection for an initial license. LPA met with applicant Rosemary Cole who led a tour of the entire home inside and out. Currently there are no children placed in the home. The applicant is applying to serve a capacity of six ambulatory children ages 0 to 17 years old. The home is a one- story building with four bedrooms and three bathrooms. The entry way of the home had a facility sketch posted and a visitation log available. The hallway leading to the garage had fire extinguisher #1, a laundry room that was accessible to clients but had a locked cabinet storing laundry detergents and cleaning supplies. Bathroom #1 was fully functioning with a locked cabinet under the sink storing cleaning supplies/extra hygiene products. The water temperature was measuring 118 degrees Fahrenheit. Bedroom #1 was fully furnished with two size beds, dressers, lamps and closet space and will be utilized for two clients and was currently vacant. Bathroom #2 was fully functioning and had dual sinks and extra hygiene products stored in cabinets.There was Bedroom #2 that was fully furnished with two twin size beds, dresser/ closet space, lamps and toys that will be utilized for two clients and was also currently vacant. There was a hallway closet that stored extra towels, blankets, linens, and mattress protectors for clients use. Bedroom #3 will also be utilized for two clients and is fully furnished with two twin size beds, dresser/closet space, and lamps. The bedroom was currently vacant. There was a formal dining area with adequate seating arrangement, a living room with couches/ television, an office with all required postings such as personal rights, emergency disaster plan, visitation policy, menu, and house rules. The office also stored a first aid kit with all required elements and fire extinguisher #2. The

kitchen was clean and sanitary with a locked cabinet for storing client and personnel files, medication, and cash resources. The refrigerator and pantry were fully stocked with three days of perishable and seven days of non- perishable foods. The knives/ sharp objects were locked in a drawer and cleaning supplies were locked under the sink. There was a dining table and counter space with adequate seating. Bedroom #4 was the master bedroom and had bathroom #3 for applicant and will be locked at all times. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room that is commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and are working properly. There was a land- line telephone service, appliances were in working order, and all trash cans had tight fitting lids. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. As stated by applicant, there were no weapons/firearms and there were no pools or other bodies of water. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. There are no corrections needed at this time. Based on this inspection, the home is appropriate for a capacity of six ambulatory clients. The request for licensure will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. Component III orientation was also completed this day of June 11, 2025. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to applicant Rosemary Cole.

The applicant is applying to serve six ambulatory children ages 6 to 17 years old. The home is a two story building with seven bedrooms and four bathrooms. The downstairs consisted of an entry way with all required postings such as emergency disaster plan, facility sketch, personal rights, and visitation policy. Fire extinguisher #1 was operable and also located in the entry way. Bedroom #1 was also downstairs fully furnished with a full size bed, dresser/ closet space, TV, light fixture and a desk that will be utilized for one client -currently vacant. The kitchen was clean and sanitary with a locked cabinet storing knives/sharp objects, a locked sink cabinet storing cleaning supplies, another locked cabinet for storing household tools such as a hammer and screwdrivers, and another locked cabinet for storing clients files, personnel records, medication, and a lock box for cash resources. The first aid kit was also in a kitchen cabinet with all required elements. The refrigerator and pantry were fully stocked with perishable and non-perishable foods. There was a dining table with adequate seating arrangements, a living room with couches, TV, and games/video games. Bedroom #2 will also be utilized for one client and was fully furnished with a full size bed, dresser/closet space, a TV, a desk, and a light fixture- currently vacant. Bathroom #1 was fully functioning with a shower/bathtub and water temperature measuring 114.6 degrees Fahrenheit. There was a storage closet storing household items such as a broom and ladder. The upstairs consisted of bedroom #3 that will be utilized for one client and was fully furnished with a full size bed, closet/dresser space, a desk, and bathroom #2 that was fully functioning. The laundry room was accessible to clients and had detergents and laundry supplies locked away. Fire extinguisher #2 was located

in the upstairs hallway leading to the bedrooms and was operable. Bedroom #4 will be utilized for one client and was fully furnished with a full size bed, closet/dresser space, a TV, a desk and a light fixture - currently vacant. Bedroom #5 will be utilized for one client and was fully furnished with a full size bed, closet/dresser space, a TV, a desk and a light fixture- currently vacant. Bedroom #6 will also be utilized for one client and was fully furnished with a full size bed, dresser/closet space, a TV, and a light fixture- currently vacant. Bathroom #3 was fully functioning with dual sinks and a shower/bathtub. In the hallway there was a linen closet storing extra blankets, sheets, and towels. Bedroom #7 was the master bedroom for applicant with a king size bed, bathroom #4, and a walk in closet that will be locked at all times. The backyard was fully fenced, had a gate with a slide latch, and was free of hazards. There was no pool or other bodies of water at this time. The garage stored a parked vehicle and multiple bicycles. As stated by applicant there were no firearms in the home. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than one child share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawers and closets for children’s belongings and all required bedding. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. Appliances were in working order. All trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients/children will have access. Based on this inspection, there are no corrections needed at this time therefore, the home is appropriate for a capacity of six ambulatory clients. The request for licensure will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. Component III orientation was also completed this day of August 4th, 2025. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to applicant Christopher Daily.

facility_name: RUTH AND JACOB SMALL FAMILY HOME
narrative:
On March 12th, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez arrived at Ruth and Jacob Small Family Home (SFH) to conduct pre-licensing inspection for an initial license. LPA met with applicants Ruth and Jacob who led a tour of the entire home. The applicants are applying for a capacity of 4 children, 3 ambulatory and 1 non-ambulatory, ages 0-17 years old . The home is a two-story building with six bedrooms and 3 bathrooms. The downstairs consisted of living room #1 that had couches, a piano, and a dining table that had adequate seating. Bedroom #1 was downstairs and had two full size beds with closet and dresser space that would be utilized for two foster children and was currently vacant. There was bathroom #1 that was fully functioning with a walk in shower with water temperature reaching 107.6 degrees F. There was bedroom #2 that was a non- ambulatory room with two exit ways. One door was leading to the outside with a ramp and the other door was leading to the indoor entry way. There was a hallway with a fire extinguisher and all required postings such as visitation policy, emergency disaster plan, and personal rights. There was another hallway that stored client/ staff files in two separated locked boxes inside a locked cabinet, there was another locked cabinet that stored a locked box for client medication, a locked box for client cash resources and a first aid kit with all required elements. There was living room #2 that had couches, TV, a fireplace that was properly screened, and board games/ game consoles. The kitchen had a refrigerator and pantry with plenty of perishable and non-perishable foods. A proper storage of all food was discussed. The knives and sharp objects were locked in a cabinet. The kitchen sink had dish cleaning items locked and stored under it. The laundry room was also located downstairs and was accessible to clients with a locked cabinet storing laundry detergents and cleaning supplies. The garage stored extra household items, a refrigerator, and deep freezer with extra foods. The applicants were advised to supervise foster children when in the garage. The upstairs consisted of a study area with a desk and computers. There was bedroom #3 that was for

applicants biological son and one foster child. There was two full size beds with proper bedding and storage space for 1 foster child and applicants biological son. There was bedroom #4 that had two full size beds for 1 foster child and applicants biological daughter. There was adequate closet/ drawer space as well as lighting. Applicants understand that foster children are to share a room with those in the same age range as well as same sex. Bathroom #2 was located upstairs and had two fully functioning sinks, a toilet, and shower/tub. There was one locked cabinet storing bathroom cleaning supplies and another cabinet storing extra hair products. Bedroom #5 had a full size bed and was occupied by applicants eldest biological son. The hallway stored extra blankets, linen, and towels. There was bedroom #6 that was a master bedroom for applicants that had bathroom #3 with locked cabinets storing medication and cleaning supplies. The backyard was free of hazards and had two exit gates on both side yards. There was also a storage shed storing sharp gardening tools. There was no pool or other body of water at this time. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawers and closets for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. Appliances were in working order. All trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. LPA observed there to be no land line service. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients/children will have access. There are no firearms in the home as stated by applicants. Based on this inspection of the home, the facility will need the following corrections: - Obtain a telephone for land line service After corrections are completed, the applicant will notify LPA so that we can move forward with licensure. Component III orientation was also completed this day of March 12, 2025. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to applicants Ruth and Jacob Munzaa.

facility_name: SAFE AND SOUND SMALL FAMILY HOME
narrative: On December 4, 2023, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging that the Licensee did not prevent inappropriate interactions between client and another child in the home. During the investigation there was no corroborating evidence to support the allegation. Although it was reported to CCL that there was an incident in the home of inappropriate touching in care involving C1 and a child in the home. The Investigator received inconsistent statements that supported a violation of lack of supervision resulting in the sexually inappropriate interaction between C1 and a child in the home. Confidential interviews denied observing inappropriate sexual behaviors between C1 and a child in the home. Other confidential interviews stated that the sexual interaction occurred without the knowledge of the Licensee and when the information was revealed the Licensee requested the removal of C1. There were no other known witnesses to the allegation. C1 could not be reached for comment regarding the allegation. Based on confidential interviews, and record review the allegation that Licensee did not prevent inappropriate interactions between client and another child in the home, may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights was provided to Licensee, Destiny Phillip.
investigation_findings: 13On March 21, 2024, at 9:11 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Cynthia Urena met Safe and Sound Small Family Home (SFH) Licensee, Destiny Phillip to deliver the investigative finding for the above stated allegation. On December 13, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Urena initiated the investigation at the SFH and collected pertinent documents from SFH and client’s files. LPA conducted an inspection of the SFH with the Licensee and there were no deficiencies observed. LPA advised the Licensee that Investigator Sonia Sandoval with the Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) Investigations Branch (IB) would be leading the investigation. Investigator Sandoval conducted interviews with the Licensee, three county staff members, two of three clients (C2, C3) a client involved C1 could not be reached after multiple attempts made by the investigator for an interview. It was reported that C1 is currently on a runaway status and no additional information regarding the allegation was obtained. (**Continued on LIC 9099 C**)

narrative:

Bedroom # 1 is downstairs and furnished with two twin beds Bedroom # 2 is upstairs and furnished with one full bed and sleep’s licensee’s daughter. Bedroom # 3 is upstairs and furnished with bunk beds bottom bed is full top is twin and sleep’s licensee’s son. Bedroom # 4 is upstairs furnished with a king bed and a crib and sleeps licensee and will sleep one infant. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients are in a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. The bathroom was clean and in good repair. Hot water in bathroom number one measured to be 119.6 and bathroom number two 119.4. Bathroom number three is the master bathroom and the clients will not have access to it. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The medications will be stored and locked in a locked box above the refrigerator. Cleaners/chemicals are locked and stored in locked cabinet under the sink. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked box in the garage. The First Aid Kit is located in the medication lock box and contained all required supplies. The facility's smoke detectors in each bedroom were checked and were operable. The carbon monoxide and the smoke detectors are the same. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by applicant Destiny Phillip. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, and Visitation policies.

The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. There is no pool or other body of water present. There was no deficiency observed during today’s visit. The home was in compliance with Title 22 Regulation. The applicant will be scheduled for a Component III prior to licensure. The request of License will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was discussed and provided to applicant Destiny Phillip this date.

On February 22, 2024 at 1:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmetha White conducted a Component II, Face-to-Face meeting with Safe Family Homes Small Family Home Licensee, Kristiana Johnson. The purpose of the meeting was to discuss the pending Small Family Home application and Program Statement review. The following concerns were discussed: Program Statement: • Treatment • Education • Transportation • Discipline · Emergency Intervention Plan · AWOL/Run Away Plan · Telephone Policy · Mail • Recreation • Protection • Religious Services Report continued on LIC809 C

• Personal Hygiene Items • Personal Allowance/Paid Jobs • Medical/Dental • Record and Reporting FOLLOW – UP: A Pre-Licensing Inspection will be conducted on 3/19/2024 at 10:00 AM. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to the Licensee.

On March 19, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White arrived at Safe Family Home Small Family Home for the purpose of conducting a Pre-Licensing Inspection. LPA met with Applicant, Kristiana Johnson who granted access to the home and together a tour of the interior and exterior home was conducted. Currently living in the home is the Applicant and the applicant’s minor biological child. The home is set up as follows: This is a two-story 5 bedroom, 3 ½ bathroom, home located in a residential area. The home consists of a living room, dining room, kitchen, loft, office, laundry room, a backyard, and an attached garage. Living room: is equipped with mounted TV, a sectional sofa, two (2) chairs, a coffee table, and a small cabinet. The living room also has sliding glass patio doors leading to the backyard. Dining room: is equipped with marble table with five (5) chairs and a bench. Kitchen: is equipped with a refrigerator/freezer, a five (5) burner gas stove (all burners were operational at the time of the inspection), double oven, microwave, and a dishwasher. Sharp knives are kept locked in the applicant’s bedroom and made inaccessible to clients when in care. LPA observed a covered trash can, a pantry, plenty of cabinet space, ample plates, cups, and eating utensils. LPA observed ample perishable food items in the refrigerator and the pantry is fully stocked with non-perishable food items. The applicant will ensure that three (3) nutritious meals and snacks will be provided to the clients. Loft/entertainment area: is located on the second floor and contains 3 TV’s, a sofa, desk, chair, computer, and a PlayStation. Office: is located on the first floor and contains a desk, chairs, sofa, computer, printer, and a locked file cabinet. The cabinet will be used to store client files. Laundry room: is located on the second floor of the home between bedroom #1 and bedroom #2. The room has a washer, dryer, built-in cabinets and drawers, and contains washing supplies. The room is kept secure with a combination lock and remains locked at all times. Report continued on LIC 809C. (Page 1 of 3)

Backyard: contains a built-in BBQ grill, a fenced and gated fire pit and in-ground pool. The pool fence meets regulations, and the pool gate has self-closing latch to ensure the body of water is inaccessible to clients when in care. The pool pump/filtering system is located on the side of the home. When pool is in use by clients, applicants will ensure that individual supervising clients in the pool area are Water Safety trained. Attached garage: used for the home’s vehicle. The garage also contains an extra refrigerator, table and chairs. LPA also observed the garage to be used storage. Bedroom #1: is located on the second floor and will be used as a client’s room. The room has two (2) twin beds, two (2) dressers with five (5) drawers each, a TV, a closet, working light, and windows. The room also has an attached bathroom that contains a shower/tub, toilet, and sink. Bedroom #2: is located on the second floor and will be used as a client’s room. The room has two (2) twin beds, two (2) dressers with four (4) drawers each, a TV, a closet, a desk and chair, working light, and windows. The room also has an attached jack and jill bathroom that contains a shower/tub, toilet, and sink. Bedroom #3: is located on the second floor and will be used as a client’s room. The room has two (2) twin beds, two (2) dressers with four (4) drawers each, a TV, a closet, working light, and windows. The room also has an attached jack and jill bathroom that contains a shower/tub, toilet, and sink. Bedroom #4: is located on the second floor and it is occupied by the applicant. This room has a combination lock and it is equipped a king size bed, dresser, working light, and windows. The room also has an attached bathroom that contains two (2) sinks, a tub and separate shower, and a walk-in closet. Bedroom #5: is located on the first floor and it is occupied by the applicant’s minor biological child. The room has a queen size bed, a sofa, a dresser, TV, working light, and windows. (3.5) Bathrooms: one bathroom is located in bedroom #1, the second bathroom is located along the hallway between bedroom #2 and bedroom #3, one bathroom is located in bedroom #4, and the ½ bathroom is located on the first floor to the right of the entrance. The ½ bathroom contains a sink and toilet. LPA found all bathrooms to be clean and in working order. The hot water was tested and found to be with 105-120 (F). Report continued on LIC 809C. (Page 2 of 3)

Vehicle: The applicant will use a 2018 Tesla Model X to transport clients in care. The vehicle is in good condition with current registration through 01/07/2025 and insurance with USAA current through 09/01/2024. The home’s temperature is maintained by central air/heating. LPA observed one (1) fully charged fire extinguisher. Extra linens are stored in the laundry room. The smoke alarm and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. First Aid kit was found to be be complete. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept in the laundry room. The home has a working telephone readily accessible to children in care. Medications will be kept locked in file cabinet located in the office. Medications requiring refrigeration will be kept in a locked box stored in the garage refrigerator. LPA observed the home to be clean, safe, and sanitary. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps and open porches are unobstructed. The front and backyard were clean and free of debris. LPA reminded Licensee to ensure the following when children are in placement: Children are accorded personal rights and the corresponding form is in their file. Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Applicant acknowledges abuse reporting requirements. Applicant will ensure grievance process, Disaster Plan, Discipline policies and procedures will be posted in dining room area. During the inspection, LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. Per a check in Guardian conducted on 03/19/2024, the applicant’s Criminal Record Clearance states "in process". LPA informed applicant that a Component 3 meeting will be held once applicant obtains eligible clearance. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report left with the applicant.
