On April 22, 2024, at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White conducted a Component III office meeting at the El Segundo Children’s Residential Regional Office for Safe Family Home (SFH). Attending Component III was Kristiana Johnson: The purpose of this meeting was to discuss the forms that are required to be maintained, available, and posted at the facility for inspections per Title 22 Division 6 Chapter 1 (General Regulations) and Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 4 (Small Family Homes). LPA went over the following: Child's Records: General regulation section code 80070 & Small Family Home regulation 83070 Personnel records: General regulation section code 80066 Reporting Requirements: General regulation section code 80061 & Small Family Home regulation 83061 Intake: General regulation section code 80068 & Small Family Home regulation 83068.1 Compatibility: *Useful documentation Small Family Home regulation 83068.2* Supervision: General regulation section code 80078 & Small Family Home regulation 83078 Removal/Discharge Complaint Procedures Food: General regulation section code 80076 & Small Family Home regulation 83070 Hygiene (toiletry) Prudent Parenting: Small Family Home regulation 83067 Pending final approval of LPA C. White will submit the application for licensure. A Copy of this report was provided to the applicant.

On September 17, 2024, at 09:45am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kim Dear, made an announced visit to the Safe Family Homes located at 25251 Golden Maple Drive, Santa Clarita, CA 91387, for the purpose of conducting a post licensing visit. Registered person and House Manager, Kyle Flourney allowed LPA access into the property and tour of the home. All clients were away from the property at time of visit. There are currently 3 of 6 children in placement. Interior: The property is two stories consisting of (5) five bedrooms. (1) One bedroom is available on the lower level next to kitchen area. A full-sized kitchen consists of a double door refrigerator, microwave oven, double oven, dish washer and additional top ranged stove. Food storage is abundant in full panty, canned goods in cabinets and perishable foods in refrigerator and double, draw freezer. Water was tested to be 103 degrees. Office space is also on the lower level to the east of the kitchen. Office is equipped with large desk, chair, computer and a large window. Office is used for participants intake. Upstairs locates the master bedroom, king sized bed, dresser drawer, night stands a closet and a television. Full Laundry room was equipped with washer and dryer. All (3) three bedrooms contain a closet within swing doors, a single twin sized bed, television, lamp, and dresser. The first bedroom has an adjourning full restroom: Restroom contains a cabinet, sink toilet bathtub and shower space. The second and third bedrooms share an adjourning full restroom: cabinet, sink toilet bathtub and shower space. See 809-C

Exterior: Large outdoor lawned area surrounds a fended in pool. A table, seating (6) six is placed on the concrete portion of the yard. An additional patio area is also available shaded under a large umbrella. Additional outdoor furniture for seating also was observed. At conclusion of safety inspection, the facility is able to continue to be licensed to provide transitional housing placement services to minor dependents; up to (06) six participants, ages 3-17 years of age. At the inspection's conclusion, it was determined that all practices and procedures maintain compliance. An exit review was conducted with the House Manager and a copy of the inspection was provided. No deficiencies were identified at this time.

Information obtained from confidential interviews and review facility file history revealed a lack of evidence to support alleged sexual abuse. Based on confidential interviews with one Youth, assigned Social Worker, and Facility Administrator, the investigation was not promoted due to consistent statements from parties revealing denial of said sexual abuse. The investigation uncovered no information to support the allegation that Resource Parent is sexually exploiting Y1, thus the investigation assignment is not promoted. Therefore, the allegation is determined unsubstantiated. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. There are no deficiencies cited per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, at this time. A copy of this report is provided to Administrator via email.
investigation_findings: 13On 6/25/2025 at 3:15 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Regina Martin arrived at SAFE FAMILY HOMES and met with Administrator to deliver investigation findings concerning the above-mentioned allegation. On 4/14/2025, Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD), received a complaint alleging that Resource Parent is sexually exploiting Youth (Y1) as the youth reportedly engages in Commercial Sexual Exploitation of Children (CSEC) activities. It was further reported that the licensee is aware of youth’s activities, and that the youth gives the licensee a portion of the money that the youth makes when the youth is being solicited for sex. The allegation was referred to CCLD Investigations Branch, Investigator Douglas Real for assignment. (Continue on page LIC9099-C)

narrative:
On 7/10/25, at 9:05 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nestor Gomez arrived at the above facility, for the purpose of conducting an Annual Required Inspection. LPA Gomez met with Facility Manager (FM), Kyle Flournoy, who granted access to the facility. The current census is 4. This facility is licensed to provide care and supervision for six (6) children ages 3-17 years old, ambulatory only. There is a swimming pool on the premises. During the time of inspection, LPA Nestor conducted an inspection of the following areas: Living Room: equipped with a large couch, coffee table, mounted television, and 3 chairs. Kitchen: equipped with a double door refrigerator, microwave, oven, dishwasher and top range stove. The pantry and refrigerator contained ample food for children in care that included both perishable and non-perishable foods. All appliances are in working order. The trash can in the kitchen was equipped with a lid. Bedroom #1: located upstairs. This master bedroom is currently occupied by Caregiver Kristiana Johnson. The bedroom is equipped with a king-sized bed, dresser drawer, nightstands, a closet and a television Continue on 812-C(Page 1)

Bedroom #2: located upstairs. This bedroom is currently occupied by C2. The bedroom is equipped with a closet, single twin sized bed, television, lamp, and dresser. Bathroom #1 is adjourned to Bedroom #3. It is equipped with cabinet, sink, toilet, and bathtub/shower. Bedroom #3: located upstairs. This bedroom is currently occupied by C3. The bedroom is equipped with a closet, single twin sized bed, television, lamp, and dresser. Bedroom #4: located upstairs. This bedroom is currently occupied by C4. The bedroom is equipped with a closet, single twin sized bed, television, lamp, and dresser. Bathroom #2: This full restroom is adjourned to Bedroom #2 and Bedroom #3. This bathroom is equipped with a cabinet, sink, toilet and bathtub/shower. Bedroom #5: located downstairs. This bedroom is currently occupied by C1. The bedroom is equipped with a closet, single twin sized bed, television, lamp, and dresser. Bedroom #6: located downstairs. Equipped with large desk, chair, full-sized bed, television and a computer. This space is used for staff. FM stated that the space is only used by staff to relax. Loft: equipped with a table, couch, television, computer, and desk. FM stated that the space is used for client intakes, but clients do not use the space. Laundry Room: equipped with a washer and dryer that are in working order. Bathroom: There are a total of 4 bathrooms in the facility. 3 upstairs and 1 downstairs. Backyard: space is equipped with a pool (enclosed by a gated fence), grill/countertop space, and a faux grassed area. Continue on 812-C (Page 2)

Additional Observations: The water temperature at the kitchen sink was tested and measured at 115 degrees Fahrenheit which meets licensing regulations. The cleaning supplies are stored in a locked closet cabinet in the master bedroom. Sharps are stored in a locked closet cabinet in the master bedroom. There are one (1) fire extinguishers located downstairs by the back sliding door. LPA observed the carbon monoxide/smoke detectors to be in working order when tested by the licensee. LPA observed the personal rights posted in the living room. There are a total of 3 cameras located on the outside of the facility. One camera is located in the backyard, one camera is located in the front yard by the garage and a ring doorbell camera. Vehicles: LPA Nestor inspected one (1) facility vehicles in total. 2024 Kia K5 (grey) with current registration that expires in 10/08/2025. Insured by Garrison Prop and Cas Ins Co that expires on 9/1/2025. The vehicle is in good condition with no issues. Staff Interview: LPA Nestor conducted two (2) staff interview with S1 and S2. Client Interview: LPA Nestor conducted two (2) client interviews with C2 and C4. LPA Nestor will return to complete the inspection. There were 4 deficiencies observed or cited at this time. See 809-D. A copy of this report was reviewed and provided to caregiver Kristiana Johnson. End of Inspection (Page 3)
On May 2, 2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes met with Applicant Loreal Mitchell via Microsoft Teams for a Component II interview. A signed copy will be placed in Applicants file.

On May 26, 2023, at 11:08 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes and LPA Jason Dalton began a pre-licensing inspection for Safe Keeping Small Family Home license. LPA met with applicant Loreal Mitchell who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. Currently there is no client in the home. The applicant is applying to serve 3 clients ages 0 to 17. The home is a two story building with three bedrooms and three bathrooms which are set up as follows: · Bedroom #1 (Master) has one bed sleeps the applicant and has a master bathroom · Bedroom #2 (Daughters/client) has one twin bed; it will sleep one client and the daughter. · Bedroom #3 (Client’s) was vacant has a two tier twin bunk bed, it will sleep two client’s. · A great room/living room, kitchen, dining area, three bathrooms, an office, a laundry room, an attached two car garage, and the backyard. The Client’s bedroom was arranged so that no more than two clients will be in the room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate closet space for the client’s belongings. There was a smoke detector in every bedroom. The six smoke detectors were checked, and they were working properly. The Carbon Monoxide detector was located in the kitchen and was working properly. There was a dedicated phone line. The home’s central air conditioning module was located on the back porch. The home’s hot water heater was located inside the garage. The appliances were in working order. The client’s files will be locked in a file cabinet by the front door. There was adequate food storage space. There was a two day supply of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable foods. Continued on next page

A proper storage of all food was discussed. A trash can for storage of solid waste had a tight fitting lid. The sharp knives are in a locked container in the pantry. The medications are located in a locked file cabinet by the front door. Bathroom one is located downstairs, and the hot water measured to be 108.3 degrees Fahrenheit. Bathroom two was located upstairs and the hot water measured to be 107 degrees Fahrenheit. The clients will not have access to the master bathroom as the only door to it is through the locked master bedroom. The home’s First Aid kit was accessible and was located in the pantry. Two fire extinguishers were present in the home one was located in the pantry and one is located upstairs. They were observed to be properly charged and inspected by the fire department. There is no firearm in the home as stated by the applicant. There is no pool or other body of water. The backyard where clients will have access to play was fenced. The following items need to be corrected · Place a bed in daughter/clients room The request for a license will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to Loreal Mitchell.

On November 07, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karen Beal conducted an application review. The revisions that are needed for your application was provided. The documents can be mailed to my attention at the office or brought into the office. Please do not forget the remaining documents must be submitted within 30 days. Thank you.

On November 14, 2024, at 12:37 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karen Beal began a pre-licensing inspection and component III for Second Chances Small Family Home for an initial license. LPA met with applicant Martha Nunez who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. The applicant is currently a resource family home with Knotts Foster Agency(FFA). Currently there is one child in the home that was placed by the FFA. The applicant wishes to be licensed for 3 children ages 0 to 17. The home is a single-story building with three bedrooms and 2 bathrooms with a Casitas which is set up as follows: · Bedroom #1 Has two twin beds, it is currently vacant. · Bedroom #2 Has a full size bed and sleeps the resource child. Bedroom #3 Master bedroom. Its sleeps the applicant and spouse Casitas- has a queen bed and it sleep applicant's son A formal living room, formal dining room, living room, kitchen with dining area, two bathrooms, three car garage, backyard with pool, and a laundry room. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly.A cell phone will be available for client use in place of a landline and appliances were in working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients/children will have access. Continued to LIC 809-C

Continued from LIC 809 Sharp knives and sharp objects were locked in a cabinet in the kitchen. Cleansers/chemicals were inaccessible and stored in laundry room which has a lock on the door. There was adequate food storage space and a supply of three days of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable food. A proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. The water temperature was observed to be at 112.6 degrees. First Aid kit was accessible with all required items, and it was in the hallway closet. A Fire extinguisher was observed and properly charged. The electric fireplace was in the living room area, it stays cool to touch. All the appropriate forms were posted in view of facility clients. As stated by applicant, there is weapons/firearms in the Casitas The weapon is stored in a safe and the ammo is stored in the closet in a lock box. There is a gated pool and a spa. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. The request for licensure will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. Applicant was advised to contact the department within 30 days of their first placement. LPA conducted Component III training. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to applicant Martha Nunez

An unannounced Annual/Required inspection was conducted by the Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Ignacia Villapudua-Soto on 11/04/2020 at 1:15 PM. LPA Villapudua-Soto met with Licensee, Roberta Tauro on today's date. On today's date there were five clients present and three staff and administrator/Licensee. The following conditions were observed: The home is clean, safe and sanitary throughout. The home has five bedrooms and two bathroom. The kitchen has adequate food, fruit, snacks and supplies. The backyard is clean and has adequate space for clients to play and take space. Cleaning supplies and hazardous materials are locked in the laundry room and inaccessible to clients. The water temperature is controlled and the hot water heater that is programmable and is set to 120 degrees. The home has smoke detectors and carbon monoxide. There is the necessary fire extinguishers (2) and first aid kits. The Facility Van was inspected and is in good repair. All bedrooms of the home are equipped with adequate linens, drawers for each client, television, desk, toys and clothing for clients. The client's have their own private space where they can take space to do their own actives and be creative. All required Licensing forms are posted and were observed during inspection. LPA observed three staff that are supervising the five clients at all times. There is a vegetable garden outside along with fruit trees where the Licensee frequently acquires vegetables for the clients. LPA observed a sufficient amount of perishable and non-perishable foods in the kitchen. The food menu is posted on the refrigerator along with personal rights. The home as games, and movies for the clients. LPA began the process of reviewing client files, but was not able to complete the process. LPA will return at another date to continue the Annual/Random inspection. Exit interview was conducted.

On 11/09/2021, starting at 10:40 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ignacia Villapudua-Soto continued the Required Annual/Random Inspection of this Small Family Home. LPA met with Licensee Roberto Tauro who assisted with the inspection. During LPA inspection there was three staff, three clients and Licensees present. This facility client's medications are locked and kept out of reach of clients. The medications are locked in a cabinet and the Medication Administration Record binder. Home has adequate personal hygiene supplies and clean linens. Personal rights, monthly menu plan and disaster plans are posted in the front room. Staff files and client files are locked in the office. Children's cash resources were located in client files Client records reviewed: medical authorizations, personal rights forms, medical history and immunization records located in files Staff files reviewed: contained fingerprint clearances, Continuing Education unit records, and training tracking forms in files. Throughout the facility grounds, there are areas where clients are able to participate in recreational activities LPA also interviewed two staff, LPA attempted to interview the three clients that were present, however, all clients were non-verbal and LPA was not able to communicate with the clients. On the previous inspection, LPA requested for Licensee to replace Bedroom 1 twin bed mattress, on today's inspection, LPA observed that the mattress was purchased and replaced. No deficiencies were noted in client files or staff files. The facility is in compliance with Title 22. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was left at the facility with Licensee, Roberta Tauro.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ignacia Villapudua-Soto arrived at the above facility to conduct a case management visit on 02/03/22 at 4:05 PM. LPA met with Administrator, Roberta Tauro and Direct Staff, Rozette Tauro and discussed the case management. During a file review and investigation of an incident. LPA requested a copy of the incident report. The Administrator stated that she did not report the incident to Community Care Licensing. Administrator stated she did call the CSW and informed her of the incident via telephone. LPA explained Title 22 regulation that she must call send or call in a 24 hour incident to Community Care licensing and then follow up with a seven day incident report. The facility is being cited for violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Section 80061(b) Reporting Requirements: Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours. In addition, a written report containing the information specified in (2) below shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report, along with appeal rights, was given to the facility.

deficiencies.title: Reporting Requirements
deficiencies.description: Upon occurrence of any events specified, report to be made to licensing next working day. A written report submitted to the licensing agency within 7 days following the occurrence.

narrative:
On August 31, 2022 at 10:30 AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Stephannie Verna and Cecilia Warren arrived at the above facility and conducted an unannounced required annual facility inspection. LPA met with, Roberta Tauro, Facility Licensee and announced the reason for the inspection. Facility Licensee, and Ruzette Tauro, facility staff assisted with the inspection. LPAs and the Licensee conducted a joint inspection of the interior and exterior areas of the facility’s physical plant. The small family home is licensed for a capacity of six ambulatory clients. The census is four. There were four staff, and three clients in the home during the inspection. The home is a one story home. The home consists of three double occupancy bedrooms, one client bathroom, and one staff/licensee bedroom and bathroom. There was no garage. The home had a backyard with no swimming pool or pond. The home had a kitchen, dining room, staff office, laundry area and living room. The facility license was posted in a prominent place, on the wall in the entry hallway. The home had an Emergency Disaster plan, and Facility Sketch, Client Personal Rights and Client Menu, Client Daily Schedule, and a calendar of activities posted on the walls within the dining area and kitchen area. The menu was a monthly menu, but contained no dates. The register of clients was present, but did not include the client's physician, ambulatory status, or restricted health condition information. The licensee will complete the LIC 9020 and include the missing information. The disaster and mass casualty plan was missing elements: The facility has an emergency disaster plan, but it is in need of updates and inclusions to include: full contingency plans for actions pertaining to disasters, including staff and client duties (for each shift), evacuation procedures, additional relocation sites/contact, means of exiting during a disaster, contact protocols during evacuation/relocation, and other details specific to the facilities emergency disaster and mass casualty plan. The entryway contained PPE supplies, and a check-in area, and a hall closet with coats and shoes. continued on 809-c

The living room contained three couches, and an ottoman, a coffee table, along with a piano, a television and chest of drawer. The kitchen contained a working landline phone. The home had a fireplace that was covered and not in use. LPA observed that the dining area was off of the kitchen and the table was set up for placement of five and contained five chairs. The dining area contained a counter area with multiple drawers and cabinets which contained storage supplies, including games and activities. It was observed that the drawers in the home (kitchen and dining room) were not secured and would fall if and once open halfway to completely. It was observed that there were missing tracks to the drawer hardware. LPA observed that the kitchen area was located off the dining and living room area of the facility and that the kitchen area had an electric stove, oven, toaster, dishwasher, microwave and refrigerator/freezer. The kitchen cabinets and drawers contained ample dishes, utensils, and cooking supplies, such as pots and pans. The sharps and cleaning chemicals were in locked cabinets. The pantry was located off of the dining area, in the hallway and near the laundry area, with no lock on the door. LPA observed no expired food in the home, and there was ample storage of fresh and frozen foods located in the refrigerator, freezer, and pantry to supply meals and snacks to the clients in care. Supplies of staple nonperishable foods for a minimum of one week and fresh perishable foods for a minimum of two days. Fresh fruits were observed on the kitchen counter. The bathrooms had a working toilet, shower/tub, and sink faucet. It was observed that the bathtub tub had cracks, one in the bottom and one in the side wall, also the bathroom floor was observed to have dark mildew or build up of dirt in the grout behind the toilet and beside the tub. The water temperature was measured to be at 106.3 degrees Fahrenheit. The bathrooms contained soap and paper towels for hand washing. Hygiene supplies were observed in the hallway closets for clients use. The hallway closet outside of the bathroom contained extra towels and wash cloths, and bedding. Trash cans with lids were observed in the bathrooms and kitchen. LPA observed a working Carbon Monoxide detector in the dining room and working smoke alarms in each bedroom, the entry area, staff office, and hallway. continued on 809-c

LPA observed that there was a fire extinguisher in the kitchen and laundry room. The fire extinguishers were charged and last inspected in May 2022. The fire clearance inspection was conducted in February 2022 and a copy was provided to LPA. LPA observed that the medications and first aid kit were stored in a locked hallway closet and kitchen cabinet. The front and back yards were free of clutter; and the passageways and egress were unobstructed. However, there was an area of potential hazard that was observed in the outdoor deck and patio space. It was observed that the patio railing was not secured entirely to the porch, and when utilized it wobbled, causing a safety hazard, and should be secured to the patio. Additionally, It was observed that the concrete patio that the outdoor play structure was on was lifted from the ground, causing the concrete to lift and create a gap between the patio pathway and the concrete area and tripping hazard. The backyard contained garden beds, a seating area with tables and multiple chairs, and shades to shade from the sun. There was a swing for client use, and the structure was bolted to the ground. There were no locks on the side yard fence, and the side yard contains trash cans, a bicycle, a locked storage shed, and storage area. There was a locked storage shed in the backyard which contained extra furniture, and storage items, and holiday decor. A table and chairs was also observed. The laundry room contained a washer and dryer, and locked cabinets which contained tools and chemicals, including paints. aware. LPA observed that the bedrooms had bed(s) and bedding including mattress cover, fitted sheet, top sheet and blanket, and pillows, dressers with drawers for personal items, and ample closet space filled with clothing, extra bedding and personal hygiene items. The windows opened and locked, to allow window and emergency exit access in the case of an emergency. The screens and window blinds were in good repair. It was observed that the drawers in the home (kitchen and dining room) were not secured and would fall if and once open halfway to completely. It was observed that there were missing tracks to the drawer hardware; the bathroom floor was observed to have dark mildew or build up of dirt in the grout behind the toilet and beside the tub. LPAs obtained copies of the following documents: LIC 400, LIC 402, LIC 500, Surety Bond, Emergency Disaster Plan, Facility Sketch, Certificate of Liability Insurance, Fictitious Business Name Statement Document, Fire Inspection and Test Form dated 02/08/2022, Fire Alarm/Clearance Certificate dated 03/13/2018, Licensee Fees Receipt. These documents will be filed at the CCL CRP Regional Office. continued on 809-c

The facility was clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair, with the exception of being deficient related to the following, where: Technical Violations (TV) were issued, related to: California Code of Regulations, Title 22, division 6, chapter 1, section 80088(e)(3) All toilets, handwashing and bathing facilities shall be maintained in safe and sanitary operating condition. Additional equipment, aids, and/or conveniences shall be provided in facilities accommodating physically handicapped clients who need such items. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, division 6, chapter 4, section 83087.2(a) The licensee shall provide outdoor activity space which is free from hazards to life and health. and Technical Advisories (TA) were issued, related to: California Code of Regulations, Title 22, division 6, chapter 1, section 80076(a)(5) Menus ... shall be dated and kept on file for at least 30 days; California Code of Regulations, Title 22, division 6, chapter 1, section 80075(g)(1)(A) ...The supplies shall include at least the following: ... A current edition of a first aid manual approved by the American Red Cross, the American Medical Association or a state or federal health agency; California Code of Regulations, Title 22, division 6, chapter 1, section 80071(a)(1) The licensee shall maintain in the facility a register of all clients... and must contain current information on the following:...; and California Code of Regulations, Title 22, division 6, chapter 1, section 80023(a) Each licensee shall have and maintain on file a current, written disaster and mass casualty plan of action. See TVs and TAs for more information. The facility is being cited for violations of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, division 6, chapter 1, section 80087(c) All outdoor and indoor passageways... open porches and other areas of potential hazard shall be kept free of obstruction; and California Code of Regulations, Title 22, division 6, chapter 1, section 80087(a) See 809-D for POC information. LPAs completed the review of the Operations and Physical Plant inspection, and will complete a client and staff file review, medication review and client and staff interviews on another date or dates. An exit interview was conducted with Roberta Tauro, Facility Administrator/Licensee and a copy of this report and appeal rights was provided to Roberta Tauro, Facility Licensee/Administrator.

On August 24, 2023 at 10:30 AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Stephannie Verna and Donna Edwards arrived at the above facility and conducted an unannounced required annual facility inspection. LPA met with, Roberta Tauro, Facility Licensee and announced the reason for the inspection. Facility Licensee, and Ruzette Tauro, facility staff assisted with the inspection. LPAs and the Licensee conducted a joint inspection of the interior and exterior areas of the facility’s physical plant. The small family home is licensed for a capacity of six ambulatory clients. The census is four. There were four staff, and two clients in the home during the inspection period. The home is a one story home. The home consists of three double occupancy bedrooms, one client bathroom, and one staff/licensee bedroom and bathroom. There was no garage. The home had a backyard with no swimming pool or pond. The home had a kitchen, dining room, staff office, laundry area and living room. The facility license was posted in a prominent place, on the wall in the entry hallway. The home had an Emergency Disaster plan, and Facility Sketch, Client Personal Rights, Client Menu, Client Daily Schedule, and a calendar of activities posted on the walls within the dining area and kitchen area. The entryway contained a table and a check-in area. The living room contained three couches, and an ottoman, a coffee table, along with a television and chest of drawer. The kitchen contained a working landline phone. The home had a fireplace that was covered and not in use. LPA observed that the dining area was off of the kitchen and the table was set up for placement of six and contained six chairs. The dining area contained a counter area with multiple drawers and cabinets which contained storage supplies, including games and activities. LPA observed that the kitchen area was located off the dining and living room area of the facility and that the kitchen area had an electric stove, oven, toaster, dishwasher, microwave and refrigerator/freezer. The kitchen cabinets and drawers contained ample dishes, utensils, and cooking supplies, such as pots and pans. The sharps and cleaning chemicals were in locked cabinets. The pantry was located off of the dining area, in the hallway and near the laundry area, with no lock on the door. continued on 809-c

LPA observed there was ample storage of fresh and frozen foods located in the refrigerator, freezer, and pantry to supply meals and snacks to the clients in care. Supplies of staple nonperishable foods for a minimum of one week and fresh perishable foods for a minimum of two days. Fresh fruits were observed on the kitchen counters. The bathrooms had a working toilet, shower/tub, and sink faucet. It was observed that the bathtub tub had a temporary repair to it due to it having cracks. The licensee informed LPA that they have obtained a quote and will have a new tub installed on September 5, 2023. The licensee provided documentation related to the quote, and repairs scheduled to be made. The water temperature was measured to be at 105.8 degrees Fahrenheit. The bathrooms contained soap and paper towels for hand washing. Hygiene supplies were observed in the hallway closets for clients use. The hallway closet outside of the bathroom contained extra towels and wash cloths, and bedding. Trash cans with lids were observed in the bathrooms and kitchen. LPA observed a working Carbon Monoxide detector in the dining room and working smoke alarms in each bedroom, the entry area, staff office, and hallway. They were tested and in working condition. LPA observed that there was a fire extinguisher in the kitchen and laundry room. The fire extinguishers were charged and last inspected in May 2023. The fire clearance certificate was provided, and is current and valid. LPA observed that the medications and first aid kit were stored in a locked hallway closet and kitchen cabinet. The front and back yards were free of clutter; and the passageways and egress were unobstructed. However, there was an area of potential hazard that was observed in the outdoor deck and patio space. The facility has made repairs to the patio, installing concrete, ensuring the ground is not uneven for clients in care, however it was observed that during the inspection of the outdoor space there were two areas of the patio deck had stairs which were not attached, unsecure, and unsteady when stepped on and in need of repair. continued on 809-c

LPA observed that the bedrooms had bed(s) and bedding including mattress cover, fitted sheet, top sheet and blanket, and pillows, dressers with drawers for personal items, and ample closet space filled with clothing, extra bedding and personal hygiene items. The windows opened and locked, to allow window and emergency exit access in the case of an emergency. The screens and window blinds were in good repair. During the review of facility documents, it was observed that the disaster and mass casualty plan was updated last after August 2022 and provided to LPAs for inspection. The facility has an emergency disaster plan, but it needs to be combined to include all aspects, including contingency plans for action during fires, floods, and earthquakes and other emergency disasters. This information was present at the facility, but separate from the facility’s written disaster and mass casualty plan. Additionally, It was observed that the LIC610C and the written disaster and mass casualty plan was missing some required information: names, addresses of emergency agencies listed, including the name of an ambulance service used. The licensee inquired about a Technical Support Program referral to assist the facility in ensuring their plan meets regulations. LPA will submit a referral to TSP for the facility. During the review of four personnel files, it was observed that documentation and/or training certificates regarding completed training was not present and/or filed related to annual training received on care and supervision. Review of the licensee file revealed that training related to prudent parenting standard, reproductive health, contraceptives, and duties and responsibilities of the licensee to ensure children can obtain services and information, was observed not to be completed and/or documented and filed in the licensee file. LPA conducted one staff interview and one client interview. LPAs obtained copies of the following documents: LIC 400, LIC 402, LIC 500, Surety Bond, Emergency Disaster Plan, Facility Sketch, Fire Alarm/Clearance Certificate dated 03/13/2021. These documents will be filed at the CCL CRP Regional Office. continued on 809-c

The facility was clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair, with the exception of being deficient related to the following, where: Three Technical Advisories (TA) and Two Technical Violations (TV) were issues, related to: CCR Title 22 Regulations, section 83187(g), 83064(j), 80075(h)(2), 80065(f)(3), and 83064(i). The facility was not issued citations during today’s inspection. LPAs completed the review of the Operations, Physical Plant, and Staffing domains of the inspection, and will complete the client file review on another date. An exit interview was conducted with Roberta Tauro, Facility Administrator/Licensee and a copy of this report was provided to Roberta Tauro, Facility Licensee/Administrator.

On July 16, 2024 at 10:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kayla Green arrived at the above facility and conducted an unannounced required annual facility inspection. LPA met with, Roberta Tauro, Facility Licensee and announced the reason for the inspection. Facility Licensee assisted with the inspection. LPA and the Licensee conducted a inspection of the interior and exterior areas of the facility’s physical plant. The small family home is licensed for a capacity of six ambulatory clients. The census is four. There were four staff, and four clients in the home during the inspection period. The home is a one story home. The home consists of three double occupancy bedrooms, one client bathroom, and one staff/licensee bedroom and bathroom. There was no garage. The home had a backyard with no swimming pool or pond. The home had a kitchen, dining room, staff office, laundry area and living room. The facility license was posted in a prominent place, on the wall in the entry hallway. The home had an Emergency Disaster plan, and Facility Sketch, Client Personal Rights, Client Menu, Client Daily Schedule, and a calendar of activities posted on the walls within the dining area and kitchen area. The entryway contained a table and a check-in area. The living room contained three couches, and an ottoman, a coffee table, along with a television and chest of drawer. The kitchen contained a working landline phone. The home had a fireplace that was covered and not in use. LPA observed that the dining area was off of the kitchen and the table was set up for placement of six and contained six chairs. The dining area contained a counter area with multiple drawers and cabinets which contained storage supplies, including games and activities. LPA observed that the kitchen area was located off the dining and living room area of the facility and that the kitchen area had an electric stove, oven, toaster, dishwasher, microwave and refrigerator/freezer. The kitchen cabinets and drawers contained ample dishes, utensils, and cooking supplies, such as pots and pans. The sharps and cleaning chemicals were in locked cabinets. The pantry was located off of the dining area, in the hallway and near the laundry area, with no lock on the door. Cont 809C

LPA observed there was ample storage of fresh and frozen foods located in the refrigerator, freezer, and pantry to supply meals and snacks to the clients in care. Supplies of staple nonperishable foods for a minimum of one week and fresh perishable foods for a minimum of two days. Fresh fruits were observed on the kitchen counters and on the dining table. The bathrooms had a working toilet, shower/tub, and sink faucet. The water temperature was measured to be at 107.1 degrees Fahrenheit. The bathrooms contained soap and paper towels for hand washing. Hygiene supplies were observed in the hallway closets for clients use. The hallway closet outside of the bathroom contained extra towels and wash cloths, and bedding. Trash cans with lids were observed in the bathrooms and kitchen. LPA observed a working Carbon Monoxide detector in the dining room and working smoke alarms in each bedroom, the entry area, staff office, and hallway. They were tested and in working condition. LPA observed that there was a fire extinguisher in the kitchen and laundry room. The fire extinguishers were charged and last inspected in May 2024. LPA observed that the medications and first aid kit were stored in a locked hallway closet and kitchen cabinet. The front and back yards were free of clutter; and the passageways were unobstructed. continued on 809-c

LPA observed that the bedrooms had bed(s) and bedding including mattress cover, fitted sheet, top sheet and blanket, and pillows, dressers with drawers for personal items, and ample closet space filled with clothing, extra bedding and personal hygiene items. The windows opened and locked, to allow window and emergency exit access in the case of an emergency. The screens and window blinds were in good repair. The facility was clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. The facility was not issued citations during today’s inspection. LPA completed the review of the Operations, Physical Plant, and Staffing and client domains of the inspection. An exit interview was conducted with Roberta Tauro, Facility Administrator/Licensee and a copy of this report was provided to Roberta Tauro, Facility Licensee/Administrator.

On July 21, 2025 at 3:00PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adaleyci Caballero completed a pre-licensing inspection of Serenity Haven Small Family Home (SFH). LPA met with Applicant Carol Noyes-Mora who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. There are no clients in placement. The two-story building with five bedrooms and three full bathrooms which are set up as follows: Bedroom #1- It consisted of one single bed. The bed had linen, comforters, and pillows. It will sleep one client. Bedroom #2- It consisted of one queen bed. The bed had linen, comforters, and pillows. It will sleep applicant. Bedroom #3- It consisted of one queen bed. The beds had linen, comforters, and pillows. It will sleep applicant's bio adult son. Bedroom #4- It consisted of two single beds. The beds had linen, comforters, and pillows. It will sleep two clients. Bedroom #5- It consisted of two single beds. The beds had linen, comforters, and pillows. It will sleep two clients. A living room, family room, office, kitchen, dining area, laundry room, loft, two car garage, and a backyard, The garage will be utilized for storage.

The clients' bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two clients will be in a room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate closet space for the clients' belongings. There was a smoke detector in every bedroom. The eleven smoke detectors were checked and working properly. The Carbon Monoxide detectors were combined with the smoke alarms. The home’s central air conditioning module was in the backyard. The water heater is located in the garage. The appliances were in working order. Medications and sharps will be locked in a secure box inside the pantry. Client and staff files will be locked inside a filing cabinet in the office. The home had a trash can for storage of solid waste with a tight fitting lid. Emergency Disaster Plan (LIC 610), Personal Rights, Grievance procedures, Facility Sketch, House Rules, and Visitation Policies were posted in the entrance. There were two fire extinguishers present in the home located in the downstairs closet and the upstairs linen closet. They were observed to be properly charged and inspected by the fire department. The First Aid Kit was located in the kitchen accessible to clients in care. There are no firearms in the home. There is no pool or any body of water in the home. There are no cameras in the home. The hot water temperature was at 105.2 degrees Fahrenheit. Corrections: Telephone Service Component III was conducted. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to applicant Carol Noyes-Mora via email due to technical difficulties. The application will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager Abdoulaye Traore once corrections are submitted to LPA.

Bedroom # 3- It has two single beds and sleeps one foster child and one bed is vacant. Bedroom # 4- It has one king bed and It sleeps Licensees Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room. There was one child per bed. There were a family room and one living room next to the front entrance which is also designated to visitation. There was an area which contained toys and sports equipment that were observed to be safe, clean, and age appropriate for the age group of children to be cared for.

Inside the facility the fireplace was properly screened. Telephone service and appliances were in a working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. LPA Haynes observed a minimum of 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. The medication was in the lock box located in the licensee’s bedroom closet inaccessible to children. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the laundry room. The hot wProper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. The Facility Sketch; Emergency Disaster Plan; Personal Rights and visitation policy were posted. There were no guns or weapons as stated by Licensee at this time. The backyard was observed to be clean and free of hazards. There was a game room linked to the garage. It had two pool tables, a bathroom and a sink. There was no pool or other body of water. Based on this inspection there is one type B violation. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report and LIC 809D was discussed and provided to applicants this date.

who confirmed this information regarding C1. While other confidential information received by Licensing Office stated that these allegations had occurred. investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Daniel Mena met with Licensees, Shaka Finnell and Ellis Jones to discuss the investigative findings for the above stated allegation. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Daniel Mena conducted an inspection to the Small Family Home (SFH) on April 06, 2022. Special Investigator (SI), Marlon Williams interviewed both Licensees (A1 & A2), County Social Worker (CSW), as well as reviewed client interviews, police, facility and client records. Community Care Licensing received information on April 01, 2022 alleging that minor was physically abused resulting in injury, more specifically that C1 was hit in the face by Co- Licensee (A2). Information obtained in confidential interviews did not corroborate the allegations with a preponderance of evidence. Confidential interviews denied that anyone in the home had ever hit or physically mistreated C1. According to confidential information obtained, C1 has a documented history of making false allegations and self-injurious behaviors. Investigator Williams spoke to C1’s County Social Worker

LPA also collected the following documents AWOL notes for C1 for the following dates 11/6/2023, 11/5/2023, 11/4/2023, 11/2/2023, 10/21/2023, 10/25/2023, and 10/29/2023, Health and Education Passport for C1, contact information for caregivers for C1, Agency Small Family Home Foster Parents Agreement for C1, Medi-cal coverage letter for C1, Letter to County Social Worker (CSW) about C1’s behavior, and Needs and Case Plan Summary for C1. On June 3, 2021 at 3:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kourtney Williams arrived at the Shallowhorn Small Family Home to conduct an annual inspection. LPA met with Licensee Danielle Shallowhorn who granted LPA access to the home. At 3:10 PM, LPA began a tour both inside and out with the Licensee. There were two children in the home at the time of this inspection. The home was set up as follows: • Bedroom #1 upstairs had a television , a couch, folding table, chairs and dressers. There is a secondary sink area that is closed off from the room. • Bedroom #2 upstairs had two twin beds. It sleeps a 9 year- old foster child #1 (FC1) and a 6- year foster child #2 (FC2). • Bedroom #3: upstairs had two vacant twins’ beds and a television. • Bedroom #4: upstairs is a guest room had a queen size bed. • Bedroom #5: upstairs sleeps the Licensees 16 – year old biological son. There is a queen sized bed in the room. Bedroom#6: upstairs is the master bedroom with an attached bathroom. It sleeps Licensee and husband. • Bedroom #7 : downstairs is the Licensee's office. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes was used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The fireplace was properly screened. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medications were locked and stored downstairs in the licensee's office. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in a locked closet downstairs in the hallway. Sharp knives were inaccessible and locked in a closet in the downstairs hallway. The first aid kit was located in the kitchen in a lower cabinet located by the kitchen entrance.

There were no guns or weapons as stated by licensee at this time. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be within regulation requirement. Proper storage of all food was noted. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. The Emergency Disaster Plan with exit map, Title 22 Personal Rights, and visitation policies were posted at this time. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. There was no pool or other body of water on the premises. Toys were safe, clean, and age appropriate for the age group of children being cared for. CPR and the First Aid cards expires on 09/23/21. Children and staff records are organized. Administrative records included: A review of one staff and two client's records on this date indicates that all facility. Staff have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances and required documents, In accordance with Title 22, Division 6, Chapters 1 & 4, there were no deficiencies being cited at this time. Based on this annual inspection, the home was operating within a full capacity of three children. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report and confidential names List (LIC 811) were given and explained to the licensee.

It was used as a guest bedroom There were also an office, a living room, dining area, a kitchen, a half bathroom and a pantry. Upstairs: Bedroom #3, The room was furnished with a queen bed had a bathroom. It was used as a guest room - vacant. Bedroom #4, The master bedroom, furnished with a king-sized bed, had a bathroom. It sleeps applicant and spouse. Bedroom #5, The room was furnished with two twin beds. It will sleep two residents. Bedroom #6, The room was furnished with a full sized bunked bed. It sleeps one resident. Bedroom #7, The room was furnished with a table and a desk. It was used as an office.

Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. Regarding the allegation that licensee engaged in inappropriate interaction with foster child resulting in injuries, it was specifically alleged that L1 took a board game from FC1 and in the process of taking it scratched FC1. During investigation, confidential interviews stated that during an incident FC1 had forced their way in to L1’s office and grabbed a box that was in the office and while attempting to run out of the office L1 tried to grab the box and accidentally scratched FC1. LPA was unable to interview FC2 and there were no other witnesses to the incident. LPA was unable to interview FC1 due to not being able to contact FC1’s new guardian. LPA was unable to gather additional information. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that licensee engaged in inappropriate interaction with FC1 resulting in injuries may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violation. Therefore, this allegations is unsubstantiated at this time. LPA Enriquez had a telephone contact with the licensee Danielle Norman, she provide verbal authorization to LPA to allow her assistant Ariana Torres to sign report. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report along with the appeal right were reviewed and provided to facility representative.
investigation_findings: 13On September 18, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rafael Enriquez arrived at Shallowhorn Small Family Home (SFM) and met with Assistant Ariana Torres to deliver the finding for the allegation stated above involving the SFM’s staff and foster children (FC1 and FC2) as listed on the Confidential Names List (LIC 811) dated September 18, 2024. On February 16, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging that licensee engaged in inappropriate interaction with foster child resulting in injuries. On February 21, 2024, LPA Enriquez initiated the investigation at the SFH and obtained pertinent documents. Additionally, LPA conducted a safety inspection of the SFH, no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. During the inspection, LPA interviewed licensee (L1) and staff 1 (S1). LPA was not able to interview FC2 due to FC2 being non-verbal. LPA attempted to be in contact with FC1.

narrative: Regarding the allegation that licensee restricted a foster child's food intake, it was specifically alleged that L1 restricted FC1’s breakfasts and dinners due to FC1 being overweight. During investigation, confidential interviews denied that FC1 was restricted on eating. It was added that FC1 was able to eat whenever FC1 wanted and was told not to snack so much but never restricted. LPA was unable to interview FC2 because FC2 was nonverbal. LPA was unable to gather additional information. In regard to the allegation licensee forced a foster child to wear an inappropriate clothing item, it was specifically alleged that L1 forced FC1 to wear a girdle to school. Confidential interviews denied that L1 forced FC1 to wear a girdle. It was added that L1 bought FC1 some compression shirts but did not force FC1 to wear them. LPA was unable to gather additional information. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that licensee restricted a FC1’s food intake and licensee forced FC1 to wear an inappropriate clothing item may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violations. Therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. LPA Enriquez had a telephone contact with the licensee Danielle Norman, she provide verbal authorization to LPA to allow her assistant Ariana Torres to sign report. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report along with the appeal right were reviewed and provided to facility representative.

narrative:
On January 24, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez arrived at Shallowhorn Small Family Home (SFH) to conduct an annual inspection. LPA met with licensee Danielle Norman who led a tour of the entire home. The home is a two story residence with 7 bedrooms and 6 bathrooms. The home is approved for 3 ambulatory clients. The downstairs consist of an entry way with visitor sign in log, a vacant guest bedroom with a king size bed fully furnished, an office that is locked at all times and holds all client and personnel records as well as emergency disaster plan, license, client roster and cash resources. Downstairs also has a bathroom that is fully functioning and stocked with all necessary toiletries. A storage closet with games and books for clients. There is a living room that is fully furnished with television and couches. The kitchen had a dining table, fully stocked refrigerator and pantry with both perishable and non- perishable foods. The pantry stored the first aid kit with all required elements. There was a locked storage closet that stored all cleaning supplies and sharps/knives. There is fire extinguisher next to garage door and a nook that stores extra waters and another guest room that is currently vacant with a queen size bed and bathroom. The upstairs consists of a bed room for licensee's biological son (which is locked at all times as he is in college), a master bedroom with a king size bed and master bathroom for licensee (also locked at all times), there is a loft that stores an up to date fire extinguisher and escape ladder, there is a storage closet that stores medication and medication logs. There is a laundry room locked at all times with a locked cabinet storing laundry detergent and laundry supplies. There is also a bathroom that is fully functioning with water temperature reaching 114.4 degrees Fahrenheit, a trash can with tight fitting lid and all necessary hygiene supplies for clients. There is a fully furnished bedroom that sleeps one client with one twin size bed currently vacant and one full size bed that is utilized for one client. The bedroom has enough closet and drawer space for two clients as well as bedding has all required elements and lighting.

There is another client bedroom that sleeps one client and has two full size beds one utilized for client and one vacant. There is storage/clothing space, and working light fixtures. The bedrooms were arranged so that there was one client to a room, and there was one client per bed and individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses are in good repair. There were no firearms or weapons in the facility as stated by Mrs. Norman at this time. The garage stores parked cars, deep freezer with frozen goods, a locked cabinet for hazardous items and other house supplies/decor. The backyard is free of hazards and has adequate space for activities. There is a storage shed in the backyard that is locked at all times and stores holiday decorations and other house supplies. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. There is no pool or other body of water. During file review one staff member has done a Tuberculosis test however staff member is still awaiting results. Licensee understands that test result need to be given to LPA as soon as result are in. LPA reviewed 3 staff files and 2 client files. LPA interviewed 2 staff and 2 clients. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews this date, there are no deficiencies found at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report along with 2 technical assistances were reviewed and provided to licensee Danielle Norman.

LPA and LPM gave a copy of the LIC 184, Notice of Application Revision, and additional correspondence to assist with the revisions needed to the application. On February 12, 2025 on 9:24 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez arrived at She Love Home Small Family Home (SFH) for a pre-licensing inspection for an initial license. LPA met with applicant Melissa Bowdry who led a tour of the entire home inside and out. Currently there are no children placed in the home. The applicant is applying to serve four children ages 0 to 17. The home is a two-story building with 5 bedrooms and 3 bathrooms. The downstairs consisted of an entry way with posted personal rights, facility sketch, emergency disaster plan and visitation policy. There was a living room fully furnished with couches and television, bedroom #1 that will be utilized for a non-ambulatory client that was fully furnished with the appropriate bedding and is currently vacant. There was also bathroom #1 that will be used by a non-ambulatory client as there is a walk in standing shower and plenty of space for movement, the first aid kit was located in there as well. LPA went over the required elements needed in first aid kit. The water temperature was reaching 130 degrees, applicant placed a temporary hot water caution sign until water is in the 105- 120 degree range. The downstairs also has a fully functioning kitchen with working appliances, locked knives/ sharps, locked cleaning supplies, pantry and refrigerator need more perishable and non-perishable foods as well as dairy products. Applicant understands that a dining table with appropriate seating is needed for dining purposes. There was fire extinguisher #1 located in kitchen that was up to date and a storage closet that holds extra house hold items such as toilet paper and paper towels. The laundry room was accessible to clients with locked detergents and other cleaning supplies. The upstairs consisted of bedroom #2 that had a full size bed with appropriate bedding and closet space that will be utilized for clients currently vacant. There was also a television and a missing dresser and light fixture. Bedroom #3 had a full size bed and was fully furnished that was utilized for applicants biological daughter. Bedroom #4 had two twin size beds with appropriate

bedding essentials and closet space however was missing dresser and light fixtures. Bedroom #5 was the master bedroom for applicant that was locked at all times that also has bathroom #2. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. The hallway had fire extinguisher #2 and storage cabinets that stored linen and towels. Bathroom #3 had a fully functioning shower, toilet and two sinks with one locked cabinet storing bathroom cleaning supplies and another cabinet storing extra hygiene products such as tooth paste. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and are working properly. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access The garage was spacious and free of hazards with a an extra refrigerator that was locked as it only stores liquor and the freezer portion was stocked with frozen goods. The backyard was fully enclosed with a gate that has a latch and free of hazards and obstruction. There is no pool or other body of water and there are no guns or weapons as stated by Ms. Bowdry at this time. Based on this inspection of the home, the facility will need the following corrections: - First aid kit with all required elements (missing first aid manual, scissors, and thermometer) - Water temperature to be adjusted to measure between 105- 120 degrees Fahrenheit (has a caution sign posted at this time) - Pantry and refrigerator needs more perishable and nonperishable foods as well as dairy products. - Dining table is needed for dining purposes with 4-6 seating arrangement - Dressers and lighting fixtures are needed for two client bedrooms - Lock box for medication and refrigerated medication is also needed After corrections are completed, the applicant will notify LPA so that another inspection can be completed. On January 17, 2025 at 11:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Irene Yamamoto conducted an unannounced case management inspection at Shelton Small Family Home (SFH). LPA met with the Licensee/Administrator Gregory Shelton. The purpose of the inspection is to inquire about an incident that occurred on April 21, 2024 that was not reported to the Department. The incident involved a client who is no longer in placement. Further follow up is needed. A copy of this report and the LIC811 Confidential Names Form was provided at the conclusion of the inspection.

It was alleged that the facility refused to pick up youth from the hospital. The investigation revealed a behavioral incident involving the youth on 5/24/24 which escalated to verbal and physical aggression towards staff and the Director. The incident resulted in a law enforcement response to the facility, and the youth being assessed, then hospitalized. When the youth was cleared for discharge from the hospital on 5/25/24, the facility refused to pick up the youth. Instead, the facility submitted a 24-hour notice of emergency removal citing that the youth needed a higher level of care and the youth's needs could not be met. A review of records revealed that Shelton SFH was aware of the youth’s basic and targeted needs, as outlined in a county placement agency document (Letter of Commitment) and the youth's needs and services plan. The document stipulated that in the event the youth’s needs cannot be met, a 30-day written notice is required. Furthermore, the facility plan of operation indicated that a client care conference is conducted prior to discharge/eviction to ensure involvement by all interested parties to prevent transfer trauma. There was no 30-day written notice submitted to the county placement agency and no record of any attempt for a client care conference prior to discharge of the youth. Based on information obtained during the investigation, there is a preponderance of evidence found therefore, the allegation is substantiated. The facility is cited under California Code of Regulations 80022(k) Plan of Operation - the facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation. Refer to LIC9099-D for the deficiency citation issued. This requirement was not met as evidenced by the facility not following its plan of operation when the facility refused to pick up youth from the hospital. This poses a health, safety and personal rights risk to children in care. A Plan of Correction was discussed with the licensee, and copies of the following reports were provided at the conclusion of the inspection: LIC9099, LIC9099-C, LIC9099-D and LIC811 Confidential Names dated 1/17/25. The reports were also emailed to licensee. Appeal rights forms were given and explained.
investigation_findings: 13On January 17, 2025 at 11:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Irene Yamamoto conducted a subsequent complaint inspection at the Shelton small family home (SFH) to deliver the finding of a complaint received by the Department on 9/5/24. LPA met with Licensee/Administrator Gregory Shelton. The allegation was investigated by the undersigned LPA which includes confidential interviews with county placement agency staff on 9/6/24, school personnel on 9/12/24 and licensee on 9/12/24. LPA reviewed an interview completed by the LPA on 7/26/24 with the licensee of another SFH, who is the Director of this SFH. The interview pertains to the same youth, who was previously placed in the other SFH. Between 9/11/24 to 1/15/25, pertinent records were reviewed including, but not limited to, county placement agency documents, county placement agency investigative report, client needs and services plan, incident report, emergency request for removal, law enforcement report and facility plan of operation.

deficiencies.description:
Plan of Operation - the facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation. 
This requirement was not met as evidenced by the facility not following its plan of operation when the facility refused to pick up youth from the hospital.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee will submit a written plan to ensure that it adheres to its plan of operation. In the event that licensee wants to make revisions to its plan of operation, a written plan must be submitted to the Department and should not be implemented until Department approval is granted.

narrative: LPA contacted various county placement agency staff on 8/15/24, 8/21/24, 8/26/24, 9/6/24 and 10/9/24. LPA was unable to obtain a statement from the identified minor due to being removed from placement. However, LPA obtained and reviewed additional records from the county placement agency and law enforcement. The investigation revealed that the allegations came about after the minor had a couple of behavioral incidents between 5/22/24 and 5/24/24. Minor was alleged to be often disrespectful to staff and during the aforementioned dates, minor engaged in verbal and physical aggression towards the caregiver and one staff. During an incident on 5/24/24, minor continued with verbal and physical aggression and bit the staff, despite efforts by caregiver and staff to de-escalate the minor. Law enforcement and a mental evaluation unit responded to the facility and after a safety assessment of the minor was completed, the minor was involuntary detained and hospitalized. Records show that the minor claimed the allegations occurred. Minor described ongoing issues between minor and caregiver which caused minor’s escalated behaviors such as disrespectful comments, threats of hospitalization and law enforcement involvement. Although some parties interviewed observed the bite mark sustained by the staff, there were no witnesses to the incidents of the reported dates. There were inconsistent statements obtained regarding observed interactions between caregiver and minor. Based on the information gathered during the investigation, the allegations are unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence found to prove that the alleged violations occurred. The finding of the allegations was discussed with the licensee and copies of the following reports were provided at the conclusion of the inspection: LIC9099, LIC9099-C and LIC811 Confidential Names, dated 1/17/25. Appeal rights forms were also given and explained. Copies of the reports were also emailed to the licensee. There was no deficiency citation issued.
investigation_findings: 13On January 17, 2025 at 11:00AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Irene Yamamoto conducted a complaint inspection at Shelton Small Family Home (SFH). The purpose is to inform the facility of an investigation regarding the above allegations. LPA met with the Licensee/Admonistrator Gregory Shelton. narrative: On 03/14/2025 at 12:05 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olena Maico conducted unannounced case management inspection at the above facility and met with Gregory Shelton, Licensee. The case management was warranted by the report of another LPA who was visiting the facility for a complaint investigation and noted some items that needed monitoring LPA's attention. On February 27, 2025, LPA D. Teal conducted a walk through of the SFH and observed chemicals under the sink in the kitchen, an open laundry room with liquid detergents on a shelf, which were exposed. The door to the laundry room does not have a lock on it. In bedroom 2, LPA did not observe any dresser drawers. There is one client in the room. There was a container in the closet, on the floor of the closet. I asked the administrator/licensee if there were any drawers in the room and administrator/licensee said they are going to get some. LPA observed multicolor containers in a cabinet, in the kitchen over the refrigerator. The containers were locked, and LPA was advised that they contained the client’s medicine. The cabinet was not locked and did not have locks on it. LPA Maico conducted a walk through the Small Family Home and found it to be in good condition and repair. LPA conducted tour of the kitchen, the medications and the sharps were locked in the kitchen cabinet above the fridge in the lock boxes. LPA checked all the kitchen drawers and cabinets, the kitchen sink cabinets have a lock on it and all the chemicals were moved to the garage. The detergent from the laundry room was moved to the garage box as well and is locked and inaccessible. LPA also observed rooms to be in good repair and LPA checked the licensee's bedroom and the licensee bedroom has a lock, so the items in licensee's room (chemicals) are inaccessible to the clients). Bedroom # 2 has a drawer with the space for the client to store items, as well as a closet space for private use of a client. LPA also observed no chemicals in the bathroom accessible to clients. The backyard is free of hazards. Living room has TV and a furniture for clients to use. LPA observed perishable and non-perishable food supply to comply with the regulations. No deficiencies cited at this time. The copy of this report was given and explained to the Facility Director.
