narrative:
On April 17, 2024 at 9:10 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olena Maico conducted an unannounced Annual Licensing Inspection at Shelton Small Family Home (SMH) and met with Licensee Gregory Shelton and Ayan Hill, Facility Director. Prior to the inspection LPA sent out an e-mail request to the facility’s Director for LIC 500 Personnel Report, LIC 9020 Register of Clients, LIC 610C Emergency Preparedness plan and LIC 308 Designation of Administrative Responsibility. The documents were provided to the LPA. A physical plant inspection was completed. The facility license, facility sketch, emergency disaster form and personal rights form were all prominently displayed in the home. All exits and hallways were observed to be free and clear of hazards and obstruction. Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested are in working order. LPA observed Emergency Intervention Plan, Menu, Facility sketch in the kitchen in the binders. LPA Maico observed that the facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. The passageways and entrances inside and outside of the home are unobstructed. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions were stored in a locked container in the garage. LPA observed an amount of perishable and non-perishable food required by CCL in the kitchen fridge and cabinets. Medications are locked in the kitchen and accessible only to the Licensee and staff. Sharps are locked in the kitchen cabinets. The temperature in the rooms that clients occupy are maintained at 70 degrees and the hot water temperature was at 120 degrees (F). Ms. Hill confirmed there are no weapons and/or ammunition in the home.

Individual beds in the client bedrooms were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good condition. Each bedroom has sufficient drawer and closet space. There are 2 full bathrooms in the home, all in working order and floors and bathtub has non-slip rugs. There are four (4) direct care staff available at the facility and 2 Facility Directors. Licensee is still the main caretaker for the clients. Clients and staff files are electronic and kept on the licensee's computer. The licensee and facility director have access to them. Emergency disaster drills are conducted at least every six (6) months and LPA reviewed the record on the laptop of all the drills. Emergency disaster plan is in the binder and available for the review. LPA reviewed 2 client files, which contained medical assessments, TB test, personal Rights Acknowledgement and Admission Agreements all signed and dated or have records of refusal to sign. LPA reviewed medication logs with psychotropic medications for client and it has all the necessary fields completed and signed, as well as JV 223 attached. LPA also reviewed Needs and Services Plan for clients. LPA reviewed 5 staff files, . Criminal record and Child Abuse Index clearance were reviewed and confirmed for all the adults at the facility. LPA also reviewed Guardian website for clearances. Staff files had staff Health screening and TB test, training records (initial 8 hours and 16 hours), CPR certificates, duties and responsibilities, resumes, etc. LPA interviewed 2 staff. No clients have been interviewed due to one client being non-verbal and one being on AWOL status. No deficiency citations were issued during the annual inspection. One technical advisory was issued to the facility. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the licensee and facility director along with the LIC 811.

On April 28, 2025, the Department received a complaint alleging that staff (PS2) engaged in physical altercations with a minor in care, and staff (PS2) spoke inappropriately to a minor in care. During the interview(s) with FD and S1 (both who reported to the LPA that they were not made aware, nor had any knowledge of the alleged incident), it was discovered that PS2 is no longer employed by the SFH. LPA attempted to contact PS2 on 5/8/2025, 5/9/2025, and 5/19/2025 via phone call to discuss the allegations against him. But to no avail. Contact number for PS2 was no longer in service. On 5/02/2025, LPA attempted to meet with and interview C1, however, FD informed LPA that C1’s placement at the SFH had been terminated and C1 had been transported to the Welcoming Center (WC) in San Jose, CA. On 5/16/2025, an LPA from the San Jose Regional Office arrived at the WC and attempted to meet with and interview C1. But to no avail. C1 refused to meet with and speak to the LPA. On 5/20/2025, LPA (Christopher J. Williams) attempted a phone/virtual interview with C1 (at the WC). But to no avail. Per staff (Robert-Manager) at the WC, C1 refused to speak with LPA regarding the allegations. During the investigation, it was determined that the information gathered by the LPA was limited due to PS2 not being available for interview, and C1 refusing to be interviewed, making the findings of the allegations difficult to determine if true or false. The LPA’s investigation revealed that due to conflicting statements gathered from confidential interviews via documentation, phone call(s) and in person, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not enough preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation. A signed copy of this report was discussed and provided to the Facility Representative. Exit interview conducted. No deficiencies cited at this time. Appeal rights was provided to the SFH.
investigation_findings: 13On May 23, 2025, at 8:45 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher J. Williams conducted a follow-up inspection at the Shelton Small Family Home (SFH) for the purpose of delivering findings on the above allegations. LPA met with Ayan Hill, Facility Director (FD). LPA’s investigation consisted of reviewing a statement from the Reporting Party (RP) on 04/29/2025 and a 10-day visit conducted with the SFH on 5/02/2025, where LPA met with and interviewed the FD concerning the allegations (See LIC811 – Confidential Names list dated: 5/02/2025). On 5/08/2025, LPA interviewed staff (S1) via phone call due to S1 not being available during the initial 10-day visit. On 4/29/2025, LPA conducted a review of the RFH’s complaint history, reviewed documentation obtained from other agencies and Guardian / LIS systems. On 5/02/2025, LPA obtained and reviewed the LIC500 (Personnel Report), current client roster, initial needs and services plan for C1, and any relevant documentation such as Special Incident Reports (SIRS), if applicable. Continued on LIC9099c.

narrative: It was also alleged that licensee does not ensure that staff has criminal record clearance prior to working with residents. Staff denied the allegation. Staff stated that everyone that has been working or worked within the facility has been fingerprint cleared. Staff stated that everyone associated to facility lives or works at facility. Documents reviewed identified no incidents of smoking in a facility or issues with client smoking cigarettes or marijuana. Additionally, documents identified no staff unclear working in facility. LPAs tried to reach county social workers; however, LPA was unable to reach social workers or additional witnesses. Based on information gathered, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was not met, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report Confidential Names Form, and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection
investigation_findings: On 6/18/2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Johanna Aracena made an unannounced visit to the Shelton SFH on behalf of LPA Dawn Mahecha for the purpose of concluding the above complaint investigation. LPA met with representative and discussed the following findings to complaint investigation. Investigation consisted of the following: On 2/27/2025 LPA Demetris Teal conducted initial 10-day inspection to SFH. LPA Teal requested documents be emailed to LPA Mahecha. LPA Mahecha reviewed the following received documents: NSP, LIC500, trainings, incident reports, discharge paperwork. LPA Aracena interviewed staff and children. Investigation revealed the following: It was alleged Staff do not prevent a minor from smoking marijuana inside of the facility. Staff denied the allegation. Staff stated nobody smokes at the facility staff or client. Staff stated their client is 9yrs old and not verbal. He has total care and he does not leave the facility unless accompanied by a staff or licensee.

narrative: It was alleged that minor sustained unexplained injuries while in care. Confidential staff interviews were consistent. C1 has self-harming behaviors. Review of C1 NSP and IP it is documented that C1 exhibits daily episodes of severe self-injurious behaviors that include scratching, biting and pinching himself and staff should keep a log and document injuries. The SFHs log for behavior and body checks documented the bruise in question on June 18, 2025. Based on the information gathered during confidential interviews the allegation is unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or are valid, the standard of the preponderance of evidence was not met. An exit interview was conducted, and a signed copy of this report was provided to the facility licensee along with LIC9099C. Appeal rights explained.
investigation_findings: On August 12, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Angelina Garibaldo conducted an unannounced follow up complaint inspection visit at Shelton Small Family Home and met with Direct Care Staff, Shasta Stubbs for the purpose of delivering findings for the above allegation. During the course of the investigation, LPA Garibaldo conducted confidential interviews with three school personnel on 6/24/25, two staff on 6/25/25, one staff on 7/11/25, and one staff on 8/11/25. LPA also reviewed documents including but not limited to staff training and certificates, special incident reports (SIRs), Needs and Services Plans (NSPs), Intervention Plan: for Reduction of Severe Self Injurious Behavior (IP) and SFH group chat. C1 was unable to be interviewed due to their diagnosis of non-verbal autism. (Reference Confidential Names list LIC811 dated0 8/12/25). Page

narrative:
On June 10th,2025, at 10:50 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Johanna Aracena conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection at the above address. LPA met with the applicants Ruth Nyanzwii and Grace Nyanzwii. A physical plant inspection was conducted. The following were observed at the time of inspection: This facility is a three- story home located in a residential community. This facility consists of four (4) bedrooms, three (3) full bathrooms upstairs and a half bathroom. On the first floor there is the entrance, Bedroom #1 with a full bathroom and the garage. Bedroom #1 is occupied by applicant #2. On the second floor there is the kitchen, living room and dining room. There is also a half a bathroom, desk/office set up, and a small patio. There is small closet in the patio which is used to keep the chemicals, cleaning and laundry supply storage. There are no cameras inside or outside the home. The third floor locates bedroom #2 and bedroom #3 which are equipped with queen beds, closet and drawer space for the use of foster children. Bedroom #3 needs closet cleaned out and extra mattress be taken out. Bedroom #4 is also located on the 3rd floor. Bedroom #4 has its own full bathroom. There is a third full size bathroom on the third floor for the use of the children. The facility is clean, sanitary and in good condition. There are no bodies of water on the premises. The facility has a centralized heat and air-conditioning unit. Temperatures in all rooms is comfortable. The hot water temperature was measured at 115 degrees (F). Carbon monoxide and smoke alarms were observed to be operational. There are two (2) fire extinguishers in kitchen and one by the main entrance of the home.

Knives and sharps will be locked in a kitchen cabinet. The applicants will purchase locks for the cabinets where the knifes and sharps will be kept. The facility will have a working cell phone that will suffice as the home phone since it will be staying at the home at all times. The applicants reports no firearms on the premises. The grounds are free from obstructions and hazards. LPA observed plenty of perishable and non-perishable food. The applicants will purchase a lockbox for any medicine that will required refrigeration. Applicants are not looking into hiring anyone for help at the moment. Medications will be centrally stored and a lock will be put on the medicine cabinet. A complete first aid kit is readily available in a central location in the facility. Pending Items - Applicant will obtain a lock for medicine cabinet and lockbox for refrigerated medication. -Applicant will clean closed for bedroom #3 and take bed out of the room. -Posting of menu and activities will be posted in the kitchen, Emergency Plan (LIC 601). A follow up inspection will be conducted to finalize the inspection. An exit interview was conducted a signed copy of this report was provided to the applicant.

On June 19, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Johanna Aracena, conducted a follow up inspection visit to Shine Bliss Small Family Home with the purpose of concluding the facility's pre-licensing inspection. During the visit LPA met with facility's Administrator Ruth Nyanzwii and Grace Nyanzwii. During the inspection visit LPA conducted a walk through of the facility and observed the following corrections: * Administrator obtained a lock for medicine cabinet and lockbox for refrigerated medication. * Closet for bedroom #3 has been cleared and extra mattres/bed was taken out of the room. * Facility's menu and activities have been posted along with the facility's Emergency Plan (LIC 601). * There is cell phone available for the children to use Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the administrator.

On July 8th, 2025 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez met with applicants Shyla and Roy Kuria this date for a Component II. LPA went over revisions needed for the application prior to licensure. LPA gave a copy of the LIC 184, Letter of Application Revision, and additional correspondence to assist with the revisions needed to the application. A copy of this report was provided to applicants Shlya and Roy Kuria

On August 8, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez arrived at Shyla and Roy Kuria Small Family Home (SFH) to conduct pre-licensing inspection for an initial license. LPA met with applicants Shyla and Roy Kuria who led a tour of the entire home inside and out. Currently there are no children placed in the home. The applicants are applying to serve two ambulatory clients ages 0-17 years old. The home is a two story building with five bedrooms and four and a half bathrooms. The downstairs consisted of an entry way with postings such as facility sketch and CPR certifications, there was a coat closet, and office with a desk, locked file cabinet where clients files and personnel records will be stored, a sliding door exit way and bathroom #1 that was a half bathroom with a toilet and sink. Downstairs also had a dining room area with adequate seating, a family room with a couch and faux fire place that was screened. The kitchen was clean and sanitary with a locked cabinet storing knives/ sharp objects, a locked cabinet for storing medication/first aid kit with all required elements and a locked sink cabinet storing cleaning supplies. The water temperature was measuring 109.5 degrees Fahrenheit. The refrigerator and pantry were stocked with perishable and non-perishable foods. There was a telephone land-line, fire extinguisher #1 that was operable, personal rights and emergency disaster plan also posted in the kitchen. There was a living room with couches, TV, and a screened fire place. Bedroom #1 was downstairs and was the guest bedroom that was locked at all times and had a full size bed and bathroom #2 that was fully functioning, the room is currently vacant. There was a storage closet for extra household items such as water jugs and brooms/mops. There was another storage closet that was locked storing tools, paint, and a vacuum. The laundry room was accessible to clients and had a locked cabinet storing laundry detergents.

The upstairs had bedroom #2 that was the master bedroom for applicants that will be locked at all times and had a queen size bed, a bassinet, and bathroom #3 that was fully functioning. Bedroom #3 will be utilized for one foster child and had a full size bed and a crib with closet/dresser space- currently vacant. There was a linen closet storing extra linen, blankets, and towels. Bathroom #4 was fully functioning with dual sinks and a locked sink cabinet for storing cleaning supplies. Bedroom #4 will be utilized for two foster children and had two twin size beds, dresser/closet space, and all required bedding- currently vacant. The upstairs also had a loft with toys, books, a table, couches and a first aid kit. Bedroom #5 was occupied by applicants biological daughter and had a full size bed and bathroom #5 that was fully functioning. The backyard had a locked shed storing gardening tools, a large side gate with a latch and there was no pool or other bodies of water. The garage stored three vehicles, fire extinguisher #2 and was free of hazards. As stated by applicants, there was no firearms in the home. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. All appliances were in working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients/children will have access. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. Based on this inspection, there are no corrections needed at this time, the home is appropriate for a capacity of two ambulatory clients. The request for licensure will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager (LPM) for final approval. Component III orientation was also completed this day of August 8, 2025. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to applicants Shyla and Roy Kuria.

Fixtures, Furniture, Equip The home has toilets and wash basins for clients' use. Client bedrooms were observed to be clean, orderly, and contained two twin beds. LPAs observed clean pillows, bed sheets and blankets. The client’s bedroom has an adequate closet and drawer space to accommodate the client’s clothing and personal belongings Heath Related Services and Record Keeping The medication will be stored in a locked closet in the kitchen. First aid kit was not available for review. Client and staff files will be kept in locked drawers in the office.

A Component III meeting was also conducted to familiarize the applicant with SFH Rules and Regulations as well as best practices. LPA sent the San Bernardino Fire Protection Station 172 an email with a copy of the form to expedite the process. - First Aid Kit - Buildings and Ground: Clean-up of the backyard/Hazardous materials - Buildings and Ground: Repairs to the ceiling in kitchen and client bedroom LPA Portillo will mail and email a new license once the Rancho Fire Department completes their inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this form was emailed to the Administrator.

On 10/26/2023 at 8:30 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Pamela Silva and Timika Martin conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection at the above address. LPAs met with Picolya Robinson, applicant. A physical plant inspection was conducted. The following were observed at the time of inspection: This facility is a single level home located in a residential neighborhood. The facility consists of 3 bedrooms, 2 full bathrooms, a living room, kitchen, dining room, 2-car garage, laundry room, a small office, and a backyard. Overall, the facility is clean, sanitary and in good condition. The facility has no bodies of water. The facility has a centralized heat and air-conditioning unit. Temperatures in all rooms are maintained at 73 degrees (F). The hot water temperature was measured at 111 degrees (F). Carbon monoxide and smoke alarms were tested and observed to be operational. The fire extinguisher located in the office is fully charged. Knives and sharps are kept in a container locked in the garage. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept in the cabinet located in the laundry room. The facility has a working telephone. The applicant reports no firearms on the premises. The grounds are free from obstructions and hazards. Clients will be utilizing bedroom #1. Bedroom #1 has 1 bed and has adequate closet and drawer space to accommodate client's clothing and personal belongings. Bedroom #2 will be occupied by applicant's bio children. Bedroom #3 will be occupied by applicant. Each bed has clean pillows, pillowcases, bed sheets and blankets. LPAs also observed extra linens stored in the hallway cabinet. Medications, client and staff records will be centrally stored and locked in the office. A complete first aid kit is readily available in a central location in the facility. Applicant reports that License, Emergency Plan (LIC 601) and facility sketch will be posted at the facility. The fire department is scheduled to conduct the fire clearance inspection on 10/30/23 at 10:00am. An exit interview was conducted a signed copy of this report was provided to the applicant.

On 12/06/23 at 8:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) arrived at the facility to conduct Component III and met with the licensee, Picolya Robinson. LPA provided licensee with the following Component III package/forms: · LIC 311E Records to be Maintained at a Small Family Home · LIC 500 Personnel Report · LIC 501 Personnel Record · LIC 503 Health Screening Report (TB Clearance) · LIC 508 Criminal Record Statement · LIC 601 Identification and Emergency Information · LIC 602 Physician’s Report · LIC 601 Identification and Emergency Information · LIC 603 Preplacement Appraisal Information · LIC 627 Consent for Medical Treatment · LIC 613 Personal Rights · LIC 613 Personal Rights · LIC 622 Centrally Stored Medication and Destruction Record · LIC 624 Unusual Incident/Injury/Death Report · LIC 625 Appraisal/Needs and Services Plan · LIC 9108 Statement Acknowledging Requirement to Report Child Abuse A copy of this report was provided to the licensee.

On 09/11/24 at 9:35AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPAs) Pamela Silva and Caitlin Chambers conducted an unannounced inspection at the Small Family Home (SFH) above for the purpose of conducting a Post Licensing inspection. LPAs met with the licensee of the home, Ms. Picolya Robinson. Currently, there are two (2) minor non-ambulatory clients in placement. There are no bodies of water on the premises. A physical plant inspection was completed. The facility license, facility sketch, emergency disaster form and personal rights form were all prominently displayed in the home. Temperatures in all rooms are maintained at 73 degrees (F). All exits and hallways were observed to be free and clear of hazards and obstruction. Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in working order. First aid kit was readily available and complete. Food supplies, both perishable and non-perishable, were checked and found to be sufficient. Knives and sharps are kept in a container locked in the garage. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept in the cabinet located in the laundry room. Medications are centrally stored and locked in the office. All exits, hallways and backyard were observed to be free and clear of hazards and obstruction. Ms. Robinson confirmed there are no weapons and/or ammunition in the home. Overall, the facility is clean, safe and sanitary. The following sleeping arrangements were noted: Bedroom #1 sleeps Client 1 Bedroom #2 sleeps Client 2 Bedroom #3 Master’s Bedroom Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good condition. Each bedroom has sufficient drawer and closet space. There are two full bathrooms in the home, all in working order.

The licensee is the main caretaker of the home. Client and staff files are stored under lock and key in the file cabinet in the office . Emergency disaster drills are conducted every month. LPAs reviewed two (2) client records and two (2) staff records. LPA checked required criminal record and child abuse index check clearance or exemption for all adults in the home. The client’s files contained: Admission Agreement, Medical Assessment, Consent Forms, Emergency Information, Needs and Services Plan, Immunization Record and Personal Rights. LPA interviewed the licensee. Clients were not available for interview at the time of inspection. LPA will attempt to interview clients at a later time. No deficiency citations were issued during today’s inspection. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the licensee, Ms. Picolya Robinson.

On September 12, 2022 at 9:08 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Anne Visaya returned and conducted a scheduled Annual inspection to the Slaughter Small Family home. LPA Visaya met with licensee Bernice Slaughter who let a tour of the home. The facility was toured inside and out and currently there is one client in the home and is at school at this time. The home is a two story home and consists of: Upstairs: Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate shelf and closet space. Bedroom #1, furnished with 2 twin size bunk bed, a closet and plenty of storage space it is empty at this time Bedroom #2, furnished with 2 twin size bed, a closet and plenty of storage space and it is empty at this time Bedroom #3, furnished with 2 twin size bunk bed, a closet and plenty of storage space, it sleeps a 5 year old male client Bedroom #4 Master bedroom with a king size bed for Licensee. The master bedroom door will be locked at all times when there are children present. Game room area has tables and chairs for children, kids entertainment and have toys that are safe, clean, and age appropriate for the age group of the child being cared for.

Downstairs: upon entry to the home, a furnished living room, a dining room with a large table and a locked closet under the stairs, kitchen with a pantry, a breakfast nook with small round table and 4 chairs, a family/den room with fireplace that is properly screened and secured, a half bathroom, and the garage. Bathroom number one downstairs hot water temperature measured to be 105.6 degrees Fahrenheit, bathroom number two upstairs hot water temperature measured to be 107 degrees F, bathroom number three is the bathroom that the licensee uses and is not accessible by the clients. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and are working properly. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. Medications are locked in the master bedroom closet. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in the stairs locked closet. The first aid kit contains all required items. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in the stairs locked closet. Telephone service and appliances are all in working order. There are no guns or weapons as stated by Mrs. Slaughter at this time. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan and visitation policy are posted at this time. Personal Rights is posted. The backyard where children will have access to play is completely fenced and free of hazards. There is no pool or other body of water. A review of one of one staff records indicates that all facility staff have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances and CPR and first aid is up to date. Licensees had current CPR/ First Aid certificates. Licensee provided proof of 8 hours of continued education training. A review of one of one client files are noted to have documents required per regulations in file. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews this date, there are no deficiencies found at this time. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was discussed and provided to Licensee Bernice Slaughter this date.

On November 17, 2021 at 10:47am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adrian Mendez arrived unannounced at the facility to conduct a Required Annual inspection of the facility. The facility was inspected inside and out with Administrator Nazanine Farshidian. The home is a two-story residence with five bedrooms, and three bathrooms. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water in the client bathroom was measured and is within regulatory requirements. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will not have access. The medications were stored and locked in a cabinet in the locked pantry in the kitchen. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in the laundry room. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the pantry in the kitchen. The First Aid Kit is located in the locked pantry in the kitchen and contained all required supplies. The facility's smoke/carbon monoxide detectors in the hallways were checked and were operable. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Administrator. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Facility License, Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Visitation policies, Emergency Disaster Plan and current menu. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. LPA discussed and reviewed the following inspection components; Operations. All the client files are stored and maintained in a secured off-site location. A sample of three client files were reviewed during the inspection. All client files had the required documents per Title 22 Regulations. Cont. on 809-C

All the staff files are stored and secured at an off-site location. LPA reviewed five staff files. All the staff have met the training and qualification requirements per regulation requirements. Per a review of the Community Care Licensing Information System (LIS), all staff met DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances and Child Abuse Index Check requirements. During the inspection, LPA interviewed two facility staff and two children. Based on the facility inspection, there are no deficiencies found at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was explained and provided to Administrator Nazanine Farshidian.

All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will not have access. The medications were stored and locked in a cabinet in the locked pantry in the kitchen. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Administrator. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. LPA discussed and reviewed the following inspection components; Operations. All the client files are stored and maintained in a secured off-site location. A sample of three client files were reviewed during the inspection. All client files had the required documents per Title 22 Regulations. Cont. on 809-C

All the staff files are stored and secured on an off-site location LPA reviewed five staff files. Per a review of the Community Care Licensing Information System (LIS), all staff met DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances and Child Abuse Index Check requirements. Based on the facility inspection, there are no deficiencies found at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal rights was provided to Nazanine Farshidian, Staff and Sonia Dezham, Administrator

***Continued from LIC 9099*** No immediate deficiencies observed. The following documents were collected from the SFH: admission agreement, authorization for medical care, Individual program planning (IPP), incident report of FC1 injury, emails, behavior spreadsheet and behavior summaries. Interviews were conducted with Licensee, FC1’s school personnel, staff 1, and bio child. FC1 social worker was not able to be contacted. LPA was unable to interview FC1 due to FC1’s developmental age and non-verbal. In regard to minor sustaining injury while in care, a confidential interview stated that FC1 would obtain bruises from having tantrums by falling onto the floor. The confidential interview added that FC1 would have tantrum when things are not going FC1’s way. Another confidential interview indicated that FC1 would have tantrum at school and could have sustained bruises. Confidential interviews did not elaborate how the bruises occurred. Regarding staff are not feeding minor allegation, confidential interviews stated that FC1 would eat breakfast every morning before school. FC1 would have a choice of what breakfast to eat. Another confidential interview stated that FC1 would arrive at school and eat breakfast as if FC1 had not eaten breakfast prior to going to school. It was added that FC1 previously would not eat breakfast and would throw away the breakfast and lunch the school provides in the trash. LPA received conflicting information. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that FC1 sustained injury while in care and staff are not feeding FC1, may have occurred, however, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report and appeal right was reviewed and provided to the licensee.

narrative: On January 3,2024 at 10:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Guadalupe Munoz and LPA Jacqueline Garcia arrived unannounced at the facility to conduct a Required Annual inspection of the facility. The facility was inspected inside and out with Administrator designee. Facility administrators was unavailable and administrator Sonia Dezham gave authorization for Maryam Ashayeri to sign for today's visit. The home is a two-story residence with six bedrooms, and three bathrooms.Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water in the client bathroom was measured and is within regulatory requirements. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will not have access. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in the laundry room. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the pantry in the kitchen. The First Aid Kit is located in the locked pantry in the kitchen and contained all required supplies. The facility's smoke/carbon monoxide detectors in the hallways were checked and were operable. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Administrator.The medications were stored and locked in a cabinet in the locked pantry in the kitchen. LPA attempted one client interview however due to disability and client being nonverbal interview was not completed. Staff and client files are located at business office. Due to client and staff file unavailability,annual inspection will need to be continued and completed at a later date. Based on the facility grounds inspection, a Type A deficiencies found at this time. LPA Munoz spoke with Facility Administrator on the phone and communicated the deficiency and created plan of correction to immediately correct deficiency. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to designee.Maryam Ashayeri

On November 18, 2024 at 09:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rachel Vanegas arrived unannounced to South County Care I for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection. LPA met with the Licensee - Sonia Dezham, who led a tour of the home, both inside and outside. The home is a two story home with five bedrooms and three restrooms. The home is set-up as follows: the first story of the facility consists of a guest room/living room, a dining room, a kitchen, family room with recreational activities accessible to children in care, a locked storage room where medication, knives, etc. are stored, a locked laundry room where chemicals and detergent are stored, one restroom, and Bedroom #1. There is an attached garage entry/exit doorway that remains locked and inaccessible to clients in care. Bedroom #1 has a twin sized bed and sleeps one client. There is adequate storage space for clothing and personal belongings and adequate linen. The second story of the facility consists of Bedroom #2, #3, #4, and #5, a storage closet with spare linen, and two additional restrooms. Bedroom #2 is the master bedroom and sleeps the Licensee. Bedroom #3 is vacant. It has two single beds and adequate store space for personal belongings and spare linens. Bedroom #4 has a single bed and sleeps one client. There is adequate storage space for personal belongings in drawers and a closet. Bedroom #5 is vacant. It has two single beds and adequate store space for personal belongings and spare linens. All required postings including the facility license, foster youth personal rights, grievance policy, meal menu's, etc. were observed to be posted in the kitchen. **Continued on LIC812-C**

All bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients are in a room and there is one client per bed. The hot water was measured in the kitchen and registered at 114.1 degrees F. LPA observed an adequate supply of nonperishable and perishable food in the facility pantry, refrigerator, and freezer. The facility outside grounds were also inspected and were observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction and there were no pools or other bodies of water at the time of this inspection. All hazardous items have been properly stored and are in inaccessible areas to clients. The fist aid kit is located in a pantry in the kitchen and was observed to contain all of the required supplies. The facilities smoke and carbon monoxide detectors are located in the hallway near the kitchen and were observed to be in operational order. There are no firearms or weapons stored on the facility grounds, per the Licensee. LPA conducted two client file reviews for Client 1 (C1) and Client 2 (C2) and observed the needed documents in the files including, medical screening clearance, individual program plans, consent to medical treatment authorization forms, placement agreements, etc. LPA conducted five staff file reviews for Staff (S) 1, S2, S3, S4, and S5 and observed that five out of five staff files contained needed documents including CPR/First Aid certificates, Drivers License, Job Duties, Health Screening, etc. The facility is issued one technical assistance in accordance with California Code of Regulations (CCR) section 80010(a) for operating the facility beyond the conditions and limitations specified on the license. Licensee provided proof of submission for LIC200 to LPA for processing that is pending. Licensee also provided proof for an age waiver request for the non minor dependent (C2) in care. Facility administrator, Nanzanine Farshidian, states that the age waiver request was submitted on August 5, 2021. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 9102, LIC 811, and appeal rights were reviewed and provided to the licensee - Sonia Dezham.

On Tuesday October 12, 2021 at 2:00 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes conducted an annual inspection of the facility. The facility was toured inside and out with licensee Meljorie Castelo. The home is a two story residence with five bedrooms and five bathrooms. There are currently no placement's at this time. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room and there is one child per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space. The Carbon Monoxide detector is located on the ceiling in the hallway and is operable. Smoke detectors located in the bedrooms were tested and are operable. The facility outside grounds were also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. There is a swimming pool located at the facility the gate is a self locking gate, five foot tall with no more than four inches between the bars. LPA reviewed caregivers files. All caregivers have Department of Justice and Child Abuse Index Check clearances, first aid and CPR cards are current. All training records are current. There are currently no Children in placement so there are no client files to review. Based on the inspection this date, there are no deficiencies being cited. Exit Interview conducted and a copy of this report provided to licensee Meljorie Castelo.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Toni Castillo made a visit to the Special Tots Small Family home. There are no clients placed in this home. Licensee provided LPA with the certification of non operational requesting to close out this license.

On June 5, 2024, at 9:10 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karen Beal began an inspection for a Small Family Home pre-licensing. LPA met with applicant Felencia Green who led a tour of the home and the backyard. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicants. Applicants are applying for a capacity of 2 ambulatory children and the house is a 4-bedroom two-story house: Downstairs: It consists of a kitchen, dining room, a living room, family room, office, bathroom, and the garage. Upstairs: Bedroom #1- Applicant's Bedroom King Bed Bedroom #2- foster children's room- two twin beds Bedroom #3 Bio child room- Queen- Bed Bedroom #4 Bio child room- Queen- Bed Bedroom #5 Bio child Queen Bed- (loft Conversion) Laundry Room Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and are working properly. All hazardous items will be stored upstairs in the laundry room and have been properly made inaccessible, children will not have access. Medication and sharp knives were inaccessible and stored downstairs in a locked closet in the downstairs bathroom. First Aid kit was accessible with all required items. A Fire extinguisher was observed and properly charged. There were no guns or weapons as stated by applicant, Felencia Green. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 118 degrees. Applicants understand that the water temperature must be maintained within the regulation range of 105-120 degrees. Proper storage of all food was noted. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids.

The Emergency Disaster Plan with exit map, Title 22 Personal Rights, and visitation policies were posted at this time. The home has a telephone service currently. The backyard where children will have access to play is completely fenced and free of hazards. There is no pool or other body of water. Component III orientation was conducted by LPA Beal. Based on this inspection, the home is appropriate for a capacity of 2 ambulatory children. The request of License will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was discussed and provided to Felencia Green, applicant.

Continued from LIC 9099 On July 22, 2022, the Department received a complaint that alleged facility staff abandoned minor at hospital. Specifically, it was reported FM did not pick up FC1 from the hospital in a timely manner. During investigation, a confidential interview stated the child was not ready to be released due to still doing self-harm while in the hospital. Another confidential interview stated the FM did not refuse to pick up FC1. After arriving to pick up FC1 at the hospital, FC1 charged at FM as if FC1 was going to attack the FM. Hospital security had to restrain FC1 to protect FM. FC1 was admitted back into the hospital. A confidential interview stated that FC1 and FM got along very well unless FC1 was having aggression. Another confidential stated FM was concerned for her safety due FC1 aggressiveness at the hospital. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that facility staff abandoned FC1 at the hospital may have happened or may be valid, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the allegation, therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time.

narrative:
On May 30th, 2025, at 9:35AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Claudia Aguilera and Cynthia Ramos arrived at Spectrum Support Solutions LLC Small Family Home (SFH) to conduct an unannounced post licensing inspection. Currently, there are no clients in the home, however the home is approved for a capacity of two clients. The Facility was toured both inside and out with the licensee. The home is a two-story building with five bedrooms and two and a half bathrooms. During the inspection, LPAs observed that the downstairs consisted of a receiving area with a couch, chair and small coffee table. The formal dining room consisted of a large table with adequate seating. The kitchen consisted of a pantry, refrigerator, and a small room dining table; additional seats were available in the kitchen island. The family room consisted of a large sectional couch, television, blankets, and toys. The downstairs also consisted of a hallway closet that stored fire extinguisher, first aid kit, and cleaning tools (i.e. broom/mop). The downstairs also consisted of an office with a computer, office supplies, and a large fish tank. Restroom #1 was located downstairs with close lid trash can and a locked storage area which stores knives, sharps, and cleaning supplies. The garage was inspected and consisted of storage area, refrigerator, freezer, and a large file cabinet that stores medications and files. The backyard was also inspected, there were no hazards or obstructions observed. The upstairs consisted of Bedroom #1 occupied by licensee and always remains locked which also includes bathroom #2. Bedroom #2 is vacant and readily available for two clients with two twin beds, closet, and storage space. Bedroom #3 sleeps licensee’s biological son and remains locked at all times. Bedroom #4 is empty without any furniture.

Bedroom #5 is utilized by licensee’s biological daughter and remains locked at all times. Bathroom #3 was located in the hallway and inspected to be fully functioning. The laundry room was also inspected and remains locked as it stores cleaning and laundry supplies. The water temperature was tested and measured at 118.5 degrees F. LPAs observed a minimum of seven-day non-perishable and a three-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. In the downstairs space, a trash can was observed to have tight fitting cover. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: personal rights, visitation policy, and current menu. The clients’ medication log records were kept updated with no discrepancy. Four fire extinguishers were observed and operable. All windows and screens were in good repair. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and operable. There were no guns or weapons in the home as stated by Licensee. There was a total of eight cameras, four cameras located in common areas and four outdoor which meets the title 22 camera policy. Based on today's inspection and observations, there are no deficiencies being cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report was provided to Licensee.

During investigations, confidential interviews denied engaging in any physical altercation with C1. The confidential interview continued stating that C1 exhibited physical aggression behaviors and staff would redirect C1. Additional interviews corroborated that C1 would be aggressive and needed to be redirected. However, a statement supported that C1 was chocked by S2 without further explanation or details. Pertaining to the allegation that foster parent did not provide a safe environment for minor, confidential information didn’t indicate any issues with safety while in care. Confidential interviews support that C1 displayed aggressive and assaultive behaviors. The interviews didn’t disclose any specific details regarding C1 being in an unsafe environment Based on confidential interviews and a review of pertinent documents, the allegations that an adult in home engaged in physical altercations with C1, and foster parent did not provide a safe environment for C1 may have occurred, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Licensee.

narrative:
On July 25, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at Spectrum Support Solutions Small Family Home (SFH) pre-licensing inspection for a change in capacity. Currently, there is one client in care, not present at home during the inspection. The home was licensed for a capacity of two clients (ambulatory clients). The applicant is requesting an increase in capacity for four ambulatory clients. The Facility was toured both inside and out with the licensee. The home is a two-story building with five bedrooms and two and half bathrooms. During the inspection, LPA observed that the downstairs consisted of living room, family room, a kitchen, two dining areas with a large table, a half bathroom, storage and a pantry. The garage was inspected and medications were locked in a metal storage file cabinet. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet. The water temperature was tested and measured at 112 degrees F. LPA observed a minimum of seven-day non-perishable and a three-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients. In addition to the downstairs space, there was also office space used as an office, fully furnished. A trash can was observed to have tight fitting cover. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: personal rights, visitation policy, and current menu. The clients’ medication log records were kept updated with no discrepancy. A fire extinguisher was observed and operable.

Upstairs was a master bedroom #1, consisting of a queen size bed and a bathroom, it sleeps licensee. The licensee’s bedroom is not accessible for the clients; bedroom #2 was fully furnished with two twin size beds, a closet and plenty of storage space. It will sleep two clients, it was vacant. Bedroom #3 sleeps a thirty-four-year-old male biological son, it was fully furnished with one king-size bed, a closet, storage space. Bedroom #4, it consists of two twin beds, a closet and plenty of storage space. It sleeps one client. Bedroom #5, consist of queen size bed, a closet and storage space. It sleep a twenty eight-year-old biological daughter. All bedrooms were arranged for one child per bed. No room was commonly used for other purposes other than a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was an adequate drawer and closet space for each child’s belongings. The First Aid Kit was in the upstairs cabinet and contained all required items. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and working properly. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the laundry room. The upstairs space includes an additional bathroom used by the clients. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients have access. All windows and screens were in good repair. There were no guns or weapons in the home as stated by Licensee. There was a total of eight cameras, four located inside and four located outdoors which met the title 22 camera policy. The facility outside grounds were also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. Based on today's inspection and observations, there are no deficiencies being cited at this time. This report will be submitted to the licensing program manager for approval. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was discussed and provided to Licensee.

A copy of this report was provided to applicant Stephen Mbugua.

On April 18, 2024, at 9:25 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rafael Enriquez began a pre-licensing inspection and component III for St Agnes Small Family Home for an initial license. LPA met with applicant Agnes Eyong who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. Currently there are no children placed in the home. The applicant was approved to serve four children ages 0 to 17. The home is a single-story building with five bedrooms and three bath home which is set up as follows: · Bedroom #1 has one bed, will be used as a guest bedroom, it was vacant. · Bedroom #2 sleeps the applicant, has a cal-king bed, has a bathroom, a walk-in closet, and a door to bedroom 3. · Bedroom #3 sleeps 2 biological children, has a bunk bed. · Bedroom #4 will sleep two foster children, has two beds. It was vacant. · Bedroom #5 will sleep two foster children, has two beds. It was vacant. · A formal living room, formal dining room, living room, kitchen with dining area, storage, three bathrooms, three car garage, backyard, and a laundry room. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. Inside the facility the fireplace had appropriate screen cover. Telephone service and appliances were in working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients/children will have access.

Sharp knives and sharp objects were locked in a cabinet in the kitchen. Cleansers/chemicals were inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the laundry room. There was adequate food storage space and a supply of two days of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable food. A proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. The water temperature was observed to be at 106.7 degrees. First Aid kit were accessible with all required items, and it was in a cabinet by the entrance. A Fire extinguisher was observed and properly charged. All the appropriate forms were posted in view of facility clients. As stated by applicant, there were no weapons/firearms and there were no pools or other bodies of water. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. The request for licensure will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to applicant Agnes Eyong.

On June 14, 2024, at 09:45 AM, a post-licensing inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rafael Enriquez. LPA met with licensee Agnes Eyong. During this inspection, LPA and licensee inspected the facility inside and out. The home is a single-story building with five bedrooms and three bathrooms which consists of: · Bedroom #1, is furnished with one twin sized bed. It will be used as a guest bedroom. It was vacant. · Bedroom #2, The master bedroom, furnishes a cal-king bed, has a bathroom, a walk-in closet, and a door to bedroom 3. It sleeps the licensee and her spouse. · Bedroom #3 sleeps 2 biological children, has a bunk bed. · Bedroom #4 will sleep two foster children, has two beds. It was vacant. · Bedroom #5 will sleep two foster children, has two beds. There is one non-Ambulatory client 21 year. · A formal living room, formal dining room, living room, kitchen with dining area, storage, three bathrooms, three car garage, backyard, and a laundry room. The Small Family Home (SFH) is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair, the outdoor area is free of safety hazards, no pool, or other bodies of water on premise. The SFH has adequate supply of perishable and nonperishable foods, chemicals are locked in the laundry room, knives are locked in a kitchen cabinet. The water temperature was measures at 107.4 degrees. Medications are stored in a locked cabinet in the laundry room, the disaster plan, personal rights, and other documentation are properly posted, smoke detectors are operable/tested.

There are no firearms or dangerous weapons per licensee. First aid kit is maintained, and complete. All adults subject to background checks are cleared. Based on observation the SFH is in care of a bedridden client but is only approved for clients that are ambulatory. The facility is being cited for violation of Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 02 Section 80010(b) Limitations on Capacity and Ambulatory Status. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to Licensee Agnes Eyong.

deficiencies.title: 1.	80010(b) Limitations on Capacity and Ambulatory Status
deficiencies.description: (b) Facilities or rooms approved for ambulatory clients only shall not be used by non-ambulatory clients.

narrative:

LPA met with licensee Agnes Eyong, who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the licensee. Licensee is applying for a change of capacity from 4 ambulatory clients ages 0-17 years to 4 clients where 2 are ambulatory, 1 is non-ambulatory and 1 is bedridden, ages 0-17 years . The home consists of: Bedroom #1, is furnished with one twin sized bed. It will be used as a guest bedroom. It was vacant. · Bedroom #2, The master bedroom, furnishes a cal-king bed, has a bathroom, a walk-in closet, and a door to bedroom 3. It sleeps the licensee and her spouse. · Bedroom #3 sleeps 2 biological children, has a bunk bed. · Bedroom #4 will sleep two foster children, has two beds. It was vacant. · Bedroom #5 will sleep one foster child that is non-ambulatory or bedridden, it has one bed. · A formal living room, formal dining room, living room, kitchen with dining area, storage, three bathrooms, three car garage, backyard, and a laundry room.

Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors were checked and were working properly. There are no deficiencies noted at this time. A copy of this report was explained and provided to Licensee Agnes Eyong.

Regarding the allegation that complaint staff did not prevent child from harming other children in care, it was specifically disclosed that C1 hits and pushed other clients against the walls causing bruises on clients. Also, C1 has threatened to strangle other clients in their sleep. Furthermore, it was specifically reported that the foster father was aware of it and law enforcement was contacted. During investigation, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that C1 was playful but sometimes C1 could be rough with other clients, however, C1 did not intent to harm anyone. In addition, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that they have not witnessed C1 hitting or pushing any clients nor causing any bruises on clients. Additionally, confidential interviews disclosed that they were not aware of C1 threatening to strangle clients in their sleep. A confidential interview disclosed that C1 has pushed, grabbed, and threw clients against the walls causing bruises but is not sure if it was intentional or playful. Another confidential interview disclosed that when they tell staff about C1’s behavior, staff tell client not to aggravate C1. Multiple confidential interviews disclosed that they feel safe at the SFH. LPA received conflicting information. Based on interviews, the allegation that staff did not prevent child from harming other children in care may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violation, therefore, this allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Licensee, Agnes Eyong.
investigation_findings: 13On 05/08/2025, at 12:00PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maya Chavez conducted an unannounced visit to St. Agnes Small Family Home (SFH) met with Licensee, Agnes Eyong to deliver the investigative finding for the allegation listed above involving the SFH staff and clients 1-3 (C1, C2, and C3). On 12/10/2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint that staff did not prevent child from harming other children in care. On 12/13/24 LPA Maryjane Perez conducted a health and safety inspection at the SFH, and no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. In addition, LPAs interviewed staff 1-3 (S1, S2, and S3), clients 1 and 3 (C1 and C3), and attempted to interview C2 and C2’s county social worker.

narrative: Regarding the allegation that minor sustained unexplained injuries while in care, it was specifically disclosed that C2 had multiple bruises caused by incidents at school and one specific bruise on upper triceps was caused by foster father grabbing C1 by the arm. During investigation, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that staff have never caused bruises to C2 nor seen any bruises on C2 in general. Another confidential interview disclosed that S3 caused a bruise on C2’s upper arm when S3 grabbed C2. LPA received conflicting information. Regarding the allegation that staff inappropriately grabbed a minor while in care, it was specifically disclosed that the foster father grabbed C1 by the arm after C1 cursed at and pretended to swing at the foster father. During investigation, multiple confidential interviews that they did not witness staff grabbing C2 by the arm. A confidential interview disclosed that recently when C2 was getting out of control trying to hit S3, S3 grabbed C2’s hand and redirected C2 to their room but it was not aggressive. In addition, a confidential interview disclosed that S3 grabbed C2 by the upper arm but did not know why. LPA received conflicting information. Based on interviews, the allegation that C1 sustained unexplained injuries while in care and that staff inappropriately grabbed C1 while in care may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violation, therefore, this allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Licensee, Agnes Eyong.
investigation_findings: 13On 05/08/2025, at 12:00PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maya Chavez conducted an unannounced visit to St. Agnes Small Family Home (SFH) met with Licensee, Agnes Eyong to deliver the investigative finding for the allegation listed above involving the SFH staff and clients 1-3 (C1, C2, and C3). On 1/27/2025, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging that a minor sustained unexplained injuries while in care and staff inappropriately grabbed a minor while in care. On 1/29/25 LPA Maryjane Perez conducted a health and safety inspection at the SFH, and no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. In addition, LPAs interviewed staff 1-3 (S1, S2, and S3), clients 1-3 (C1, C2, and C3), and C3’s County Social Worker.

narrative: Regarding the allegation that facility staff made inappropriate comments towards a minor, it was specifically disclosed that the foster father gave C1 a post-it note that said to call him when C1 turns eighteen and he will buy C1 an iPhone for C1’s birthday. During investigation, it was disclosed that the foster father did not give C1 a note. Additionally, confidential interview disclosed that the foster father never said nor did anything inappropriate to C1. Another confidential interview disclosed that C1’s mother sent C1’s CSW a picture of a post-it note with the foster father’s phone number and name but CSW was unsure if it pertained to the allegation or if it was just the foster father’s contact information incase C1 needed it. Confidential interviews also stated that a post-it note was written by both S1 and S2 for C1’s bio-mother to get in contact with them in the future. Multiple interviews disclosed that there were no concerns between the foster father and C1. LPA received conflicting information. Based on interviews, the allegation that facility staff made inappropriate comments towards C1 may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violation, therefore, this allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Licensee, Agnes Eyong.
investigation_findings: 13On 05/08/2025, at 12:00PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maya Chavez conducted an unannounced visit to St. Agnes Small Family Home (SFH) met with Licensee, Agnes Eyong to deliver the investigative finding for the allegation listed above involving the SFH staff and client 1 (C1). On 2/21/2025, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint that staff made inappropriate comments towards a minor. On 3/3/2025 LPA Maryjane Perez conducted a health and safety inspection at the SFH and no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. In addition, LPAs interviewed staff 1-4 (S1, S2, S3, and S4), clients 1-3 (C1, C2, and C3), and C1’s County Social Worker.

narrative: Regarding the allegation that that staff did not ensure youth was accorded personal privacy while in care and that staff touches youth in an inappropriate manner, it was specifically disclosed that (S2) walked into the restroom while C1 was showering (unknown what S2 did or how many times this occurred) and would kiss C1 on the forehead (no details). During investigation, a confidential interview disclosed that C1’s CSW did not know much about the allegations and that C1 never disclosed any concerns. In addition, a confidential interview disclosed that one time while C1 was using the restroom, C1 asked someone to bring C1 toilet paper and then S1 walked in but did not give C1 toilet paper and C1 did not know why S1 walked into the restroom but it was not on accident. Furthermore, confidential interview disclosed that no one ever walked in the restroom while C1 was showering. Another confidential interview stated that staff would help C1 turn on the shower but C1 was always fully clothed and S1 was present while other staff would adjust the water. Confidential interviews continued stating that the door was always open when staff was assisting. Moreover, a confidential interview disclosed that S1 never kissed C1 nor did/said anything inappropriate towards C1. The confidential interview added that clients are allowed to lock the door while using the restroom for privacy. LPA received conflicting information. Based on interviews, the allegations that staff did not ensure C1 was accorded personal privacy while in care and that S1 touches C1 in an inappropriate manner may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violations, therefore, this allegation are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Licensee, Agnes Eyong.

investigation_findings: 13On 05/02/2025, at 12:00PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maya Chavez conducted an unannounced visit to St. Agnes Small Family Home (SFH) met with Licensee, Agnes Eyong to deliver the investigative finding for the allegations listed above involving the SFH staff and client 1 (C1). narrative: Another confidential interview stated that S3 doesn’t pose a risk to the minors in the home. narrative:
On September 23, 2024, at 9:00AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karen Beal a Pre-Licensing inspection at Suitable Home Small Family Home (SFH). LPA met with applicant Ramses Boutin who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. Applicant is applying for a small family Home with a capacity of 3 ambulatory children. The home consists of: Downstairs: Bedroom #1, It is furnished with twin daybed. It will sleep one client - Vacant. There were also a family room, a living room, dining area, a kitchen, gym, storage, 3 car garage and bathroom. Upstairs: Bedroom #2, It was furnished a queen bed. It sleeps the bio child Bedroom #3, The room consisted of twin bed and baby bed. Vacant Bedroom #4, The room was furnished with a queen bed. Vacant. Bedroom #5, Master bedroom. The room consisted of one king sized bed, office space, and bathroom Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors were checked and were working properly.

Continued from LIC 9099 Inside the facility there is an operable smoke detector/carbon monoxide located throughout the house. The fireplaces are properly screened. The medications and sharps are locked and stored under the staircase. No weapons as stated by the applicant. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 118 degrees. Proper storage of all food was noted. The Emergency Disaster Plan posted at this time. The backyard where children will have access to play is completely fenced and free of hazards. There is no pool or other body of water. The home has fountain in the front yard that is enclosed. The fence completely surrounds the fountain is located at the entrance of the home . The Licensee meet the requirements for the 8 hours of annual foster care training. Licensee’s First Aid and CPR cards expire on 5/20/25. Synthia Boutin must complete first aid/CPR training and take some training courses before the license is issued. A copy of this report was provided to Ramses Boutin.

met_with: Veronica Cano Contreras and Annette Vera
narrative:
On January 14, 2025, at 9:37 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jose Gonzalez began a pre-licensing inspection for Sunrise Home Small Family Home license. LPA met with applicant Veronica Cano Contreras and Annette Vera who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. Currently there are no clients placed in the home. The applicant is applying to serve three clients ages 0 to 17. The home is a two-story building with four bedrooms and 2 bathrooms and one-half bathroom which are set up as follows: · Bedroom #1 (Master) has one bed, will sleep the licensee, and has a master bathroom. · Bedroom #2 (Client) was vacant, and had one has one full size bed; it will sleep one client. · Bedroom #3 (Adult Child) had one full size bed, will sleep licensee son. · Bedroom #4 (Adult Child) had one full size bed, will sleep licensee daughter. · Downstair has two living rooms, two dining areas, kitchen, a half bathroom, an attached two car garage, storage closet, pantry, sunroom, and the backyard. The Client’s bedroom was arranged so that no more than one client will share the room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate closet space for the client’s belongings. There was a smoke detector in every bedroom and one carbon monoxide detector located in the hallway. The smoke detectors and the carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. The home’s central air conditioning module was located outside of the home in the side yard. The home’s hot water heater was located inside the garage. Inside the facility there was a Gated fireplace. The appliances were in working order. All sharp knives were located under the kitchen sink in a locked container. CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE

The client’s files will be locked inside a locked file cabinet in the master bedroom. There was adequate food storage space. A proper storage of all food was discussed. A trash can for storage of solid waste had a tight-fitting lid and was located in the second dining area. The client bathroom also had a trash can with a working lid. Cleaning supplies were located in the garage in a locked cabinet. The water temperature of the client bathroom 1 was observed to be 119.1 degrees Fahrenheit and the water temperature of the half bathroom 2 was observed to be 118.5 degrees Fahrenheit. Medications were located in the master bedroom locked in container. The home’s First Aid kit was accessible with all required items included and located in the client’s bathroom under the sink cabinet. A fire extinguisher was present in the home and located on the wall in the second living room. It was observed to be properly charged. Applicant stated there were no weapons/firearms in the home. LPA observed there were no swimming pool. The backyard where clients will have access to play was completely fenced. The facility sketch, emergency plan, and client rights were hung on the pantry door. No deficiencies were observed: Licensee informed LPA that she was going to work one client at this time. Licensee informed LPA that she would get additional beds before she accepted additional clients. Licensee informed LPA that her son (bedroom # 3) was moving out in February. LPA explained the reporting requirements and submit licensing reports to cclpaccr@dss.ca.gov The request for a license will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval once the Plan of Corrections are cleared. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to Veronica Cano Contreras.

In regard to the allegation that licensee was not allowing C1 to the home, it was specifically alleged that licensee kicked client out of the home for a few hours because licensee was upset with client (unknown reason) and client was screaming, crying, and banging on the door to be let back in. A confidential interview stated that C1 was upset with the licensee because licensee didn’t allow C1 to go to a friend’s house and decided to lay outside of the home with a blanket refusing to go inside the home. The same interview reported that law enforcement was called previously because C1 had ran away from the home due to not feeling comfortable in the home. Another confidential interview reported that C1 refused to go inside the home because C1 didn’t want to live in the SFH anymore. The interview continued stating that licensee and A1 opened the window to keep an eye on C1 laying in front of the SFH since they were not allowed to forcefully bring C1 in. Furthermore, the confidential interview reported that C1 voluntarily came inside the home and went to C1’s room after a few minutes. One confidential interview stated that licensee would lock the doors of the home on C1 because licensee would be upset about C1 going to the neighbor’s home and talk to the neighbor about what was going on in the SFH. The interview stated that police showed up to the home and told C1 to go back inside the home, but C1 didn’t want to go inside the SFH. There were no reports of why C1 didn’t want to live in the SFH. A confidential interview indicated that C1’s representative had no concerns about the care and supervision from licensee and added that C1’s behaviors began to escalate and C1 had a hard time following directions and rules. Regarding the allegation that licensee used inappropriate forms of discipline, a confidential interview stated that C1 had a wraparound team meeting, and the agreement was to take the television away as a form of discipline. Another confidential interview reported that taking the television away was the only form of discipline used in the home. One confidential interview stated that C1 would go outside, or television privileges were taken as a form of punishment. County Social Worker stated not having any concerns on inappropriate discipline in the home and licensee used taking away the television as a form of punishment as discussed in the wraparound team meeting. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that licensee is not allowing C1 access to the home and licensee used inappropriate form of discipline may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the alleged violations. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were provided to licensee Veronica Cano.

During investigation, confidential interview stated LS niece was spanked privately by LS. The confidential interview added no foster child was in the home or witnessed niece being spanked. Another confidential interview did not witness a child being spanked in the home by LS. The confidential interview never observed anyone being spanked in the home. Additional confidential interview did not spank child in the home. Additional confidential interview stated child was not a foster child and child had returned to parent. Based on the confidential interviews, the allegation that LS and SP in the home physically abuse minor, may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report and LIC 811 was provided to the licensee at the SFH.
