narrative: On March 4, 2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes met with Applicant Tashima Martin via Microsoft Teams to complete a component II interview. A signed copy of this report will be placed in facility file.

On April 23, 2024 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes completed a pre-licensing inspection of Tashima Small Family Home. LPA met with Applicant Tashima Martin who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. Currently there are no clients in placement. The home is a two story building with five bedrooms and three bathrooms which are set up as follows: · Bedroom #1 (Applicants) has one bed will sleep the applicant. · Bedroom #2 (sons) has one bed and sleeps the son. · Bedroom #3 (daughter) has one bed, it sleeps the daughter. · Bedroom #4 (daughters) has one bed, it sleeps the daughter. · Bedroom #5 (Client’s) has 2 beds, it will sleep two clients. · A great room/living room, kitchen, dining area, three bathrooms, laundry room, two car garage, play room, and the backyard. The Client’s bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two client’s will be in a room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate closet space for the client’s belongings. There was a smoke detector/carbon monoxide in every bedroom. The five smoke detectors/carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. The home’s central air conditioning module was located on the side of the house. The home’s hot water heater was located in the garage. The appliances were in working order. The client’s files will be locked inside a locked cabinet in the laundry room. There was adequate food storage space and a supply of two days of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable foods.

A trash can for storage of solid waste had a tight-fitting lid and was present. The sharp knives will be in a locked cabinet in the laundry room. The medications will be located in a locked cabinet in the laundry room. The hot water in bathroom one measured to be 119.1 degrees Fahrenheit, bathroom two was 109.4 degrees Fahrenheit, and in bathroom three 106.3 degrees Fahrenheit. The home’s First Aid kit was accessible and is located in a cabinet in the hallway and contained all required supplies. There was two fire extinguishers present in the home one is located in the kitchen by the kitchen cabinets and one is located upstairs in the hallway. They were observed to be properly charged and inspected by the fire department. There are no fire arms in the home as stated by the applicant. There is no pool or other body of water at the home. The backyard where clients will have access to play is fenced. There are no corrections that need to be made at this time A component III was conducted. An exit interview was conducted. Application will be forwarded to the Licensing Program Manager for Licensing.

On February 24, 2022, at 11:16am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adrian Mendez, conducted an unannounced Required Annual inspection of the facility. LPA was met at the facility by Licensee Tawania Alvarez. The home is a one story two bedroom condominium/apartment. The home is equipped with two full baths and an exterior laundry facility. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate drawer and closet space for the children’s belongings. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medications are locked and stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in the locked cabinet beneath the kitchen sink. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet beneath the kitchen sink. The first aid kit is located in the locked medication cabinet in the kitchen. There are no guns or weapons as stated by the Licensee. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be within regulatory requirements. Proper storage of all food was noted. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights, and the Emergency Disaster Plan was also posted. A review of staff files indicates that staff files contained all required documentation per Title 22 Regulations. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. LPA reviewed two client files, and all files did have the necessary documents required per regulations. Cont. on 809-C

LPA also observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. The exterior of facility was also inspected and observed to be clean well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. One facility staff was interviewed during the inspection. No clients were present at the time of the inspection. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews, there are no deficiencies found at this time. A copy of this report, along with a Confidential Names List (LIC 811 dated 02/24/2022) were explained and provided to Licensee Tawania Alvarez.

On September 13, 2022 at 9 am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) JoAunne Griffin arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Component II and Component III inspection. LPA and LPM were met by Farisha Taylor, Administrator and Adult 1 allowed access into the facility. LPA and LPM toured home and discussed the licensing process with Farisha Taylor and Evan Brown. The facility layout is as follows: This is a single family home located in a residential area. Home consist of living room, kitchen, laundry area, three bedrooms, two bathrooms and detached garage. Bedroom 1: Consists of two twin size beds, television and storage space for clothes and personal belongings. Bedroom is currently not be occupied and room is designated for clients. Bedroom 2: Consist of queen size bed, dresser, television and closet. Closet contains a firearm located in the a combination/key safe. The ammunition is stored separately in Bedroom 3 closet. Bedroom 2 is occupied by Farisha Taylor and Adult 1. Bedroom will be inaccessible to children in care. Bedroom 3: Consist of queen size bed, dresser, couch, and television. The second bathroom is located in this room. This room is occupied by Adult 2. Cleaning supplies and medication is tripled locked in bedroom closet and inaccessible to children in care. Cont 809-C

Laundry area: Located next to kitchen and consist of large washer and dryer. Cleaning tools are also located in this area. Garage: Is detached from home. Garage area remains locked and is only accessible to the owner and inaccessible to residents. The front and back yard is free of debris and hazards. met_with: Licensee's - Farisha Taylor and Evan Brown
narrative:
On April 24, 2023 at 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White arrived at Taylor Small Family Home for the purpose of conducting a Post Licensing Inspection. LPA met with Licensee's, Farisha Taylor and Evan Brown who granted access to the home and together a tour of the interior and exterior home was conducted. The facility is licensed to provide care and supervision services for two (2) children, ages 3-17 years old, ambulatory only. The census today is zero (0) and living in the home currently are the Licensee and Adult 1. The facility is set up as follows: This is a single-story 3 bedroom, 2 bathroom, home located in a residential area. The home consists of a living room, dining room, kitchen, laundry area, a backyard, and a detached garage. Living room: is equipped with a sectional sofa, a mounted flat screen television, and an electric fire place. Dining room: is equipped with a table four (4) chairs, and a bench. Kitchen: is equipped with a refrigerator/freezer, a five (5) burner gas stove/oven (all burners were operational at the time of this inspection), dish washer, and a microwave. Sharp knives are kept in a magnetically locked kitchen drawer. Cleaning supplies are kept under the kitchen sink in a magnetically locked cabinet and made inaccessible to children in care. The kitchen also has an exit door that leads to the side of the home. Laundry area: is located off the kitchen and is equipped with a washer and a dryer; there is a stand-alone pantry located in this area; and a fully charged fire extinguisher, and cleaning tools are stored in this area. Backyard: contains a covered charcoal grill and a small water hose storage container. Detached garage: LPA observed the garage to be used for storage; it remains locked at all times and is made inaccessible to children in care. Bedroom #1: is designated for clients. The room is equipped with two twin size beds, a stand-alone storage unit for clothes, cube storage bins, a television, a working light, and two windows. This room was vacant at the time of the inspection. Report continued on LIC 809C.

Bedroom #2: is vacant. This room was not equipped with any furniture at the time of this inspection. The room contains a working light, windows, and a closet which LPA observed to store clothing items. The closet also contains a firearm located in a combination/key safe. Bedroom #3: is occupied by Licensee and Adult 1. The room is equipped a queen size bed, dresser, television, a working light, windows, and a closet. The closet contains personal belongings, firearm ammunition stored in a combination safe, additional cleaning supplies, and a medication lock box. The closet remains locked at all times and made inaccessible to children in care. (2) Bathrooms: one bathroom is located along the hallway, and the second bathroom is located inside bedroom #3. The bathrooms contain a toilet, sink, and a combination shower/tub. The hot water was tested and found to be with 105-120 (F) LPA observed one (1) fully charged fire extinguisher. The hallway has cabinets which store extra linen. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. Medications are stored in a locked box inside the closet in bedroom #3 and made inaccessible to children in care. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept locked inside the closet in bedroom #3 and in a locked cabinet under the kitchen sink. The home has a working telephone readily accessible to children in care. The First Aid Kit was checked and found to be complete. LPA observed the home to be clean, safe, and sanitary. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps and open porches are unobstructed. The front and backyard were clean and free of debris. There are no bodies of water located on the premises. The water shut off valve is located in the front of the home. LPA reminded Licensee to ensure the following when children are in placement: Children are accorded personal rights and the corresponding form is in their file. Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Licensee acknowledges abuse reporting requirements. During the visit, LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. All posting requirements for Small Family Home Licensure and Emergency Plan were met. The home currently has no staff or clients placed in the home. An exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with the Licensee, Farisha Taylor

Bedroom #3: is occupied by Licensee and Adult 1. The room is furnished with a queen size bed, dresser, television, a working light, windows, and a closet. The closet contains personal belongings, a medication lock box, firearm ammunition stored in a combination safe, and additional cleaning supplies. (2) Bathrooms: one bathroom is located along the hallway, and the second bathroom is located inside bedroom #3. The bathrooms contain a toilet, sink, and a combination shower/tub. The hot water was tested and found to be with 105-120 (F). The hallway has cabinets which store extra linen. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. Medications are stored in a locked box inside the closet in bedroom #3 and made inaccessible to children in care. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept locked under the kitchen sink. The home has a working telephone readily accessible to children in care. The First Aid Kit was checked and found to be complete. LPA observed the home to be clean, safe, and sanitary. Licensees ensure that children in placement are accorded personal rights and the corresponding form is in their file. Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. LPA reviewed the following records during the inspection: Client Records: The home currently has a total of one (1) client. LPA reviewed the client’s records and found the record to meet required regulations. LPA obtained the LIC 9240. Staff Records: The home currently has a total of one (1) staff and the Administrator. LPA reviewed a total of two (2) staff records and confirmed files contained staff qualifications, current CPR/First Aid cards, health screening, and TB test results. LPA obtained the LIC 500. All personnel have required criminal record clearance: DOJ, FBI and Child Abuse, which meet qualification. LPA conducted interviews with one (1) client, one (1) staff, and the Administrator. An exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with the Licensee, Farisha Taylor.

On February 28, 2025, at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analysts, LPA, Kim Dear and LPA Dennis Jarmin arrived at the Taylor Small Family Home to conduct an Annual Licensing Inspection. LPAs met with Licensees Farisha Taylor and Evan Brown, who granted access to the home for the inspection. A health and safety inspection were conducted upon entrance into the facility. The home is licensed to provide care and supervision for two ambulatory children, ages 3-17 years old. At the time of the inspection, there were currently no children in placement. Also residing in the home were the Licensees, one adult, and a seventeen-month-old, biological child. Facility Overview The home is a single-story, three bedroom, two bathroom residence that includes a living room, dining room, kitchen, laundry area, backyard, and detached garage. · Living Room: Furnished with two large sofas, a glass coffee table, a mounted flat-screen TV, an electric fireplace, large bean bag and a portable air conditioning unit. · Dining Room: Contains a glass table with four chairs and a three seater bench. · Kitchen: Equipped with a five burner gas stove/oven, refrigerator/freezer, and dishwasher. All burners were operational at the time of the inspection. Sharp knives are stored in a magnetically locked drawer, and cleaning supplies are kept in a secured cabinet under the sink, inaccessible to children. The kitchen has an exit leading to the right side of the home and the backyard.

Laundry Area: Located next to the kitchen, it contains a washer, dryer, stand-alone pantry, cleaning tools, and a fully charged fire extinguisher. · Backyard: Features a covered charcoal grill and a small water hose storage container. · Detached Garage: Remains always locked and is used for storage. Bedrooms and Sleeping Arrangements · Bedroom #1: Occupied by Client #1, furnished with two twin-size beds, a storage unit for clothing, a television, a working light, and two windows. · Bedroom #2: Occupied by the biological child, furnished with a crib, working light, windows, and a closet. A firearm is securely stored in a combination/key safe inside the closet. · Bedroom #3: Occupied by the Licensee and Adult 1, furnished with a queen-size bed, dresser, television, working light, windows, and a closet. The closet contains personal belongings, a medication lock box, firearm ammunition stored in a combination safe, and additional cleaning supplies. Bathrooms The home has two bathrooms—one in the hallway and another inside Bedroom #3. Both contain a toilet, sink, and a combination shower/tub. The hot water was tested and measured between 105-120°F, within the required range. Health & Safety Compliance The hallway has cabinets used for storing extra linens. Smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found operational.

Medications are stored in a locked box in the closet of Bedroom #3, ensuring they are inaccessible to children. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are secured under the kitchen sink. A working telephone is available for children in care. The First Aid Kit was checked and found complete. LPAs observed the home to be clean, safe, and sanitary, with unobstructed passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps, and porches. The front and backyard were clean and free of debris. No bodies of water were present on the premises. Children’s Rights & Facility Compliance Licensees ensure that children in placement are granted their personal rights, which are documented in their files. Children are encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities and can contact licensing authorities confidentially without fear of retaliation. They are treated with dignity and respect. LPA emphasized the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and notifying the Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) of any changes in the facility. The home meets all posting requirements for Small Family Home licensor and the Emergency Plan. Records Review LPA reviewed the following records during the inspection: · Client Records: No client records were reviewed as there are no clients in placed in the home. LPA obtained the LIC 500. · Staff Records: The home has Licensee, one adult and no staff. LPA reviewed both files and confirmed compliance with staff qualifications, CPR/First Aid certification, health screenings, and TB test results. LPA obtained the LIC 500.

·Background Clearances: All personnel have the required DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Index clearances. Interviews and Exit Meetings LPA conducted interviews with the Licensees. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Licensees. Inspection Findings: No deficiencies were observed during this inspection. The home remains in substantial compliance with licensing regulations.

investigation_findings: 13On October 3, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White arrived at Taylor Small Family Home (SFH) for the purpose of delivering findings for the above allegation. LPA met with Licensee, Farisha Taylor. During the course of this investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews and reviewed records. Licensee denied the allegation and stated the Child was no longer placed in the home. Licensee stated the child Awoled on 03/19/2024, per an emergency CFT meeting held 03/20/2024, the child’s placement ended 03/21/2024, and that an Emergency Social Worker attempted to pick the child up on 03/22/2024, however child was still Awol. LPA was unable to obtain a statement from Child #1. Moreover, documentary evidence did not corroborate the allegation. Based on information obtained, the allegation is found to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. There were no deficiencies cited. An exit interview was completed, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

The applicant is applying to serve 3 clients ages 0 to 5. The home is a two story building with four bedrooms and three bathrooms which are set up as follows: · Bedroom #1 (Master) has one bed and one crib, will sleep the licensee, and one infant client and has a master bathroom. · Bedroom #2 (Client’s) was vacant had two twin beds, it will sleep two client’s. · Bedroom #3 (daughter) had two twin beds, it sleeps the daughter. · Bedroom #4 (sons) had one full bed, it sleeps the son. · A great room/living room, kitchen, dining area, three bathrooms, a play room, a loft, an attached two car garage, storage closet, and the backyard. The Client’s bedroom was arranged so that no more than two client’s will be in the room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate closet space for the client’s belongings. There was a smoke detector in every bedroom and a carbon monoxide detector located above the clients bedroom door. The four smoke detectors and the carbon monoxide detector were checked, and they were working properly. The home’s central air conditioning module was on the patio. The home’s water heater was located inside the garage. Inside the facility there was a fireplace with a gate in the front. The appliances were in working order. CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE:

The client’s files will be locked inside a cabinet in the in the play room. There was adequate food storage space and a supply of two days of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable foods. On October 2, 2023 at 11:42 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie began a Pre-Licensing inspection for a Small Family Home license. LPA met with applicant Ashley Daniels who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. Applicant is applying for a capacity of 2 ambulatory clients. The home consists of: Downstairs: Bedroom #1, It was furnished with a king sized bed. It is used as a guest room. There were also a family room, a living room, dining area, kitchen and one bathroom. Upstairs: Bedroom #2, Master bedroom. The room consisted of one king sized bed. It sleeps the applicant. Bedroom #3, The room was furnished with two twin beds. It will sleep two clients - vacant. Bedroom #4, The room was furnished with a desk and chairs. It is used as an office. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. The smoke detectors were checked and were working properly.

Inside the facility the fireplace was properly screened. Telephone service and appliances were in a working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medication will be locked in the office cabinet. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the garage cupboard. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in the locked kitchen cabinet by the cooking stove. There were no guns or weapons as stated by applicant at this time. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 110 degrees. Proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. First Aid kit were accessible with all required items, and it was in the office. A Fire extinguisher was observed and properly charged. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, visitation policy and Personal Rights were posted. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. The request to be licensed for small family home will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. Component III was conduct with the applicant Ashley Daniels. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to Applicant/Licensee
